Pleiades Change Log: 2023-04-04 - 2023-08-01

New Place Resources

  • Abbatija tad-Dejr
    A multi-period burial site located in the northwest of modern Ir-Rabat, Malta. Archaeological evidence points to first use of the site in the Punic and Roman periods. A quarry of possible Roman date was used in the construction of Byzantine-period hypogea. Further modifications were made in the late Medieval (post-Muslim) period, prior to abandonment of the site.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Abbazia di San Giovanni in Venere
    A Christian monastic complex that is located in the municipality of Fossacesia, Italy. The site occupies a hilltop at 107 m above sea level on the Adriatic Sea coast. The basilica dates originally from the thirteenth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Abbey of Santissima Trinità, Venosa
    The Abbey of Santissima Trinità at Venosa was a Roman Catholic abbey that exhibits numerous architectural influences. Its remains now lie within the archaeological park of Venosa. The complex includes several principal parts in addition to the church, including monastery buildings and the so-called "Incompiuta", a church project of the eleventh century that was begun but never completed.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Abū Fanduwā
    Find place for cuneiform text, located in the modern Hoseynabad-e Goruh Rural District of Iran's Kerman province.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ada / Adalar
    Ada / Adalar is a village in Southeast Anatolia. It is located a few kilometres southwest of Malazgirt in the Turkish province Muş. Nearby is a rock inscription of the Urartian King Minua (ca. 810-785/80 BCE), in which he reports the construction of a Canal named "Canal of Minua", which is still in use today. In Late Antiquity, the canal was attributed to the legendary Queen Semiramis by the Armenian historian Movses Khorenatsi (ca. 410–490s).
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen; Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Adams 1069 (find site)
    An archaeological site designated by Robert McC. Adams as 1069 that consisted of a settlement mound that was the find spot for a cuneiform inscription. The site’s ancient name is unknown.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ad Palmam
    Ad Palmam was a place in North Africa and is included on the Peutinger map. It is located along the route from a place called Lacene, also unlocated, to Tacape.
    Creators: Richard Talbert
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ad Silma
    Ad Silma was a place in Africa Proconsularis that is included on the Tabula Peutingeriana. It was located approximately 12 miles (ca. 18 km) northeast of Bulla Regia.
    Creators: Richard Talbert
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Afas Lupeici
    Afas Lupeici is a place included on the Tabula Peutingeriana. It was situated roughly 10 miles to the south of Martae and 5 miles to the north of Augarmi.
    Creators: Richard Talbert
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Agamemnoneion of Mycenae
    An archaeological site near the Mycenaean causeway has been interpreted as a multi-period heroön dedicated to Agamemnon.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Agbia amphitheater
    A Roman amphitheater located at Agbia in what is now Tunisia (Henchir Ain Hedja).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Agora at Kibyra
    The agora of ancient Kibyra.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Akropolis of Klazomenai
    The Akropolis of Klazomenai
    Creators: Peter Cobb; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Alburnus Maior
    A settlement and gold mining complex at modern Roşia Montană in Romania. The Roșia Montană Mining Landscape was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 2021.
    Creators: J.J. Wilkes
    Contributors: Tom Elliott; Richard Talbert
  • Alekseev
    Bronze Age settlement and associated burial site located on the left bank of the Tobol river in northern Kazakhstan.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Al-Ḥilah
    Find place for a Kassite cylinder seal in modern city of Al-Ḥilah.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Al-Khiḍr
    Dilmun Bronze age settlement
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Al-Maqsha
    Village in Bahrain, find place for cuneiform inscribed stele.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Al-Mukhaṭṭaṭ
    Site with large mud brick platform, supposedly find place for Old Babylonian Dilbat cuneiform tablets.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson
    Contributors: Rune Rattenborg
  • Alonianum
    Alonianum was a place in Africa that is included on the Peutinger map. It is likely a road station positioned along the way from Thelepte to Tacapae via the palus Tritonis.
    Creators: Richard Talbert
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Altessera
    Now unlocated, Altessera was likely a road station in North Africa. Based on its inclusion on the Peutinger map, it lies along the route from Althiburos to Assuras.
    Creators: Richard Talbert
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Altyn-Asar
    The largest site of the Dzhetyasar culture, Altyn-Asar is a fortified settlement in the Syr Darya region inhabited from the 5th century BCE-8th century CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Ancient Agora of Argos
    The Agora of ancient Argos.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ancient sanctuary at Marion
    An Iron Age sanctuary located at Peristeries in Polis Chrysochous, Cyprus, dedicated to the female goddess of Cyprus that was in use for half a millennium, from ca. 950 to ca. 450 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aqua Cernens
    An aqueduct at Rome that is mentioned only in the Notitia for Regio VIII.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aquinum, Thermae
    Roman baths at Aquinum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Archaeological Site at Plasi of Marathon
    The excavations at Plasi, Marathon, have revealed evidence across a broad chronological spectrum, including evidence of an archaic sanctuary.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Area archeologica di Casarinaccio
    During archaeological excavations carried out between 1926 and 1934 in Casarinaccio (Ardea), a monumental complex was identified. This consisted of a late republican basilica (first century BCE) and the remains of an archaic temple dedicated to Venus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Area archeologica di Colle della Noce
    The ancient temple in the sacred area of Colle della Noce dates to the fifth and fourth century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aşağı Anzaf Fortress
    The Aşağı Anzaf Fortress ("Lower Anzaf Fortress") is situated in the Van region in southeast Turkey. It was built by the Urartian King Išpuini (9th / 8th century BCE) who reports about his building activity in several building inscriptions (see especially the building inscription on the fortification wall (CTU A 2-6). Another fortress at Anzaf, namely Yukarı Anzaf (Upper Anzaf) was built by Išpuini's son Minua (9th / 8th century BCE).
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Seidler
  • Asklepeion of Ancient Trichoneion
    An excavated sanctuary sacred to Asklepios located at Gavalou in Aitoloakarnania West Greece.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Asklepieion of Trikka
    The Asklepieion of Trikka was said to be the oldest such sanctuary in Greece.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Assur Archive 16
    In the area of the western outer wall of the prince’s palace in Assur, in lA9II, as well as in other parts of the palace, a library and an archive were found. Assur Archive 16 consists of at least 89 clay tablets, a small prism and two cylinder fragments, as well as an Aramaic docket. The texts date from 708 to 658 BC, with one text dating to the time of Adad-nirari I (1305–1274 BC). The texts mostly consist of incantations, including incantations for protection, against sickness or against an enemy. Other texts include prescriptions against sickness, a portion of the poem of the righteous sufferer, a hemerology, a list of eponyms, historical texts, as well as administrative documents such as a list of cow- and sheep-hides, a letter, a field purchase document, a legal settlement, and the Aramaic docket.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Assur Archive 17
    In the Old Palace of the city of Assur, excavators discovered a Neo-Assyrian archive consisting of 10 clay tablets. It includes multiple lists of charioteers.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Assur Archive 18
    At the eastern corner of the large ziggurat in Assur, a group of clay tablets were unearthed in a house in area hB4V. Forty clay tablets were found above a sarcophagus, 25 clay tablets were also located nearby and either some or all of them could belong to the first group. Additionally, a clay pot, containing 13 tablets, was found in a door opening of a different house. The texts seem to form a library, except for the tablets in the pot, which formed a separate archive (Assur Archive 51). The library, dating primarily to the 7th century BCE, belonged to a family of scribes and mainly contained documents pertaining to that profession: lexical lists, astronomical and astrological texts, omens, incantations, other literary texts, and drafts or copies of royal inscriptions.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 19
    In a private house in Assur, cut into by the excavation trench 6III, researchers found the remains of a library and an archive, consisting of at least 136 tablets and possibly 52 more tablets. The texts date from the 8th and 7th centuries BCE. The two or three best-attested individuals in Assur Archive 19 held the title nargallu, "chief singer" or "musician". The library contained many hymns and similar texts, but also other literary texts such as myths, hemerological texts, royal inscriptions, and various lexical lists. The archive, mixed with the library, includes loan and purchase documents, as well as other texts.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 20
    In a private house in Assur, cut into by the excavation trench 8I, researchers found the remains of a library and an archive, consisting of at least 800 tablets, making it the largest library excavated in Assur. The library, mostly dating to the 7th century BC, belonged to a family of exorcists with ties to the Aššur temple. Under the floors of most of excavated rooms in this house, researchers found brick boxes with apotropaic figurines. The library consisted mainly of incantations and prescriptions, but also prayers, lists of stones and plants for medical use, lexical lists, hemerological texts, as well as texts concerning the ruler's attitudes to the cult and of the destruction and rebuilding of Babylon; additionally, texts such as ration lists form an archive.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 21
    In what seems to be a Neo-Assyrian layer inside a Parthian house in hC10IV, excavators found the remains of a library, consisting of about 20 fragmentary clay tablets. The largest group of texts are incantations, but the library also included a prayer, lexical lists and a list of persons, as well as a literary text detailing the netherworld vision of an Assyrian prince. One of the texts, a memorandum, dates to the reign of Sin-šarru-iškun (ca. 626–612 BC).
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Assur Archive 22
    In a private house in cD9II, excavators found the remains of a small library of 25 fragmentary clay tablets with a few other tablets nearby. Most of these are literary texts and date to the Sargonid period. The library consists of epics, an omen series, a commentary on an omen series, either a commentary or a vocabulary, and a list of persons. Possibly, the library also includes a king list and a text listing the duties of priests of the Aššur temple.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 23
    In a private house in Assur, cut into by the excavation trench eD10I, researchers found eight clay tablets and a stamp seal. One of the texts can be dated to 717 BC. The group of texts mostly includes school tablets, as well as a purchase document and an incantation in the form of a letter, written in Babylonian script.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 24
    In the northern corner, along the northwest town wall of Assur (bE4V, bD/E5I), researchers unearthed House 66 with an archive belonging to a family with the title ḫunduraya, a gentilic meaning "from Ḫundur". Another archive belonging to a related family of ḫunduraya was found nearby (Assur Archive 25). In House 66, a total of 86 clay tablets were found, including one docket. Of these, 64 tablets were found in Room k near the inner courtyard, while others were found in the courtyard and in the rooms to its southwest. Available datings range from 681 BC to the last years of the Assyrian Empire. The archive includes legal documents, such as loan documents concerning silver, textiles and straw, purchase documents, receipts, work contracts and juridical settlements.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Assur Archive 25
    In the northern corner, along the northwest town wall of Assur (bD5I, bC/D5II, bC5III), researchers unearthed Houses 67–68 with an archive belonging to a family with the title ḫunduraya, a gentilic meaning "from Ḫundur". Another archive belonging to a related family of ḫunduraya was found nearby (Assur Archive 24). In House 67 and 68, about 48 clay tablets and fragments were found. The tablets mostly date to the second half of the 7th century BC. The archive consists of loans, mostly concerning silver, work contracts, purchase documents and a juridical settlement.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Assur Archive 26
    Southwest of the Adad ziqqurrat in Assur, in dE5V, researchers found 6 clay tablets, some of which had envelopes, in the remains of a destroyed private house. The archive, belonging to Dadaya, dates to the reigns of Aššur-etel-ilāni (ca. 630–627 BC) and Sin-šarru-iškun (ca. 626-612 BC) and mostly contains loan documents.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 27
    In a house in Assur, between the southwest side of the Anu-Adad temple and the remains of the inner wall of Shalmaneser III, researchers found a small archive of 9 clay tablets and 6 clay envelopes in a clay pot (Room c in WHA). The archive dates the 8th and 7th centuries BC and mostly contain loan documents and receipts recording payments.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 28
    The famous gold flash of lightning of Adad was found in the northern room of a small house in Assur (in eB5V), built into the recess of the southwest wall of the Anu-Adad temple. In the same room, 7 coiled lead strips with hieroglyphic Luwian texts, dating to Neo-Assyrian times, together with an Old Assyrian inscription on an alabaster slab were found. This archive, probably belonging to a man called Takasla, consists of 6 letters which are mostly concerned with the sending of different objects.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 29
    In the grave chamber and some other areas of House 33 (dB5IV), above the Middle Assyrian palace terrace, researchers found a small archive of 8 clay tablets. The archive contains purchase documents, a document concerning the division of inheritance, a receipt of payment, a list, and a letter of complaint.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 30
    In an unspecified place in cD6I, excavators found an archive of 8 complete clay tablets and 12 fragments. The archive contains purchase documents concerning slaves as well as loan documents concerning silver and barley. The only available dating is postcanonical, and dates to the reign of Sin-šarru-iškun (ca. 626–612 BC).
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 31
    In a chamber of House 5 (dA6II), situated where "Ost Strasse" forks into two lanes, excavators found a small archive of 15 nearly complete and several fragmentary clay tablets. One fragmentary text seems to be a purchase document concerning the acquisition of a woman.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 32
    In House 9, in a room to the back of the main room of the house (in dA6IV), excavators found an archive of 14 clay tablets, three of them written in Aramaic. The house is situated next to another house containing an archive (Assur Archive 33). The available datings range from 675 BC to the years shortly before the fall of the city of Assur. All legible texts, belonging to an individual named Kakkullanu and others, are concerned with silver. Among these documents are loan documents and two texts, one of them in Aramaic, that list quantities of silver in connection with various persons, probably for internal administration.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Assur Archive 33
    In House 12, in the western corner of a room with graves (in dD6IV), excavators found an archive of at least 17 clay tablets, two of which were Aramaic dockets. Other clay objects, mostly of which are probably spindle whorls, were found there as well. The house is situated next to another house containing an archive (Assur Archive 32). The dates on of the texts range from 659 BC to the years shortly before the fall of the city of Assur. The best attested central person is an individual called Nagahi, an Aramaic name. The archive consists of at least 6 loan documents, two receipts of payments, three purchase documents, a juridical settlement and other texts.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 34
    4 clay tablets were found in dA6IV in a private house. These tablets were found near House 12 (Assur Archive 33) and House 9 (Assur Archive 32). The archive dates to the 7th century BC. The group consists of 2 loan documents concerning silver, a list of oxen and textiles, and a purchase document concerning a slave.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 35
    Scattered around House 15 and the adjacent House 15a in eE6IV, excavators found an archive of more than 40 clay tablets. The available datings range from 687 BC to the years shortly before the fall of the city of Assur. The archive, belonging to Šarru-iqbi and others, consists of documents dealing with loans, a purchase document, a document concerning the adoption of a girl, and a fragmentary list.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 36
    In House 20, connected to "Westgasse" by a small alley-way, excavators found apotropaic clay figurines and plaques under the floor. Near a terracotta sarcophagus in cE6III, an archive of 14 clay tablets was found as well, either having been deposited there or having secondarily fallen down into it. Another clay tablet was found in cE6IV, with an additional tablet with similarities possibly also belonging to this group. The available datings are from the second half of the 7th century BC. The archive, belonging to Mutaqqin-Aššur, a doorkeeper, as well as others with the same title, consists mainly of loan documents, and also contains a purchase document and a juridical settlement.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 37
    In an unspecified area with private houses in c6, excavators found a small archive of 5 clay tablets. The available datings are from the 7th century BC. The archive, belonging to Nanunu, consists of loan documents and a purchase agreement.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 38
    In the street from the Tabira gate into the city (bE7I), excavators found a stone with inscription and small archive of 11 clay tablets in a secondary context. The archive may have belonged to a nearby house. Two tablets are dated to 686 B.C, and another is dated to 675 BC. The archive contains documents such as loans, a purchase document, a document concerning the dissolution of a marriage, as well as an adoption document.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 39
    In a room northeast of the courtyard of a private house (in bE8I), excavators found an archive of 29 clay tablets. Two more texts may also belong here. Most of the texts date to the 7th century BC. The archive concerns individuals named Nabu-šar-ahhešu, Sagib-Aššur, and others. It includes both purchase documents and loans.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 40
    Just inside the inner town wall in bD8II, excavators discovered a grave chamber. Inside this grave chamber, with its partly destroyed roof, were 87 fragmentary clay tablets that fell down when the private house above was destroyed. Tablets from this archive date to the 8th and 7th centuries BC. Several of the texts are purchase documents, mostly of people.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 41
    In the ruins of a private house outside the inner town wall in cC9I, excavators discovered a small archive consisting of 3 clay tablets and fragments as well as one clay envelope, dating to the mid-7th century BC. These texts are loan documents, as well as one list, which is a harvest report.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 42
    In a house in cD9II, built against the outside of the then-ruined inner town wall, excavators discovered an archive of 22 clay tablets and envelopes, 3 of them written in Aramaic. The texts date to the 7th century BCE. The archive, belonging Aššur-šallim-aḫḫe and others, consisted of loan documents, and other material, such as a juridical document, a letter, and a lump of clay with a seal impression.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 43
    In a house in dA9III, next to the outer surface of the ruined inner town wall, excavators discovered a room with a sarcophagus, two graves and a grave with sherds. In this room, they found an archive of about 38 clay tablets above the sarcophagus, one clay tablet in the grave with sherds and 3 fragmentary tablets in another sarcophagus just outside the ruined town wall. Whether the last group belongs to the same house is unclear. The archive, dating from 698 to the final years of the Assyrian Empire, probably belonged to a man called Nabu-šuma-iddina, although other men are attested as well. Texts include purchase documents concerning houses, slaves and fields, loan documents and juridical settlements, as well as some other types of documents, as well as a fragmentary tablet with the second half of a bilingual literary composition called Examination Text A.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 44
    In dD9IV, in the area of the ruined inner town wall where presumably private houses were located, excavators discovered a clay pot with around 12 clay tablets. Also in dD9IV, another clay pot with pieces of silver was found; a possible connection between these finds cannot be proven. The preserved datings are from the 7th century BCE. The archive, belonging to a man called Samidu with other men attested as well, appears to consist exclusively of purchase documents.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 45
    In a private house in dE9V above the ruined gate to the inner town wall, probably House 1 or just nearby, excavators discovered an archive of some 15 clay tablets. The majority of datings are from 707 to 681 BC, except for one dating: postcanonical 639* BC. The archive includes multiple documents concerning loans, as well as a letter and a purchase document.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 46
    In a private house, between the southwest to northeast road and the Nabu temple, excavators discovered an archive of 43 clay tablets (eA7II). 44 clay tablets, which according to their content also belong to this archive, were found about 350 meters to the southeast in gE9I. Some additional tablets also belong to this archive. Finds from the house include a scarab and a bronze object decorated with a man in Egyptian style. This, considering the number of Egyptian names attested in the archive, suggest that the archive belongs to a group of partly assimilated Egyptians. Available datings are from the 7th century BC. The archive includes at least 22 loan documents usually concerning silver, purchase documents concerning people and houses, marriage documents and a division of inheritance.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 47
    In a private house in fC8I, excavators discovered a small archive of 7 clay tablets. Available datings range from 762 to postcanonical 622* BC. The archive, belonging to a family of tanners, consists of purchase documents, a juridical settlement, and two documents concerning inheritance.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 48
    In a private house in fD8I, excavators discovered an archive of 45 clay tablets and 37 fragments of clay tablets, some of which have since been joined together. Two more clay tablets were located nearby in the same level. The tablets date to the 7th century. The archive, belonging to Nabu-zera-iddina and other goldsmiths, consists of letters, loans, purchase documents, lists of personal names, textiles and amounts of silver, as well as notes and four ‘Median’ texts, among others.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Assur Archive 49
    In the area of private houses in gB9I, excavators discovered a small archive of 3 clay tablets and an envelope. The archive, dating between 655 and postcanonical 641* BC, consists of loan documents concerning silver and barley.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 50
    In a private house in gD10I, excavators discovered a small archive 4 fragmentary clay tablets. The archive, dating to the 7th century BC, consists of juridicial settlements and a loan document.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 51
    At the eastern corner of the large ziggurat in Assur, a library, belonging to a family of scribes, was unearthed in a house in area hB4V (Assur Archive 18). In a door opening of a small house nearby, excavators found a clay pot with 13 tablets inside. This separate archive belongs to Aššur-bissu-epuš and other men. It also dates to the 7th-century BCE. and contains various types of documents, including a juridical settlement and a document concerning the deposit of a chair.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 52a
    In a fill from various rooms of a private house (in area eA8V), excavators discovered an archive of 75 texts, belonging to Duri-Aššur and his business partners. The archive consists of letters, purchase and loan documents, divisions of inheritance, and other legal documents, as well as administrative lists. Most of these texts are concerned with trade. The available datings suggest that Duri-Aššur and his business partners were active in the trade north of Assur from 651 to the destruction of the city in 614 BC. Notably, some documents exemplify the financial independency of Egyptian women in Assur.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 52b
    In a fill from private house in Room 1A2 (in area eA8V), excavators discovered an archive of 15 texts, belonging to a group of Egyptians. Some of these people have Egyptian names, others have Assyrian names. Available datings belong to a period of some 30 years in the mid-7th century BC. The archive consists of legal documents.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assur Archive 53
    In a private house, south of the Parthian Palace, near the western wall of the New City of Assur, excavators discovered an archive of 52 clay tablets. Of the 34 published tablets, most date to the postcanonical period. The only two exceptions date to 679 and 666 BC. and two tablets are undated. The archive, belonging to Aššur-matu-taqqin, contains purchase documents, loan documents, juridicial settlements, a letter, an adoption document, and others.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Assyrian rock relief at Yağmur
    Inscribed relief, dated to the reign of Tiglath-Pileser I, on a large block near the fortified site of Yağmur in the Tur 'Abdin.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Augusteum, Antioch in Pisidia
    The Augusteum, or Sebasteion, at Antioch in Pisidia was a monumental architectural complex dedicated to the Roman Imperial cult. Its archaeological remains were first excavated in 1913.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aydıncık Theater or Odeon
    Remains of a small theater or odeon at ancient Kelenderis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Noah Kaye; Tom Elliott
  • Ayn Braq Aqueduct
    An aqueduct that supplied Petra with water drawn from the Ayn Braq spring, where a large sanctuary had been built.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Bab el-Gasous
    The collective tomb known in modern times as "La Cachette de Bab el-Gasous" at Deir el-Bahari in Egypt was discovered in the early twentieth century and its contents (the remains and funerary equipment of 153 members of the Theban elite dating to the end of the 21st dynasty) were distributed to some 90 museums around the world. The tomb extended under the "Court of Hatshepsut" from a concealed entry located north of the east end of the court and now surrounded by a low stone wall.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Bachkovo Monastery
    Monastery in southern Bulgaria founded in 1083 CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Baptistery, Christian House Church, Dura-Europos
    Room in the NW of the Christian House Church, Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Basilica Damasiana
    The basilica and oratory of Damasianus, as well as the martyr tombs of Simplicius, Faustinus, Beatrice, and Ruinianus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Betitius Perpetuus Arzygius, Domus
    A domus included in Regio III, the house of Betitius Perpetuus Arzygius was located on the Quirinal Hill close to the ara incendii Neroniani. Some of its remains have been documented beneath the present Palazzo delle Esposizioni.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bramiana
    Small settlement in southeastern Crete dated to the Middle-Late Minoan period.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Braq
    Khirbet Braq is the modern name of a ruined Nabatean sanctuary at Ayn Braq in Jordan, a spring that, in antiquity, was channeled through an aqueduct to supply ancient Petra. The heavily looted site is located just south of modern Wadi Musa, on the west side of the modern road to Taybeh.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Canaanite Gate
    The Tel-Dan Canaanite Gate is built of mudbrick and likely dates to the eighteenth century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Canneto sul Trigno
    The remains of a Roman "Villa rustica" located adjacent to the Sanctuary of the Madonna di Canneto.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casal Bernocchi-Malafede
    An archaeological area along the Via Ostiensis with evidence of human activity stretching from the Archaic period to the time of the Roman Empire. SIgnificant archaeological features include an extensive necropolis and a Roman bathing facility.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casa Matta at Kaulonia
    The so-called "Casa Matta" at Kaulonia is an elite domestic building of the Hellenistic period that includes mosaics in the remains of its bathing rooms.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casas del Turuñuelo
    An archaeological site located in Spain's Extremadura region, Casas del Turuñuelo is associated with the Tartessian culture and dates from the fifth century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Castello di Vicalvi
    The ruined castle of Vicalvi is an eleventh-century fortification that remained in use until the sixteenth century. The Medieval fortifications re-use elements of ancient, pre-Roman polygonal masonry architecture that is presumed to date to the fifth or fourth centuries BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castel San Pietro Romano, polygonal walls
    Polygonal masonry walls at Castel San Pietro Romano are likely remnants of an ancient defensive circuit, possibly dating to the later first millennium BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Castillo de Cote
    The Castillo de Cote was built toward the end of the 13th century on the orders of Alfonso X.
    Creators: María Jesús Redondo
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Cavalupo Necropolis (Vulci)
    Excavated in the nineteenth century and only recently re-assessed, this cemetery is located east of Vulci itself, across the modern river Fiora from the ancient acropolis. The cemetery was in active use from the Villanovan period through Hellenistic times.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Chanār-i Pāyn
    Bronze Age site, low mound in Lorestan where cuneiform brick inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Chirik-Rabat
    City in southern Kazakhstan inhabited from the 14th century BCE-14th century CE. Chirik-Rabat was an important trade center on the Silk Road.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Chiyāpuykah
    Bronze Age site, low mound in Lorestan where cuneiform brick inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Church of Saint Sophia
    The Church of Saint Sophia, also referred to as the Old Bishopric, is an Eastern Orthodox church located in Nesebar, eastern Bulgaria. The church originally dates to the sixth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Citadel of Arwad
    The Citadel of Arwad in its present form date originally from the thirteenth century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Complesso episcopale
    The Late Antique to early Medieval "Episcopal" complex of the Santissima Trinità located at Venosa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Costedt Roman Cemetery
    A Roman cemetery was excavated in the late 20th century at modern Costedt in North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Costia dei Lippi
    The archaeological area of Costia dei Lippi is located near the contemporary cemetery of Vetulonia. Excavations in this area began in the 1960s and revealed a series of stone walls built in a squared technique, as well as a system of terraces and a paved road. The area has been interpreted as a domestic quarter dating ca. the third to the first century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cyclopean Bridge of Agios Ioannis
    The Cyclopean Bridge of Agios Ioannis is located one kilometer south of the citadel of Mycenae.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dam-i Malik Khan
    An unexcavated fortress of likely Parthian date, located north of Qala-i Fath on the right bank of the Helmand River in modern Afghanistan.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Dam/Khaima Barang
    An unexcavated Bronze Age site located in the modern Chahar Burjak District of Afghanistan's Nimruz province.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Devia (San Nicandro Garganico)
    A casale first attested in 1032, Devia is located on Monte Devio (also referred to as Monte d'Elio). This mountain is situated between the coastal lakes of Lesina and Varano, in the northern Gargano.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dibbin
    A settlement mound where a cuneiform brick inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Domus Romana "delle Entrate"
    The remains of a Roman townhouse (domus) at Castra Albana.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dur-Katlimmu Archive 2
    In the northeastern corner of Dur-Katlimmu stood a large building complex (Building F and W). While it has been described as a "palace", it was not a royal palace, as no royal inscriptions were found there. In Room B of Building F, an archive was discovered. It consists of 19 Aramaic dockets, previously attached to perishable material, one Aramaic tablet, five Neo-Assyrian tablets and an envelope, as well as a Neo-Babylonian letter in its envelope. More texts were found in nearby rooms, including another Neo-Babylonian tablet. The texts date between 676 BC and the end period of the empire.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Dur-Katlimmu Archive 3
    In several rooms of the Red House, located in the central part of the lower town of Dur-Katlimmu, an archive of ca. 150 clay tablets inscribed in Assyrian cuneiform and ca. 50 tablets inscribed in Aramaic alphabetic script, along with many more small fragments, was discovered. The texts found at in the Red House date between 828 and 600 BC, after the fall of the Assyrian Empire. Many of the texts can be connected with a man named Šulmu-šarri, a contemporary of king Ashurbanipal (r. 668-ca. 631 BC). The texts pertaining to him were found in multiple rooms of the house (Rooms YV, CW, IW and XW), although texts were also found in other rooms. Several of the people who appear in the tablets found at the Red House bear military titles: a garrison was located at Dur-Katlimmu The four latest texts, Neo-Babylonian tablets dating from 603 to 600 BC, were found in Room XX. The texts include purchase documents, loans and juridicial documents.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Evriokastro (Paros)
    A small islet located northeast of Paros, Greece, with the remains of a Byzantine fort (ca. seventh century CE).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Flavia marci
    An unlocated place in ancient Numidia, Flavia marci was situated some 47 Roman miles from Theveste along the road leading to Cirta.
    Creators: Richard Talbert
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Galaxia
    A place recorded on the Tabula Peutingeriana that is to be located between Equizeto? and Auzia. Talbert notes that Galaxia is attested as a name on the manuscript, but has no symbol.
    Creators: Richard Talbert
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Gate of Athena Archegetis
    The Gate of Athena Archegetis is the Doric-order gateway at the west of the Roman Agora in Athens. It was dedicated to Athena Archigetis in 11/10 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Geguti Palace Complex
    Royal residence in Georgia initially constructed in the 8th-9th centuries CE, and expanded several times through the 14th century.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Gird-i Gulak
    High mound on edge of Lake Dukan, threatened by submersion.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Gird-i Rostam
    Tall multiperiod settlement mound in Kurdistan Iraq.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Great Temple of Hera
    The Great Temple of Hera, or Polycrates Temple, is the third temple constructed at the Heraion of Samos between 540 and 530 BCE.
    Creators: Anna Wilson; Casandrah Catterton
    Contributors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Landvatter
  • Grotte dell'Acqua
    Architectural remains near Lago Fusaro that may have been associated with a so-called "villa maritima".
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Güganis
    Abandoned village where a cylindrical stone with Urartian inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Habil Abu Ibrahim
    Unlocated find place in southern Iraq that is recorded for an artifact with cuneiform inscription in the collection of the British Museum.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ḥammām
    Graves near the village Ḥammām (now inundated), find place for inscribed cylinder seal.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Harput
    Original location (known as ruins of Kyzil-Kala) for a fragment of a Urartian stele, later transferred to Bağin.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Hasancıklı
    Find place for an inscribed bronze spear head.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Hasbey
    Village from which a Urartian inscribed temple block is said to originate.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Hazine Piri Kapısı
    Place for Urartian rock inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • House of the Chaste Lovers
    The so-called House of the Chaste Lovers at Pompeii is located on the north side of the Via dell'Abbondanza. The site has been the subject of ongoing archaeological excavation since 1987. It is located in insula 12 of Regio IX. It adjoins the so-called House of the Painters at Work which lies to the north.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • House of the Painters at Work
    The House of the Painters at Work or Casa dei pittori al lavoro is a ruined domus at Pompeii that was undergoing renovations and repairs at the time of the city's final destruction.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ḥūr Sulaymān
    A Bronze Age site, comprised of a low settlement mound, in Lorestan where a cuneiform brick inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Idu
    Idu or Idum, Iron age town by Lower Zab.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Ishān Abū Kumbārah
    Archaeological site and find place for inscribed cylinder seal.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Ishān al-Khāzna
    Group of mounds where cuneiform inscriptions have been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Ishān Dhahak
    Find place for inscribed bricks.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Ishān Hāfudh
    Small mound where a stamped brick is said to have been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Ishān Khālifa
    Group of mounds where cuneiform inscriptions have been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Ishān Miziyād
    Large mound north of Kish, Akkadian settlement and find place for cuneiform inscriptions.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Jabal ‘Ārūdah
    Uruk period settlement located on the bank of the Euphrates river.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Jawānqal‘h
    Site for Urartian rock inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kabrīt
    The findspot of a Persian stele commemorating the construction of a canal near modern Suez.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Kadembas/Katepants
    Kadembas (Katepants) is a modern settlement in the Van Province in the Southeast of Turkey. Here several rock inscriptions of the Urartian king Minua (9th / 8th century BCE) were found which report the construction of the “Canal of Minua” which is still in use today. Furthermore a rock inscription of Tariria, wife of Minua, (9th / 8th century BCE) is located here which attributes a vineyard to her belongings.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • Kaisaran Rock Relief
    Kaisaran (Kaissaran, Kayseran Ekece) is a modern mountain village in the mountains east of the Keşiş Gölü ("Priest Lake"), an artificial lake created by Rusa, son of Erimena (probably 8th century BCE). At an elevation of 2,780 m above the village (more than an hour’s difficult ascent) a rock inscription of probably the same ruler was found in the late 19th century. Another rock inscription and a stela of Rusa, son of Erimena have been found in other places in the vicinity of the lake. These are the rock inscriptions situated in Erek Dağ (CTU I A 14-3) and the so-called Keşiş Göl stela (CTU I A 14-1) whose upper part has been found at Gövelek.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • Kalīshīn
    Find place for stele with Urartian/Akkadian inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kāmfīrūz
    Find place for texts in Linear Elamite.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kamışvan
    The findspot of a stele fragment with an Urartian inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Kānī Bī
    Village from which a cuneiform inscription is said to have been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kanī Jūnī
    Bronze Age site, low mound in Lorestan where cuneiform brick inscription has been found, Kanī Jūnī (I).
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kanī Jūnī
    Bronze Age site, low mound in Lorestan where cuneiform brick inscription has been found, Kanī Jūnī (II).
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kānī Shāyah
    Small site in Kurdistan Iraq consisting of a high and low mound with remains from fourth and early third millenium BCE.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Karacaören
    Find place for inscribed metal hay forks.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Karahan
    The findspot for a group of Urartian stelae.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Karakala
    Place for Urartian rock inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kar-Assurnazirpal
    Town founded by Assurnazipal II, mound (Tall Masaikh) in the Lower Middle Euphrates valley, find place for cuneiform inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kar-Mullissi
    Assyrian city.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kasımoğlu
    Kasımoğlu (Ghusnents) is a modern settlement situated 30 km north of Van in the southeast of Turkey. Here a stela with a military account of the Urartian kings Išpuini and Minua (9th / 8th century BCE) was found (CTU A 3-5).
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Seidler
  • Kasımoğlu
    The findspot for an Urartian stele fragment.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Kavousi Vronda
    At Kavousi Vronda in Eastern Crete (also Vronda or Βροντάς or Βρόντας) is an archaeological site located approximately 1.25 km south of the modern village of Kavousi, in the municipality of Ierapetra, prefecture of Lasithi. The site was in use from the Final Neolithic period (later fourth millennium BCE) onwards.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Kawala Kandal
    Assyrian site near a pass in the Chiya-î Qerechugh hill.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kazane Höyük
    Mound with remains of fortification, close to modern city Şanlıurfa.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Keçikıran
    Find place for Urartian stele.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Keşiş Gölü
    Keşiş Gölü (“Priest Lake”), which known today as Turna Gölü, is an artificially-created lake located 23 km east of Van, in the Varak Dağı massif. The lake was made by the Urartian king Rusa, son of Erimena, to ensure a constant water supply water supply of the capital Tušpa. Four Urartian inscriptions, including a rock relief, were discovered in its vicinity. The upper part of a stele, the so-called Keşiş Göl stele (CTU I A 14-1), records the creation of Rusai Sue (“Lake Rusa”).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Kevenli
    A village in the modern Van Province in southeast Turkey. It is a find place for Urartian inscriptions, and may possibly be identifiable as ancient Arṣuniuni.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Birgit Christiansen; Tom Elliott
  • Khane Gauhar
    Remains of a Buddhist shrine of uncertain date located near modern Darwishan in the Nawa-i-Barakzayi district of Afghanistan's Helmand province.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Khān Ḥaswā
    The findspot of a cylinder with an Old Babylonian funerary inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khirbet Kusiya
    Find place for cuneiform tablet.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Khwaja Ali Sehyaka/Sehyak
    This "Mesopotamian-style temple" site located near modern Dishu in Afghanistan's Helmand province was excavated in the 1970s. Carbon-14 dates and "Greek-style architectural fragments and fine red pottery" led the excavators to date the use of the site from the late Hellenistic and Parthian period to "the beginning of the Sasanian period in the 3rd century" CE. Finds included a fragmentary bilingual (Greek/Aramaic) inscription possibly mentioning a Parthian king Phraates and the Iranian deity Ahuramazda.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Kimūnah
    Site with Bronze age palace, periodically submerged in the Tigris river.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Koçaklar
    Find place for a stele fragment with Urartian inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Koçyatağı
    Place for Urartian rock inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Konār Sandal
    Konār Sandal is a Bronze Age archaeological site associated with the "Jiroft culture" (third millennium BCE). The site is located in the valley of the Halil River just south of Jiroft, Kermān Province, Iran. There are, in fact, two tells situated a few kilometers apart. By convention, these mounds are referred to as Konar Sandal A and B.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Köşk
    Find place for stone objects with Urartian inscriptions.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kotanlı
    A findspot for a stele fragment with an Urartian inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Kūbrī
    Find place for Persian multilingual stela.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kuhanak
    The findspot for a fragmentary cuneiform inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Kūlfaraḥ
    Place for Neo-elamite rock inscriptions.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kumidi
    Bronze age settlement.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kūnārā
    Bronze age site with upper and lower town and remains of monumental building.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kupinovik Roman Villa
    A Roman villa site on the modern Croatian island of Hvar (ancient Pharus)
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Kuşsaray
    A Bronze Age archaeological site consisting of a mound with finds of cuneiform tablets. The site was only briefly excavated.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Lacene
    Lacene was a place in North Africa. It is included on the Peutinger map where it is presented as a name without a symbol. Based on the routes on the Peutinger map, Lacene was located between Ad Palmam and Praesidium Silvani.
    Creators: Richard Talbert
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • La Marmotta
    An Early Neolithic settlement that is now submerged beneath the waters of Lake Bracciano. Settlement activity begins ca. 5750 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lchashen
    Urartian rock inscription near the town Lchashen.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Le Vistre de la Fontaine
    A tributary of the Vistre that originates from a spring in central Nîmes (ancient Nemausus), near the so-called Temple of Diana.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • library at Nysa on the Maeander
    A second-century CE library located at Nysa on the Maeander.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lori Berd fortress
    Fortified structure near the modern village of Lori Berd (Armenia) constructed in 1065 CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Lori Berd necropolis
    Burial site in Armenia containing tombs dated to the Late Bronze-Early Iron Ages (22nd-5th centuries BCE).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Lydney Roman temple
    A fourth century AD temple dedicated to Nodens.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Māhān
    Tomb of Shah Nematollah Vali, find place for cuneiform inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Maḥmūd Ābād
    Mound and find place for a stone block with Urartian inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Malabadi Bridge
    The Malabadi Bridge spans the Batman River in southeastern Turkey. Construction began ca. 1146/47 CE and continued until 1154.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Malazgirt
    Find place for Urartian stone inscriptions.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Maleme
    A Mycenaean tholos tomb located to the north of Margarites, Rethymno, Crete.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Tom Elliott
  • Marmachyn
    Place for Urartian rock inscription, 1km from Marmashen Monastery.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Maroneia Cave
    A cave located on mount Ismaros near the ancient settlement of Maroneia in Aegean Thrace. The cave was in human use from the late Neolithic period until the abandonment of the fortified settlement in the 13th century CE. The cave is known locally as "The Cave of Polyphemos" or "The Cave of the Cyclops".
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Mater Deum, Aedes
    A place included in the Regionary Catalogues for Regio XI, the Aedes Mater Deum is otherwise obscure. According to Richardson, the toponym may refer to the statue of Magna Mater on the spina of the Circus Maximus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mattonara necropolis
    The Etruscan necropolis of La Mattonara near Civitavecchia, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mawānā
    Find place for Urartian stele.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Meher Kapısı
    Urartian inscribed rock niche.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Mergeh Karvan
    The findspot of an Urartian stele dating to the eighth century BCE that mentions Rusa, son of Sarduri.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Meta Romuli
    The so-called "Meta Romuli" was a pyramidal tomb located in the Ager Vaticanus at Rome. It likely dated to the first century BCE or the first century CE. Its extant superstructed was demolished in 1499. Remains of foundations and pavements that have been associated with the tomb were encountered in 1948-1949 during construction work in the first block of the north side of the present-day Via della Conciliazione.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Methone (Macedonian)
    Settlement in Pieria, Greece, constructed following the destruction of the town of Methone in 354 BCE and inhabited during the Hellenistic and Roman periods.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Meturant
    Hamrin basin site named Tall al-Sīb.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Mezraa Teleilat
    A low mound on the east bank of the Euphrates, close to the border between Syria and Turkey. Salvage excavations were undertaken here around the year 2000. The site has yielded cuneiform finds.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Military compound in the Temple of Artemis Azzanathkona
    Complex of rooms requisitioned for military record keeping and administration, formerly belonging to the Temple of Artemis Azzanathkona.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Mithraeum of Felicissimus
    The so-called Mithraeum of Felicissimus is a Mithraic shrine located in ancient Ostia. The shrine itself was installed in a second-century CE building and likely dates to the later third-century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mithraeum of the Seven Gates
    The so-called Mithraeum of the Seven Gates was built at Ostia in the second century CE, repurposing rooms that originally date to the previous century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mithraeum of the Seven Spheres
    The so-called Mithraeum of the Seven Spheres is located in ancient Ostia near to the theater-cum-quadriporticus complex. The so-called Quattro tempietti screen it from the Decumanus Maximus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mogao Caves
    Buddhist cave monastery complex in the cliffs above the Dachuan River near the Dunhaung Oasis, constructed in 366 CE and in use until the 14th Century CE. The caves contain thousands of murals and painted sculptures, and thousands of manuscripts in Chinese, Tibetan, Uyghur, Sogdian, Sanskrit, and Khotanese were stored in the so-called "Library Cave." The Mogao Caves were added to UNESCO's World Heritage List in 1987.
    Creators: Yifei Wu
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Mova
    Mova is a place in North Africa included in the Tabula Peutingeriana. It was located 15 miles northwest of Theveste.
    Creators: Richard Talbert
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Muhrapert
    Find place for Urartian inscribed stone.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Mukdan
    Mound (Umm al-Jīr) and find place for Akkadian cuneiform tablets.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Muradiye
    Find place for Urartian inscriptions.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Muş
    Find place for a Urartian stele fragement.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Nalbandyan
    Find place for a cylindrical stone for Urartian inscription. The village was previously known as Šahriar.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Namrīk
    Site excavated in conjunction with the Mosul Dam project, currently submerged.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Nashteban
    Place for Urartian rock inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Necropoli del Castellaccio
    A necropolis at Falerii Veteres.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Necropoli del Poggino
    The necropolis of Poggino is an Etruscan necropolis located near Fonterutoli, in the municipality of Castellina in Chianti, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Necropoli di Celle
    Extensive areas of rock-cut tombs in the vicinity of Falerii Veteres (modern Civita Castellana in Italy)
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Necropoli di Montarano
    A necropolis located to the north of ancient Falerii Veteres containing more than 67 tombs.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Necropolis and Mortuary Complex of Pepi I
    Located in south Saqqara, this monument and associated necropolis date to the Sixth Dynasty of ancient Egypt (Dynasty VI).
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Nisaki
    The remains of Classical to Hellenistic fortifications on the islet Nisaki Agion Anargyron.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Noheda Roman villa
    A Roman villa richly appointed with polychrome mosaics located 18 kilometers north of the city of Cuenca, near Noheda (Villar de Domingo García).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Noragavid
    Find place for a stone fragment with Urartian inscription, suburb of Yerevan.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Northern sanctuary at Kythnos
    Religious structure in Kythnos constructed in the Archaic period.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Novyy Kumak
    Burial ground close to the modern city Orsk, possibly covered by modern construction.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Odeon at Kibyra
    The building referred to as the odeon at Kibyra was used for multiple purposes, including as a bouleuterion.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Ojasar-Ilandağ
    Place for Urartian rock inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Old Forum at Lepcis Magna
    The original Roman forum at Lepcis Magna, in use prior to the construction of the Severan Forum in the early 3rd century CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ortadamla
    Urartian rock inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ortakent
    Place for Urartian rock inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Ozbaki
    Chalcolithic site, find place for cuneiform inscriptions.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Palace at Amathous
    A large-scale building, tentatively identified as a palace, constructed during the 9th century BCE and in use until about 500 CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Palazzo Imperiale (Ostia)
    The so-called Palazzo Imperiale at Ostia is located at the western margin of Regio I. This building complex was initially excavated between 1855 and 1871 and many of its finds, especially mosaics, were transported to the Vatican Museum. The complex dates to the second and third centuries CE and includes a variety of installations - shops, storehouses, bathing facilities - but is most likely not a palace despite its modern sobriquet.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Palu
    Fortress with Urartian inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Paraebasium
    A tomb built for those who were slain in battle by Cleomenes. Pausanias locates the tomb along the road leading from Gortys to Megalopolis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Parthian House 139
    Remains of a house whose earliest components date (C14) to the Parthian era, located south of the large site of Shahr-i Gholghola in the modern Chahar Burjak region of Afghanistan's Nimruz province.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Philippeion
    The Philippeion is a tholos at Olympia constructed to celebrate Philip II's victory at Chaeonea in 338 BCE and completed by Alexander the Great.
    Creators: Eli Franz; Marco Tonda
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Pilsdon Pen
    Pilsdon Pen (277 m above sea level) is a Cretaceous outcrop located in Dorset, South West England. It is the site of a multivallate Durotrigian hillfort dating to the Iron Age. Peter Gelling and Margaret Gelling of the University of Birmingham conducted excavations at the site in the 1960s.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pirabat
    The findspot for Urartian inscribed stone blocks.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pir Hüseyin
    Large mound east of Pir Hüseyin, find place for cuneiform inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Piscina romana (Acqui Terme)
    A Roman water feature at Acqui Terme dating to the Imperial period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Plataean Tumulus (Marathon)
    A tumulus at Marathon associated with the Boeotian Plataeans. Marinatos identified the mound in 1970. It rises to a height of about 3 meters.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Platia Magoula Zarkou
    Tell site in western Thessaly containing the remains of a settlement and necropolis dated to the early 6th millennium BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Puente del Chantre
    A Medieval bridge spanning the Jucar stream.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pyrgos-Mavroraki
    Settlement and industrial site in southern Cyprus dated to the Early and Middle Bronze Ages.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Qarah Jatān
    Find place for an inscribed stone slab ("Haldiny Inscription" of Iddin-Sin).
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Qaryat ad Dawā’irah, Libya
    A possible fortified farm site.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Qaṣr-i Abūnaṣr
    Small mound with Achaemenian remains.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Quattro tempietti
    The sanctuary along the Decumanus Maximus of Ostia known as the "Quattro tempietti" dates from the Republican period. Based on multiple phases of restoration, they continued in use until at least the second century CE. Epigraphic evidence leads some scholars to conclude that the four temples were sacred to Venus, Fortuna, Ceres, and Spes and had been dedicated by one Publius Lucilius Gamala.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • regio Pedana
    The territory of the city of Pedum, referred to as both "regio Pedana" and "ager Pedanus" was known to Cicero and Horace but all traces had vanished by the time of Pliny the Elder.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Rhodopolis Ancient Theater
    The ancient theater at Rhodopolis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Rocca dei Colonna
    A Medieval fortification of the Colonna family located in the Italian municipality of Castel San Pietro Romano, the Rocca dei Colonna was in use from the thirteenth century until ca. 1800.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman amphitheater of Thyna
    A Roman amphitheater located at Thaenea, a Roman station in the province of Africa Proconsularis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman Bridge: Le Vistre de la Fontaine Palaeochannel
    Remains of a Roman bridge spanning a former channel of Le Vistre de la Fontaine south of Nîmes have been excavated. Work at the site also provided significant evidence for Roman-era waste and lead contamination transported down the river from the urban center of Nemausus.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Roman city wall at Telese Vetere
    Remains of the fortification wall of the Samnite center of Telese Vetere.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater (Haidra)
    The remains of a Roman theater located at Haidra, Tunisia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman theater of Guelma
    The Roman theater of ancient Calama (now Guelma) was built in the early third century CE and substantially restored in the twentieth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman theater of Mandeure
    The Roman theater of Mandeure dates to the first century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman villa on viale Alfredo Ottaviani
    The ruins of a Roman villa were discovered along viale Alfredo Ottaviani at Acilia Nord in 2011.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Room W13, Military compound in the Temple of Artemis Azzanathkona
    Room requisitioned for military record keeping and administration, formerly belonging to the Temple of Artemis Azzanathkona in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Sabratha Roman Theater
    A large Roman theater, likely built sometime in the third century CE.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Saliagos
    An islet of the Cyclades with evidence of a Neolithic agricultural community dated ca. 5000-4500 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Samara Bend
    Area surrounding a sharp bend in the Volga river. The region contains a number of major archaeological sites of the Neolithic Age.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Šamuḫa
    Hittite settlement.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Sanctuary of Artemis at Avlonas
    A sanctuary possibly sacred to Artemis on the island of Lemnos.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Sanctuary of Kybele
    A sanctuary dedicated to Kybele located at Daskalopetra on the island of Chios.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sanctuary of the Bona Dea
    The Sanctuary of the Bona Dea at Ostia dates originally to the republican period (second century CE?) and was renovated in the second century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • San Giuliano Roman bridge
    A Roman bridge crossing the Melfa river in Lazio, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santa Maria delle Vigne
    A Paleochristian church (fifth century CE) located near ancient Lavinium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santuario dei Tre Santi (Alfio, Filadelfio e Cirino)
    A church of ca.1200 AD onwards, containing ancient material from the site of Apollonia in re-use.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Jonathan Prag
    Contributors:
  • Semo Sancus, Aedes
    A sanctuary on the Quirinal Hill in Rome sacred to the cult of Semo Sancus Dius Fidius, a cult of Sabine origin said to have been introduced to Rome by Titus Tatius. The dedication of the temple is generally attributed to Sp. Postumius on 5 June 466 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Settlement north of Buridava Roman fort and Vicus
    A Dacian settlement, probably of indigenous origin, lying a few kilometers north of the Roman fort and vicus known as Buridava. It may have originated the toponym.
    Creators: Johan Åhlfeldt; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Shengavit
    Mound site in modern Yerevan containing the remains of a settlement associated with the Kura-Araxes culture (ca. 2900-2200 BCE).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Shiqāft-i Gulgul
    Assyrian rock cut relief.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Shiveet khaĭrkhany
    Burial site in western Mongolia that dates to between the 8th century BCE and the 3rd century CE. Nine tombs associated with the Pazyryk Culture and 7 tombs associated with the Xianbei Culture have been identified.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Karen Rubinson; Tom Elliott
  • Šibaniba Archive 2
    In the southwestern area of the tell of Šibaniba, an archive of 22 clay tablets, most of which date from 853 to 826 BC, was discovered. The archive consists of administrative documents dealing with matters concerning taxation. Only one of the tablets is a legal text, it documents the lease of a field in 830 BC.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Sīnīya Island
    The largest island in the modern Khawr al-Bayḍā lagoon in the Emirate of Umm al-Quwain. Archaeological surveys conducted between 2012 and 2021 have identified two major and a variety of minor archaeological sites while beginning to establish dates and sequences for human occupation and exploitation of the island.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • So-called Arco di Druso
    The popular toponym associated with this monument - Arco di Druso or Arch of Drusus - is a misnomer and is misleading. This is problematic given other textual, epigraphic, and archaeological attestations that mention honorific monuments dedicated to Nero Claudius Drusus. This place is the site of the remains of a triple-bay arch that is now reduced to the central bay. The monument sits astride the Via Appia just inside the Porta S. Sebastiano and has been referred to as "Arco di Druso" since the sixteenth century. The monument is built of travertine and faced with marble. This arch, in fact, supported the Aqua Antoniniana, a branch of the Aqua Marcia. The connection with Drusus is erroneous.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Stadium at Kibyra
    The Stadium at Kibyra dates to the second and third centuries CE and could seat about 10,000 people.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Stoa at Brauron
    The Stoa at Brauron, within the larger Artemis Brauronia complex, housed dining spaces as well as votive offerings to the goddess Artemis. The Stoa was Π-shaped, wrapping around a courtyard that separated it from the temple of Artemis at Brauron, which it faced. Worship at the cult site began ca. the eighth century BCE. The site was abandoned after a flood in the third century BCE.
    Creators: Basil-Anne Stackpole; Julie Mason
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Sulaiymah
    Large mound by the Diyala River, find place for a large number of cylinder seals.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tall al-Disim
    Mound where cuneiform inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall al-Gharrān
    Find place for cuneiform inscription: high mound with eroded brick walls, north of Babylon.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall al-Hādī

    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall al-Ḥadīdī
    Bronze age site, possibly ancient Azu.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tall al-Qiṭar
    Late Bronze Age fortress-settlement, possibly ancient Til-Abni, find place for cuneiform inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall Fisnah
    Mound of a small rural settlement at the confluence of the river Robal with Tigris in modern Iraq. The site is now submerged by the reservoir created by the Mosul dam.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tall Fray
    Bronze age settlement mound, submerged since 1974 in Lake Assad.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall Gasir
    Group of mounds in the Ram Hormuz Valley.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall Ghaḍaiyrīfah
    Find spot (large mound) for an inscribed door socket.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall Ḥadwat al-Faras
    The findspot for a cuneiform inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker

    Find place for cuneiform tablets.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
