  • Tall Hanas
    Middle Assyrian Settlement.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall Ḥuwaysh
    Find place for cuneiform inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall Ibrāhīm Bayis
    Fortress/military area where bricks with cuneiform inscritpion has been found, close to the village Makhmur.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall Imlīḥiyah
    A settlement mound now submerged in the Hamrin basin; a findspot for cuneiform inscriptions.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tall Jūkha
    Early dynastic settlement.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall Karay Qāsim
    Small mound, periodically submerged in water, where cuneiform inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall Kozkhān
    A settlement mound at which cuneiform brick inscriptions have been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tall Marwāny
    Mound in the Lower Middle Euphrates valley, find place for cuneiform inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall Mīthlay
    Minor mound at which a cuneiform tablet was found in a grave.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall Nūyaja
    Mound and find place for cuneiform inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tall Qabr Abu al-’Atīq
    Mound on the left bank of the Euphrates with Bronze Age settlement.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson
    Contributors: Rune Rattenborg
  • Tapah Farukhābād
    Small town mound in Deh Luran Plain.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tapah Gutwand
    The findspot of an ancient brick with an Elamite inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tapah Khībr
    Large mound and site for Iron Age fortress. Possibly ancient Ḫarḫar.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Teatro romano, Aquino
    The Roman theater of Aquinum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tell Abu Hafur
    Tell Abu Hafur is an archaeological site located in the Khabur River basin of Syria. Salvage excavations in 1988–1990 documented the site, which had two main tells. These mounds and the evidence for human activity there ranged in date from the Early Dynastic period to the Mitanni period to the Neo-Assyrian period, with later Hellenistic, Parthian-Roman, and early Islamic activity.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tell Djassa
    Tell Djassa is an archaeological site in the upper Khabur River basin identified by salvage excavations in 1988-1990. Four main phases of human occupation were identified, all belonging to the third millennium BCE. The site was re-settled in the later first millennium BCE as demonstrated by Hellenistic pottery.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tell el-Samara
    Located adjacent to the modern village of el-Samara (Dakahlia governorate, Egypt) and partly covered by its cemetery, this tell provides archaeological evidence for one of the earliest settlements identified in the Nile delta. Excavations have demonstrated that the settlement was founded in the 5th millennium BCE and subsequent habitation of the site continued to the beginning of the third millennium BCE.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Tell F6 at Failaka
    Tell on the southwestern corner of Failaka Island containing the remains of two large buildings, tentatively identified as a palace and a temple, dated to 1900-1400 BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Artemis Azzanathkona Phase 1 (Dura-Europos)
    Archaeological phase (c. 13-160 CE) of the Temple at Dura-Europos dedicated to Artemis Azzanathkona, probably the tutelary deity of the Euphrates island settlement Anath.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Artemis Azzanathkona Phase 2
    Temple at Dura-Europos dedicated to Artemis Azzanathkona, tutelary deity of the Euphrates island settlement Anath; building complex later used for Roman military record keeping in addition to worship.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Athena Makistos
    An Athena temple located to the west of Nea Skilloundia, possibly at ancient Makiston, in the Peloponnese.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Temple of Augustus and Rome (Ankara)
    The Temple of Augustus and Roma at Ankara likely dates ca. 20 BCE. It is also known as the "Monumentum Ancyranum", highlighting the structure's role in preserving the most complete copy of the inscription known as the "Res Gestae Divi Augusti", which was promulgated in both ancient Greek and Latin following the death of emperor Augustus in 14 CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Iuno Sospita, Lanuvium
    A celebrated cult-place sacred to Iuno Sospita that retained its sacred significance even after a cult to the same divinity was dedicated in the Forum Holitorium in Rome in 194 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tepe Horreeye
    Place with archaeological remains where Elamite inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Thasarte
    Now unlocated, Thasarte was a place in Africa Proconsularis that is included on the Peutinger map.
    Creators: Richard Talbert
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Theater at Kibyra
    The Theater at Kibyra dates to the Hellenistic period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Theater of Nero
    The Theater of Nero located in the Vaticanus Ager is relatively little known and receives little attention in the ancient sources. Archaeological discoveries announced in the summer of 2023 seem to point to remains of the theater preserved beneath the courtyard of the Palazzo della Rovere located between the Borgo Santo Spirito and the Via della Conciliazione. The first-century CE theater seems to have been dismantled by the second-century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • theater of Nysa
    The ancient theater of Nysa could accommodate ca. 12,000 spectators.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Théâtre Antique de Vaison-la-Romaine
    The Roman Theater of Vasio Vocontiorum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Theatre of Messene
    The ancient Theater of Messene (Mavrommati, Messenia, Greece).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Tholos tomb at Marathon
    A large Mycenaean tholos tomb at Marathon.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Tomba della Fibula d'oro
    A corridor-type tomb in the territory of Vetulonia dating to the Orientalizing period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Troulli tis Korfis
    A hilltop sanctuary, in use from the Bronze Age until the time of the Roman Empire.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Tsepi at Marathon
    A large Early Helladic cemetery excavated at the Leoforos Plataion near Marathon, Attiki.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Tul-i Ājuri
    Mound where glazed brick has been found, currently overbuilt.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tulul al-Baqarat
    Tulul al-Baqarat is an archaeological site located seven kilometers northeast of Tell al-Wilayah, Iraq. The settlement was occupied from the fourth millennium BCE to the Islamic period. It may have been the Early Dynastic city of Kesh.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tulūl al-Hummar
    Mound where stamped bricks have been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tumulo Etrusco del Molinello (Asciano)
    An Etruscan tumulus-type tomb at Asciano with artifactual evidence dating to the Orientalizing period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tušhan Archive 1
    In the city of Tušhan, modern Ziyaret Tepe in Turkey, excavators discovered an Assyrian archive of 28 clay tablets, most of which were found in Rooms 9 and 10 of the administrative complex in the lower town. Weights, tokens, and sealings were found there as well, suggesting that the building served economic purposes. The majority of texts deal with administrative transactions of barley, as well as other commodities, such as copper, garments, and sheep. The archive seems to date to the final years of the empire. Indeed, one of the texts is a letter in which the writer describes the collapse of the administrative and military infrastructure around him.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Typhrestos/Tymphrestos (mountain)
    A mountain at the western edge of the Spercheios valley on which the river itself rises. In modern times, the mountain has been known both as Timfristos and Velouchi.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Uluşar
    Find place for Urartian inscriptions.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Umm al-Ḥafryāt
    Mound, find place for inscribed brick.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed Roman bridge
    An Unnamed Roman bridge that spans the Rio di Fontechiari.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed Roman bridge
    The remains of a bridge located in Sierra de Fuentes, Spain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Vardzia
    Cave monastery complex in southern Georgia constructed from 1184-1186.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Veresuos
    A settlement in Byzacena that is now unlocated. Based on its inclusion in the Peutinger map, this place is located along the road leading from Capsa to Tacape.
    Creators: Richard Talbert
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • via Pedana
    The via Pedana, known only from epigraphic evidence, led presumably from Rome to Pedum. It was likely a branch of the via Praenestina.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa delle Guardiole
    A Late Republican to early Imperial coastal villa located at the mouth of the Fosso delle Guardiole near Castrum Novum. Two artificial fish ponds are associated with the villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa Romana de los Villaricos
    The site of Villaricos lies 5 km east of Mula (Murcia), Spain. The Roman villa at the site was large and well-appointed, including rich mosaics and a bathing complex. There is also an industrial area that includes a torcularium (facility for pressing of olives or grapes). The site's use ranges from the first to the fifth century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Villa Romana di Punta San Limato
    The ruins of a Roman villa located in the modern Italian locality of Punta San Limato, province of Caserta.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Vrasna fort (Thessaloniki)
    A fortified site located at Trypimeni Petra, between the foothills of Mount Kerdyllion and the coastline at Vrasna, dating to the fourth-first century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Vryokastro
    A Bronze Age settlement located on the south coast of the island of Tinos to the west of Agios Phokas.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Wall0042, Christian house church (Dura-Europos)
    Eastern interior wall from the Baptistery, Christian House Chruch, Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Wall0043, Christian house church (Dura-Europos)

  • Yağmur
    Fortified site atop a limestone terrace in the Tur 'Abdin, constructed during the Iron Age and in use into the Medieval period.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Yalvac Theatre - Antioch Pisidia
    The theater at Pisidian Antioch was perhaps founded in the first century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Yrokastro castle
    A ruined Medieval fortification on the island of Naxos.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Yukarı Anzaf Fortress
    The Yukarı Anzaf Fortress ("Upper Anzaf Fortress") is situated in the Van region in southeast Turkey. It was built by the Urartean King Minua (9th / 8th century BCE) who reports about his building activity in several building inscriptions. The fortress is situated close to Aşağı Anzaf Fortress ("Lower Anzaf Fortress") which had been built by Minua's father Išpuini.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Seidler
  • Zakros villa
    A Minoan "villa" along the road leading south from Zakros, Lasithi, Crete.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Zaraka Monastery
    The ruins of a Frankish monastery between Stymphalia and Kionia, Zaraka, Korinthia, established by monks of the Cistercian Order ca. 1225.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Zawyet el-Maiyitin
    A small pyramid of the late Third Dynasty of ancient Egypt.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:

Modified Place Resources

  • A'ali Mound Cemetery
    A large complex of burial mounds located near the town of A'ali in central Bahrain. The burials date to the early Dilmun era, ca. 2050-1700 BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee

  • Abrotonum/Sabratha
    The westernmost of the "three cities" of Tripolis, Abrotonum/Sabratha was founded ca. 500 B.C. by the Phoenicians. The city was part of the Numidian Kingdom of Massinissa before becoming a Roman city.
    Creators: D.J. Mattingly
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; jfu

    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Acherusia Palus
    Acherusia Palus, now known as Lago del Fusaro or Lake Fusaro, is a lake located in the Italian community of Bacoli. The acropolis of Cumae is about 1.5 km from the lakeshore. The lake itself is separated from the sea by a narrow strip of land. The lake has also been noted since antiquity for the presence of freshwater springs and the quality of its oysters and mussels.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: edited; summary; update references; created location "OSM Location: Lago del Fusaro"; modified name "Acherusia Palus" (update reference); created name "Lake Fusaro"; created name "Lago del Fusaro"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Acquapendente
    The modern Acquapendente was settled in pre-Roman times but is known historically from the Middle Ages onward.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Acrae
    Akrai, an ancient city of Sicily, originated as a colony founded by Syracuse in 664 B.C., making it the first of the city's three colonial foundations.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Jonathan Prag; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Aegaeum Mare
    The Aegean Sea is the largest body of water between Greece and Asia Minor and an embayment of the Mediterranean Sea.

  • Aenaria/Pithekoussai (island)
    Aenaria/Pithekoussai Ins. (modern Ischia) is a volcanic island located in the northern part of the Bay of Naples.

  • Aeoliae (islands)
    A volcanic archipelago in the Tyrrhenian Sea composed of eight islands.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add MANTO 9746287: the Lipari Islands
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Aeolis
    Sometimes defined as covering the entrance of the Hellespont to the mouth of the Hermus River, Aeolis was a region centered on the North West coast of Asia Minor and some islands, notably Lesbos. Herodotus lists the eleven ancient cities of Aeolis as Cyme, Lerisae, Neon Teichos, Temnos, Cilla, Notion, Aegiroessa, Pitane, Aegaeae, Myrina, and Gryneia. He also claims that Smyrna was once an Aeolian city, but was taken by the Ionians at an unspecified date.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; created name "Aeolis"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Aesis (river)
    Aesis fl. (modern Esino river) is a river of the Marche region of Italy and flows into the Adriatic Sea.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created OSM location of Esino (river course)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Aethiopia
    Aethiopia is a term used in the Classical sources to refer both to Upper Egypt and the regions south of the Sahara desert. It is employed as early as the time of Homer.
    Creators: E.W.B. Fentress
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Michael Heubel; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; R. Warner; Richard Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Aetna (mountain)
    An active stratovolcano on the east coast of Sicily (known today as Mount Etna).
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Afas Laminie
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 35 unlocated Afas Laminie
    Creators: D.J. Mattingly
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add TP reference; update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Agade
    Agade was the capital of the Akkadian state, which was the dominant military and political force in southern Mesopotamia ca. 2334-2113 B.C. Agade (also known as Akkad and Akkade) is mentioned in cuneiform texts from the late third millennium B.C. to the Neo-Babylonian period. The exact location is still unknown and debated among scholars, many of whom place it along or east of the Tigris River, between Samarra and Baghdad.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sarah Bond; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: update wikidata; added HiTop reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Agarsel
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 35 unlocated Agarsel
    Creators: D.J. Mattingly
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add TM GEO ID 41761: Agarsel; add TP reference

  • Agedincum
    A settlement located at the Yonne-Vanne confluence in the territory of the Senones.
    Creators: C. Haselgrove; J. Kunow

    Modifications: created connection "Icauna (river)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Ag. Eirene
    Ayia Irini, located on Keos, was occupied from the Late Neolithic until the Mycenaean period. The site was extensively excavated under J.L. Caskey.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Ayia Irini (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Ager Faliscus (region)
    The territory of the Faliscans that lay between areas where Etruscan, Latin, and Sabellic languages were spoken. The geographic limits of this territory on the right bank of the Tiber River stretch from Grotta Porciosa in the north to Capena in the south.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: add fr wikipedia, wikidata references; update
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Agoranis (river)
    Arrian (quoting Megasthenes) lists the Agoranis among a large number of tributaries of the Ganges river. Some modern scholarship (e.g., Tomaschek in RE) has therefore identified it with the modern Gogra (Ghaghara); however, Erdosy in BAtlas silently rejects this view, preferring to identify it as a distributary of the Ganges, the modern Garai (Gorai) in Bangladesh.
    Creators: M.U. Erdosy
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Gorai-Madhumati River (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Agora of Athens
    The marketplace of the ancient city of Athens in Greece.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: add Stewart 2023, update Arachne; added MANTO reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Ag. Paraskevi
    The fort of Aghia Paraskevi is located on the western slopes of Mount Zastani, according to Ober. This ridge of the Makron Oros looks out over the plain of Oropos.
    Creators: J.S. Traill
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: edited; update summary; created Imagery Location of Παρεκκλήσι Αγίας Παρασκευής

  • Aigosthena
    Aigosthena was a fortified city of Attica that belonged to Megara.

    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Ai Khanoum (Alexandria Oxiana?)
    Ai Khanoum, probably to be identified with the attested name "Alexandria Oxiana" (Alexandria on Oxus), was founded in the fourth century BCE in the wake of the campaigns of Alexander the Great. It was a chief city of the Graeco-Bactrian kingdom, but was abandoned around 145 BCE.
    Creators: F.T. Hiebert; P.L. Kohl
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: DARMC 19952; added Martinez-Sève 2015; title; summary; added Nikolaou 2023; created location "OSM Location: Ai Khanoum"; modified connection "Oxus (river)" (located on)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Ain Dara
    Ain Dara, located northwest of Aleppo, Syria, is noted for the remains of an Iron Age Syro-Hittite temple.
    Creators: P.-L. Gatier; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; M. Ballance; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Ain Dara (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)

  • Ainos

  • Aisepos (river)

  • Alalaiou (islands)

  • Alalie/Aleria

    Creators: S.L. Dyson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Alba Docilia
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 39 D5 Alba Docilia
    Creators: M. Pearce; P. Tozzi
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Stefano Costa; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created location "OSM Location: Alba Docilia"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Alba Longa
    Alba Longa, located in the Alban Hills southeast of Rome, was the chief city and founder of the Latin League. Conflict with Rome caused Alba's destruction in the seventh century B.C. The legendary history of Romulus and Remus connects them to the royal lineage of the city. The ancient city is probably to be located at and around the site of modern Castel Gandolfo.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Alcántara
    The Roman temple of Alcántara is a well-preserved structure located at one side of the Alcántara Bridge in Extremadura (Spain). The building, dating to A.D. 103, is the work of Caius Iulius Lacer. The lintel inscription indicates the structure was dedicated to Trajan.
    Creators: F.H. Stanley; Jr.; R.C. Knapp
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Alcántara Roman temple (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Alconis
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 16 B3 Alconis
    Creators: R. Häussler; S. Loseby
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: updated Zotero URI for Barruol 1969
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Alessandria della Rocca
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 47 C3 Alessandria della Rocca
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Aleta
    An ancient settlement, attested by literary or documentary sources, whose precise location cannot be determined today
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; created connection "Sicilia (island)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Aletrium
    A Hernican hill town that formed part of a sixth century B.C. defensive league against Volscian and Samnite aggression and allied itself to Tarquinius Superbus. Rome eventually took Aletrium in 306 B.C.; by the first century B.C. the site was a Roman municipium.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: TGN 7006674: Alatri (inhabited place)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Alexandria
    The ancient port city in Egypt's Nile Delta, founded by Alexander the Great in 332/331 BCE.
    Creators: A. Bernand
    Contributors: Adam Prins; Brady Kiesling; Eric Kansa; Elizabeth Platte; Francis Deblauwe; Iris Fernandez; Jeffrey Becker; Roko Rumora; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; Herbert Verreth; Jen Thum; Mark Depauw; R. Talbert; W. Röllig
    Modifications: added MANTO reference; cleaned up references; added Sforza 2023
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Alexandria ad Issum
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 67 C3 Alexandria ad Issum
    Creators: P.-L. Gatier; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; M. Ballance; R. Talbert; R. Warner; W. Röllig
    Modifications: add TM GEO ID 8866: Alexandreia (Iskenderun); update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Alexandria/Alexandropolis/Cufis
    Now Kandahar in Afghanistan, Alexandria/Alexandropolis/Cufis is an ancient site founded by Alexander the Great ca. 330 BC. The indigenous people of the Hellenistic period were likely the Pakthas.
    Creators: M.U. Erdosy
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Jeffrey Becker; David Mimno; Ryan Horne; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; H. Kopp; R. Talbert; W. Röllig
    Modifications: update references; modified CIGS location of Qandahār (added positional accuracy assessment); created CIGS location of Qandahār; modified name "Qandahar" (change type to = associated modern name); modified name "Qandahār" (change type to = associated modern name); created name "Qandahār"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Alexandria/Antiochia/Merv
    Alexandria/Antiochia/Merv was a major oasis-city of Central Asia, located along the Silk Road (in modern Turkmenistan). Listed as UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1999.
    Creators: F. Hiebert; P.L. Kohl; St J. Simpson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add TP reference; add New Pauly reference; modified name "Merv" (ctype)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Alexandria/Kapisa
    "Alexandria in the Caucasus", an Achaemenid town re-established by Alexander the Great at modern Charikar, near Bagram in Afghanistan.
    Creators: M.U. Erdosy
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified name "Alexandria" (Baseline created, add BAtlas 6 B3 Alexandria reference); created name "Alexandreia pròs Kaukásōi"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • al-Hajjar
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 95 C3 al-Hajjar

  • Alişar Höyük
    A settlement with occupation from the Chalcolithic period (fourth millennium B.C.) until the Phrygian period (first millennium B.C.).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: update references; add Kealhofer 2023; created OSM location of Alişar Höyük
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Al-Khazneh
    An elaborate, rock-cut monument at Petra built ca. 100 BC to AD 200 known as "Al-Khazneh" or "The Treasury". The Nabatean structure, originally used as a tomb, dates to the reign of Aretas IV Philopatris.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
    Modifications: created OSM location of The Treasury (Al-Khazneh); created connection "Nabataea (region)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Allobroges
    The Allobroges were an ancient Gallic tribe whose territory lay between the between the Rhodanus fl. (Rhône River) and Lemannus L. (Lake Geneva).
    Creators: E. Bertrand
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; jfu
    Modifications: updated Zotero URI for Barruol 1969
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Almus
    Almus (now Lom, Bulgaria) was a place in Moesia Inferior located on the southern bank of the Danube River and near the mouth of a river of the same name (Almus). Both places are noted on the Tabula Peutingeriana.
    Creators: J.J. Wilkes
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary, references; add TP reference; created connection "Almus (river)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Alphe(i)os (river)

  • Althiburos
    Althiburos was a city of Africa Proconsularis that became a municipium under Hadrian and a colonia during the third century A.D.
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Altinum
    Altinum was the capital of the Veneti of northern Italy. The site was destroyed by Attila in AD 452.
    Creators: M. Pearce; P. Tozzi; R. Peretto
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Ammaedara
    An extensive ancient settlement and road station at modern Haidra in Tunisia with evidence for occupation from the Roman, Vandal, and Byzantine eras. The site seems to have been abandoned by the 10th century CE.
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Amphanai?

  • Amphipolis
    A Greek city in Thrace located on the east bank of the Strymon river, Amphipolis was originally founded as an Athenian colony.
    Creators: E.N. Borza
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; G. Reger; R. Talbert

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Amphitheatrum Castrense
    The Amphitheatrum Castrense is a Roman amphitheater built in the third century AD. Its structure was later incorporated into the Aurelianic Walls. Adjacent to the amphitheater is the Christian church of Santa Croce in Gerusalemme.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Amphitheatre Castrense (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Amplero
    The toponym Amplero refers to an archaeological area located to the northeast of Collelongo (L'Aquila) in Italy. The Institute of Archaeology at the University of Pisa conducted fieldwork at the site in 1969-1971.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: updated Names; add Commons reference; summary, details; edited; add Letta 1975 reference; add Arachne Collelongo, (Amplero) L'Aquila (Provinz), Italien, Europa; create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; update references; created OSM location of Sito Archeologico Amplero/La Giostra; created name "La Giostra"; created name "Amplero"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Amymone
    A river and homonymous spring mentioned by Pausanias in the vicinity of Lerna. Its precise location cannot be determined today.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference; cleaned up BAtlas reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott

  • Anavlochos
    An archaeological site in Crete, Anavlochos (Vrachasi, Lasithi), provides evidence of a settlement straddling the end of the Bronze Age and the Early Iron Age, carrying on to the Archaic period (ca 1200-650 BCE).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: added Gaignerot-Driessen 2023; cleaned up references
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Ancient theater of Kourion
    The Ancient theater of Kourion was first built in the second century B.C. It remained in use until the fourth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Kourion Theatre (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

  • Andes
    Andes is said to be the birthplace of the Latin poet Vergil.

  • Andesina
    An ancient place, mentioned only in the Peutinger Map. Its modern location is not known today.
    Creators: C. Haselgrove; J. Kunow
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Andriake
    An ancient settlement in modern Demre on the southern part of the Teke Peninsula, west of the Gulf of Antalya in Turkey. Located about 5 kilometers southwest of the ancient city of Myra, Andriake served as its port.
    Creators: C. Foss; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Phoebe Acheson; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added Çevi̇k 2022; summary; cleaned up references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Andros (island)
    The northernmost island of the Cyclades.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. Bennet
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Stuart Dunn; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference; removed smith (outdated); cleaned up references
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Anfiteatro di Bleso
    The "Anfiteatro di Bleso" is a second century A.D. Roman amphitheater at Tibur (modern Tivoli in Italy).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: created location "OSM location: Anfiteatro di Bleso"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Anisa
    Anisa was an ancient settlement of Cappadocia that was inhabited in Hellenistic, Roman, and Byzantine times.
    Creators: T.B. Mitford
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Jordy Didier Orellana Figueroa; Rune Rattenborg; Stefano Costa; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; R. Talbert; W. Röllig

  • Annuagras
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 48 unlocated Annuagras
    Creators: S.L. Dyson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Antemnae
    Antemnae is an ancient Latin settlement located north of Rome near the point where the Anio and Tiber rivers intersect. Connected with Rome's early history, Antemnae was involved in episodes such as the 'Rape of the Sabine Women' and Romulus is said to have celebrated a triumph over the Antemnates in 752 BC.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add Arachne Antemnae, (Antemnae / Antemnae) Rom (Metropolitanstadt), Italien, Europa; created name "Antemnates"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Anthedon
    A port city of northern Boeotia located in the foothills of Mount Messapion on the Gulf of Euboea.
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created connection "Boeotia"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Anthemous (river)
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 50 D4 Anthemous fl.
    Creators: E.N. Borza

    Modifications: added MANTO reference; cleaned up references; created OSM Location of modern Anthemountas River
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Antigoneia/(Col. Augusta) Alexandria Troas
    An ancient city of the Troad, founded as Antigoneia by Antigonos Monophthalmos. Lysimachos renamed the city Alexandria after 301 BCE. The city became part of the kingdom of Pergamon and, later, the Roman empire.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Phoebe Acheson; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add strabo
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Antiochia/Col. Caesarea
    An ancient city in Pisidia.
    Creators: T. Drew Bear
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Rob Chavez; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; update references; created OSM location of Antiocheia in Psidia
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Antissa
    An ancient settlement on a promontory on the island of Lesbos sometimes referred to as "Ovriokastro". Antissa was destroyed by Roman forces in 166 BCE. The visible archaeological remains derive mostly from a later Genoese fortress.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM Location of Άντισσα (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Antium
    Antium ranked as one of the most important and most powerful centers of Latium and was captured by Rome at the close of the Latin War in the fourth century B.C. Imperial Antium was well known for its number of coastal villas.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Ingrid Luo; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Anzitene
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 89 B2 Anzitene
    Creators: M. Roaf; S.E. Kroll; St J. Simpson; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: Adontz 1970
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Apa Apollo
    A Coptic monastery founded ca. 385/390 located 80 km north of Asyut, near the village of Dashlout, Egypt.
    Creators: M. Drew Bear
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modern name; title; place type -> monastery; added Calament 2023; created name "Bawit"; modified name "Apa Apollo" (Initial revision)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Apamea/Kelainai/Kibotos
    Apamea/Kelainai/Kibotos (modern Dinar) was an ancient settlement of Phrygia located at a road junction linking Ionia to the east. In 333 BC Alexander the Great installed his general Antigonos as satrap of Phrygia.
    Creators: C. Foss; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified location of archaeological area at Dinar, Turkey (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott

  • Apollo Alaeus (temple)
    A sanctuary of Apollo near Punta Alice. Tradition ascribed its foundation to Philoctetes and it is said he dedicated his bow to Apollo.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title; modified OSM location of Tempio di Apollo Aleo (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Apollo Hylates, T.
    The temple of Apollo Hylates, located northwest of Kourion, was one of the most important cult centers of ancient Cyprus. The site was active from the eighth century BCE and until the fourth century CE.
    Creators: D. Rupp
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Sanctuary of Apollo (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Apollonia
    An ancient settlement in the modern S. Fratello commune in northern Sicily.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Jonathan Prag; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale; R. Talbert

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Aptera
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 60 B2 Aptera

    Modifications: modified OSM location of Απτέρα (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Aqua Alexandrina
    The Aqua Alexandrina was an ancient Roman aqueduct that carried water 22.4 km from Pantano Borghese to the Baths of Alexander in the Campus Martius. It was in use from the third to the eighth century AD.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Aqua Alsietina
    The Aqua Alsietina was an aqueduct built by Augustus that drew water from the lacus Alsietinus (Lago di Martignano) and conducted it to Rome.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Aqua Anio Novus
    Aqua Anio Novus is an ancient aqueduct supplying the city of Rome. Begun by Caius in A.D. 38, it was completed and dedicated by Claudius in A.D. 52.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Gabriel Moss; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created OSM location of Acquedotti Claudio e Anio novus
    Actors: Gabriel Moss; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Aqua Appia
    The earliest of Rome's aqueducts, the Aqua Appia was constructed in 312 BC by the censor Appius Claudius Caecus. The aqueduct runs a course of 16.4 km, entering Rome at the Porta Maggiore. Frontinus estimated the daily volume at 75,537 cubic meters.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created location "Imagery Location: aqueduct segment at Piazza Celimontana"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Aqua Augusta (Naples)
    The Aqua Augusta (Naples), also known as the Acquedotto romano del Serino, is a complex aqueduct system supplying Roman-period sites in the Bay of Naples. The aqueduct system was built between ca. 33 and 12 B.C. It supplied a number of Campanian centers, including Pompeii, Herculaneum, and Puteoli.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Acquedotto di Serino (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Aqua Claudia
    The Aqua Claudia was one of the four great aqueducts of the ancient city of Rome. It was begun by Caius in A.D. 38 and completed by Claudius in A.D. 52.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created location "OSM Location: Aqua Claudia ruins in Parco degli Acquedotti "
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Aquae Passeris
    Located in Etruria, Aquae Passeris was frequented in antiquity for its thermal springs, as noted by Martial. The site is included on the Tabula Peutingeriana, placing it on the road from Rome to Volsinii. Its location likely corresponds to that of Bacucco, a comune to the north of Viterbo.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: updated Locations; edited; modified name "Aquae Passeris" (add TP ref.); created connection "Via Ciminia"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

    Creators: W.V. Harris

  • Aqua Tepula
    The Aqua Tepula was an aqueduct built in 126 BC by the censors G. Servilius Caepio and L. Cassius Longinus.

  • Aquileia

  • Aquincum Civil Amphitheater

  • Arados

  • Archelais
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 70 G2 Archelais
    Creators: B. Isaac
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Archilocheion
    A sanctuary dedicated to the Greek lyric poet Archilochus, known as the Archilocheion, was established on Paros during the third century BCE. It is attested textually in both literature and inscriptions; however, the precise location of the sanctuary has not been identified. During the 19th and 20th centuries, some scholars argued for it to be placed at the site of the “Three Churches” (Tris Ekklisies) because inscriptions mentioning Archilochos were found reused in remains of the 6th century Christian basilica over which the later churches had been built. Other scholars (e.g., Kontoleon in PECS) have vigorously rejected this view. Foss (BAtlDir) cites Berranger in tentatively placing the Archilocheion further east at the modern village of Elitas.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title; summary; cleaned up references; update references; created OSM location of basilica at Tris Ekklisies; created OSM Location of modern Elitas; modified name "Archilocheion" (data source (BAtlDir), attested, dates (20th century), type -> label, english, Baseline created); modified connection "Paros (island)" (located on)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Arch of Caracalla
    The so-called Arch of Caracalla at Theveste is a tetrapylon arch dating to the third century. Originally dedicated to the deified Septimius Severus with Julia Domna and Caracalla, the arch was repurposed and modified to function as a gate in the Byzantine city wall.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of CARACALLA'S GATE Tebessa (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Arch of Diocletian

  • Areias Poros
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 47 unlocated Areias Poros
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Areopagus
    Named after a mythical trial of the god Ares, the Areopagus is a rocky outcropping in Athens located to the northwest of the acropolis. The hill was used as a meeting place for the Council of the Areopagus which functioned as a council of elders for the city of Athens. The Areopagus is also traditionally identified as the setting for Paul's sermon to Athens.
    Creators: Ryan Horne
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: added New Pauly and MANTO references
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Arethusae Fons
    Arethusae Fons is a spring in Ortygia, Sicily, traditionally connected with the nymph Arethusa.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; update references; created OSM location of Fountain of Arethusa
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Argolis
    Argolis (also known as 'the Argolid') occupied the eastern part of the Peloponnese; comprising primarily the Argolid peninsula and the coastal region lying to the east of Arcadia, and north of Laconia.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II

  • Argos

  • Ariconium
    A site in Roman Britain located some 20 km northwest of Gloucester along the road leading towards the Wye valley. Numismatic evidence suggests possible Roman military presence.
    Creators: A.S. Esmonde Cleary

  • Arpinum
    An ancient center that originated as early as the seventh century B.C. that became a civitas sine suffragio in 305 B.C. Arpinum was the birthplace of Caius Marius and Marcus Tullius Cicero.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Arslantepe (Melid)
    Arslantepe became an important center in the Late Chalcolithic period. With the decline of the Hittite empire, the site became the center of an independent Luwian Neo-Hittite state (Kammanu). The state became a tributary of the Assyrian empire under Tiglath-Pileser I (1115-1077 BC) and it was sacked by Sargon II in 712 BC.
    Creators: Clifflena Tiah
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; H. Kopp; W. Röllig
    Modifications: add TGN 1086264: Malatya (inhabited place); modified OSM location of Arslantepe Höyüğü (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); created CIGS location of Arslantepe Höyüğü
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker
  • Artaxata
    An ancient city located on and around the hills known today as Khor Virap. This location is near the Armenian village of Lusarat, which is about 8 km south of modern Artashat.
    Creators: M. Roaf; S.E. Kroll; St J. Simpson; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: DARMC x 2; added associated modern Names; summary; added Connection to Araxes river; cleaned up references; added references: EncIran, Livius, Schreiber 2021, Ting 2023, Wikidata; created location "OSM Location: Khor Virap"; created name "Khor Virap"; created name "Lusarat"; created name "Artashat"; created connection "Araxes (river)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Artemis Brauronia
    A sacred site in Attica dedicated to Artemis Brauronia. The sanctuary is active from the Middle Bronze Age period, although a gap in activity stretches from the Final Bronze Age to the eighth century B.C.
    Creators: J.S. Traill
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add TGN 8713186: Brauron (deserted settlement); modified OSM location of Brauron, temple of Artemis (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); modified name "Artemis Brauronia" (Baseline created, ctype, add reference)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

    Creators: A.G. Poulter
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Cetatea Arrubium (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Arusini Campi

    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry

  • Arzâ
    A town mentioned in Neo-Assyrian sources; the modern site is T. Ǧāmā.

  • Asabon (mountain)
    The Al Hajar Mountains of northeastern Oman and the eastern United Arab Emirates are the highest mountain range in the eastern Arabian peninsula.
    Creators: D.T. Potts
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Asea
    Asea was a town of Arcadia, located in the district Maenalia. Lying near the frontier of Laconia, Asea was to be found along the road from Megalopolis to Pallantium and Tegea. Asea participated in the foundation of Megalopolis and many of its inhabitants relocated there.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; created connection "Arcadia"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Ashqelon/Ascalon
    Ashqelon/Ascalon was an ancient city in coastal Palestine, located midway between Azotus and Gaza. It became independent in 104 B.C. and remained the only free city in Palestine. Strabo refers to it, while Pliny calls it a free city (oppidum libera).
    Creators: B. Isaac
    Contributors: Adam Prins; Brady Kiesling; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Sarah Bond; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; Herbert Verreth; Jen Thum; Mark Depauw; R. Talbert; W. Röllig
    Modifications: added MANTO reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Ashur/‘Lamban’?/‘Liba(nai)’?
    Aššur, modern Qal'at Sherqat, is an Assyrian city on the western bank of the Tigris River. Named after its enigmatic tutelary deity, it was the original capital, ancestral home, and burial place of the Assyrian royal family. From the late third millennium B.C. until 614 B.C., when the city was captured and destroyed by the Medes, Aššur was Assyria's most important religious center. It was also Assyria's principal administrative center until the beginning of the ninth century, when Ashurnasirpal II (883-859) moved the capital to the newly constructed Calah.
    Creators: M. Roaf; St J. Simpson
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Ryan Horne; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified name "Aššur" (added HiTop reference, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Asklepios, T.
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 55 unlocated Asklepios, T.
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ašnakkum
    Town in the Khabur River basin in Northern Syria, now known as Chagar Bazar. First settled in the Neolithic Period, the town appears to have been abandoned during the Early Bronze Age. It was resettled in the Early Dynastic period, becoming an administrative center of the Old Assyrian Empire.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: update references; modified OSM location of Chagar Bazar (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); modified name "Tall Shāghir Bāzār" (ctype); modified name "Chagar Bazar" (ctype); modified name "Chagar Bazar" (ctype)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Asopos (river)
    A river of Boeotia and northern Attica that marked the border between the cities of Thebes and Plataea.

  • Asopos (river)

  • Assos/Apollonia
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 C3 Assos/Apollonia
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Rob Chavez; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created OSM location of Assos
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Assur Archive 15 (N 1)
    In the southwest courtyard and nearby rooms of the Aššur temple, researchers found a library and an archive consisting of at least 301 clay tablets, mostly fragmentary, and possibly several hundred more. These tablets were concentrated in the northwest part of the courtyard, the northwest rooms and the Enpi gate, and some stone tablets and other inscribed objects were also found in this area. Tablets found in other parts of the Aššur temple complex also belong to Assur Archive 15. This includes at least 72 clay tablets, often fragmentary, as well as fragmentary clay prisms and cylinders. These tablets were mostly found in the southern part of the large forecourt, as well as west of the temple complex. The texts included in the library date from the Old Assyrian to the Neo Assyrian period, with a core of Middle Assyrian texts and contained cultic and hymnic texts, myths, omens, incantations, prescriptions, lexical lists, as well as hemerological, mathematical, astronomical and astrological texts. The dating of the archive is similar; it contained lists, decrees, letters and historical texts.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jamie Novotny
    Modifications: corrected URL for ATAE Assur 15 (N 1).; edited; new reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • Assuras
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 33 D1 Assuras
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: edited; update references; update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Astapous (river)
    Astapous fl. (Blue Nile or Amharic or an-Nīl al-Azraq (النيل الأزرق‎ an-Nīl)) is a major river of Africa and a tributary of the Nile river. Its source is Lake Tana in Ethiopia.
    Creators: D.T. Potts

  • Ategua
    A Ibero-Roman fortified settlement with substantial archaeological remains stretching into the Middle Ages. The site of Ategua is located near an abandoned farmstead called Cortijo de Teba la Vieja in the area of modern Santa Cruz, approximately 24 kilometers to the southeast of Cordoba in Spain.
    Creators: P.O. Spann
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner

  • Aufidena/Aufinum
    Smith (1854) notes that this station was located at the river mouth where a bridge carried the coast road that led from Sipontum to Barium. Its name is corrupted in various forms, appearing as Aufidena in the Antonine Itinerary and as Aufinum on the Peutinger Table.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Aurelian Walls
    The Aurelian Walls of Rome began as a fortification system built by Aurelian and Probus between 271 and 275. They enclose an area of approximately 1,400 hectares.

  • A(u)xoume
    Present-day Aksum in Ethiopia. The center of the Aksumite Kingdom, a maritime trading power that flourished from the first to the tenth centuries AD. The city was listed as UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1980.

    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Ayanis
    Ayanis (or Ayanıs, now Ağartı Kalesi) is an Urartean fortress and settlement located 35 km north of Van on a rocky outcrop 250 m above Lake Van (1867 m above sea level). It was founded in the 7th century BCE under Rusa, son of Argišti, and was named Rusahinili Eidurukai ("The City of Rusa in front of Mount Eiduru"). Here two inscriptions of Rusa, son of Argišti (7th century BCE), have been found which report that Rusa cultivated the barren land, built the fortress and the city as well as a “tower temple” (“susi temple”) and a “Gate for the God Haldi” (A 12-01 and A 12-09).
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Gabriel Mckee; Noah Kaye; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: added Muşkara 2023
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Aynuna
    In modern Saudi Arabia, about 3km inland from the modern fishing port of al‑Khuraybah on the Gulf of Aqaba, a pair of ancient Nabatean sites occupy high ground to the northwest of the Wadi Aynuna. Settled since at least the Hellenistic period, Aynuna probably served as a Red Sea port for Petra. Most scholars agree that these sites are to be identified collectively with Leuke Kome, mentioned in Strabo and the Periplus of the Erythraean Sea; however, some other locations have been posited (see Gawlikowski 2022, note 5).
    Creators: D.F. Graf
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added Juchniewicz 2023; summary
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Babylon
    The ancient city of Babylon began as an Akkadian city-state founded by Amorites in 1894 B.C. The city was also the seat of the Neo-Babylonian Empire from 608 to 539 B.C.
    Creators: M. Roaf; St J. Simpson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Ryan Horne; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott

  • Balineum Ampelidis et Dianes
    A bath complex that is included in Regio XIV and also possibly represented on the Severan Marble plan. In the Notitia, referred to as "Balineum Ampelidis, Prisci et Dianes" and as Balineum Ampelidis et Dianes in the Curiosum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: update
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Banadedari
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 37 D2 Banadedari

  • Bara
    A modern village located on the border of Iraq and Syria. An Assyrian stele (possibly of Adad-nerari III) was found there.

  • Barbegal

  • Bargylia
    An ancient city of Caria, now known in Turkish as Varvıl. The site is located near the modern Turkish village of Boğaziçi in Muğla province.

    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Barygazon Kolpos

  • Basilica Aemilia
    A basilica located at the juncture of the Sacra Via and the Argiletum flanking the Forum Romanum that was initially built in 179 B.C.E.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
    Modifications: Ertel et al. 2007
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Basilica and convent of S. Ippolito

  • Basilica Julia
    The Basilica Julia was built on the south side of the Forum Romanum in 46 B.C. on the site of the former Basilica Sempronia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
    Modifications: modified location "Basilica Julia (southwest corner)" (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Basilica of Santa Pudenziana
    A palaeo-Christian church dedicated to St. Pudentiana located in Rome and, perhaps, the earliest site of Christian worship in the city. The church is located along the Via Urbana, which follows the course of the ancient vicus Patricius.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of S. Pudenziana (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Basta
    An ancient settlement of Calabria that, according to Pliny the Elder, was located between Hydruntum and the Iapygian Promontory. Modern Vaste, Italy.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM Location of Parco dei Guerrieri di Vaste (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)

  • Boinoa/Oinoe
    According to Strabo, Boinoa/Oinoe was an ancient settlement between Pylos and Lasion in Elis that was either also called Ephyra or located near another place with that name. The precise location of this settlement cannot be determined today.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary; summary
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Bolani
    The Bolani were the people of Bola, an ancient city of Latium. Its foundation is ascribed by Virgil to the kings of Alba.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Bomos Athenas
    Now unlocated, Bomos Athenas was an island in the Red Sea described by Ptolemy as being off the coast of the territory of ancient Aethiopia.
    Creators: D.T. Potts
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary; add place type island; add TM GEO ID
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Bordj-Hellal
    Bordj-Hellal shows evidence for both pre-Roman and Roman phases, as attested by both epigraphic evidence and ceramics.

    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Bouthroton
    Modern Butrint (Butrinti) in Albania, ancient Bouthroton was an ancient Greek and later Roman city located in Epirus. The city became an important bishopric by the sixth century. The site was enrolled as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1992 because of its archaeological remains, which date from prehistoric times down through the late Middle Ages.
    Creators: W.M. Murray
    Contributors: Adam Rabinowitz; Brady Kiesling; Elizabeth Robinson; Gabriel Bodard; Jeffrey Becker; Noura Alavi; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale; DARMC; R. Talbert; Taylor Harrison; jfu
    Modifications: add TP reference; modified name "Bouthrōtón" (update reference); modified name "Buthrotum" (update reference)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Bouto
    Modern Tell/Kawm el-Fara’in, located in Egypt's Nile delta. The site was a locus of human settlement and activity from the prehistoric period through the early Islamic period.
    Creators: A. Bernand
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added Ballet 2023; create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; summary; cleaned up references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Bovium?
    Bovium? was the site of a brickworks that supplied the Roman fort of Deva Victrix.
    Creators: A.S. Esmonde Cleary
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created OSM location of Roman tile factory and depot
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Brenthe
    Brenthe was a city in Arcadia that was reportedly in ruins in Pausanias' time. It was located close to the right bank of the river Alpheius.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: edited; update references; modified name "Brenthe" (Greek name, reference, Baseline created)

  • Brylleion/Myrleia/Apamea/Col. Iulia Concordia
    Brylleion/Myrleia/Apamea/Col. Iulia Concordia was a city in Bithynia founded originally by the Colophonians.
    Creators: C. Foss
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; modified name "Apameia" (update reference)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Bulla Regia
    A center for Numidian royalty, Bulla Regia first became an oppidum liberum in the reign of Augustus and then a colony under Hadrian. The site, which boasts significant archaeological remains, lies in modern Tunisia, about 5km north of the modern city of Jendouba. The site was reportedly known in the 19th century as Hammam-Darradji. Today, a small modern settlement named Aïn Babouch abuts the site (not to be confused with Babouch, which lies further north along the border with Algeria).
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; TGN 7001071: Bulla Regia (deserted settlement); created OSM location of Bulla Regia
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Buluba/Bulba
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 36 unlocated Buluba/Bulba
    Creators: D.J. Mattingly
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference; modified name "Buluba" (add Latin name, add Pliny reference)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Buridava Roman Fort and Vicus
    A Roman fort and associated structures at modern Stolniceni, Romania. An indigenous settlement was likely located a few kilometers to the north.
    Creators: A.G. Poulter
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; Țentea 2021; place type; summary; updated Locations, Names; title; reference cleanup; created Imagery Location of excavated bathhouse; created Approximate imagery location of fortification; created name "Stolniceni"; created connection "Settlement north of Buridava Roman fort and Vicus"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Burmarina Archive 1
    The small town of Burmarina belonged to the area of the city Til-Barsip which was under Neo-Assyrian rule. An archive, consisting of about 130 clay tablets and fragments, including some bullae, was discovered in two rooms, presumably part of a private house, in Area F. Although most texts were written in Assyrian, some were in Aramaic, and some had short Aramaic notes written in ink. While most of the Assyrian texts were loan or purchase documents, the archive also includes short notes and a list. The Aramaic texts concern loans or are short notes written on bullae.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
    Modifications: added ORACC reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • [Bushahr]/Antiocheia Persidos?
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 94 A5 [Bushahr]/Antiocheia Persidos?
    Creators: A. Hausleiter; M. Roaf; R. Wenke

  • Byzacena
    Byzacena was a late Roman province in the diocese of Africa. It was located in what is now Tunisia.
    Creators: A.S. Esmonde-Cleary; C.M. Wells; J.F. Drinkwater; J.J. Wilkes; R.C. Knapp; R.S. Bagnall; S. Mitchell; S.T. Parker; W.V. Harris

  • Caere
    Caere (also known as Cisra or Cerveteri) was a major Etruscan polis located ca. 50 km north-northwest of Rome in southern Etruria.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Caesena
    An Umbrian and Etruscan city on the Savio river that passed into Roman control in the third century B.C.
    Creators: M. Pearce; P. Tozzi; R. Peretto

  • Cales
    Cales was an ancient city of Campania of Ausonian origins. The Romans captured the town in 335 B.C. and established a colony there.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

    Modifications: update references; Initial revision
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Camarina
    Camarina was founded by Syracuse in 599 B.C., but subsequently destroyed in 552 B.C. The city was re-founded by Gela in 461 B.C. Carthage razed the site in 405 B.C., but Timoleon restored it in 339 B.C. From the late third century B.C. the town fell under Roman administration.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference; cleaned up Thucydides reference; create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; modified OSM location of the archaeological site of Kamarina (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Cambete
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 18 E2 Cambete
    Creators: G.D. Woolf
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Campetti - Decumano
    At Campetti - Decumano, in the southwestern part of Veii near the "Portonaccio" gate, there is evidence for a sacred complex that includes a therapeutic bath dating to the Roman period. Some residential functions emerged in Late Antiquity.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Campetti - Decumano (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

  • Cannae
    An ancient settlement of Apulia on the Aufidus river. Nearby the Roman army suffered a major defeat at the hands of the Carthaginians in 216 B.C. during the Second Punic War.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Capitolinus Mons
    The smallest of Rome's hills and one of its most important, the Capitoline served as the citadel (arx) of the city and as the site of its poliadic temple.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott

  • Capitolium

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Cappellette
    The site of a villa located between Frascati and Monte Porzio Catone. It is associated with Matidia Augusta on account of an inscribed fistula discovered there in 1888.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: edited; update references; modified OSM location of Villa di Matidia Augusta (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)

  • Capsa (Iustiniana)

  • Caralis
    A city with its origins in a Phoenician settlement of the seventh century BC, Caralis comes under Roman control in 238 BC during the Punic Wars. Florus refers to it as urbs urbinum, or capital of Sardinia
    Creators: S.L. Dyson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Carbia
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 48 A2 Carbia
    Creators: S.L. Dyson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Carchemish
    An ancient city that was part of the Mitanni, Hittite, and Neo-Assyrian Empires (Kargamiš in Hittite; commonly Carchemish). The site was occupied as early as the Neolithic and Chalcolithic periods; evidence for Early Bronze Age cist tombs begins ca. 2400 BC. It was a key commercial center during the time of Ebla and Mari. The Mitanni controlled the site from the sixteenth to the fourteenth centuries and was conquered by Šuppiluliuma ca. 1350 B.C. A famous battle, attested in the Bible, was fought at the site in 605 BC between the Babylonian army under Nebuchadnezzar II and that of the Egyptian Pharaoh Necho II.
    Creators: P.-L. Gatier; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Carolin Johansson; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; M. Ballance; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: add Pliny reference; update references; title; created CIGS location of Karkamış; created name "Εὔρωπος"; created name "Karkamış"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Cardo Maximus (Apamea)
    The Cardo Maximus of Apamea in Syria is the site of the so-called "Great Colonnade", a portico that flanks the road for some 2 kilometers.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM Location of Cardo Maximus of Apamea in Syria (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Cares (river)
    The ancient Cares has been identified with the modern Cher in France. It is a tributary of the Liger (modern Loire).
    Creators: H.S. Sivan; R.W. Mathisen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference; modified OSM location of Le Cher (Reimported full relation geometry and updated provenance)

  • Caria (province)

  • Carnuntum
    A Roman army camp on the Danube river in Noricum; after the first century AD Carnuntum served as the capital of Upper Pannonia.
    Creators: A. Bursche; L.F. Pitts
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sarah Bond; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; E. Krekovič; P. Kaczanowski; R. Madyda‑Legutko; R. Talbert

  • Carteia/Calpe/Karpessos
    A Phoenician and Roman town in Spain located on the Bay of Gibraltar. The site played a strategic role in the Punic Wars, and was given the rights of a Latin colony in 171 BC.
    Creators: F.H. Stanley; Jr.; R.C. Knapp
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Jonathan Prag; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; update reerences; created OSM location of Carteia; modified name "Calpe" (update reference)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Carthago
    The ancient city of Carthage, located in modern Tunis (Tunisia). Carthage engaged the Roman state in a series of wars conventionally referred to as the Punic Wars by scholars.
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Ingrid Luo; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Jonathan Prag; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: add references - Cuntz, ItMiller; added MANTO reference; modified name "Carthago" (Baseline created, add Latin name, add Livy reference,)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Casa Branca
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 26 B3 Casa Branca
    Creators: F.H. Stanley; Jr.; R.C. Knapp
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Fortificação Romana de Casa Branca (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Casa dei Grifi
    A late Republican domus of the Palatine Hill that was later consumed by the substructures of the Domitianic wing of the Flavian palace. The Casa dei Grifi preserves important wall paintings that are transitional from the First to the Second Pompeian style. Giacomo Boni discovered the domus in 1912.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Casa dei Grifi (Reimported full relation geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Casa della Regina Carolina
    A domus at Pompeii partially excavated in the nineteenth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Casa della Regina Carolina (VIII 3.14) (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Casa della statuetta indiana
    The so-called "Casa della statuetta indiana" (I.8.5) lies on the Via dell'Abbondanza. Excavated between 1930 and 1935, it was named for the fine ivory statuette (thought by some to depict Lakshmi) found inside. The house has a slightly irregular floor plan with some rooms added to the structure from adjacent properties.
    Creators: Holly Sypniewski
    Contributors: Gabriel Moss; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of so-called "House of the Indian Statuette" (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: edited
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Casalbore
    At modern Casalbore, Italy, archaeological evidence includes a significant temple structure and associated material from the Samnite and Roman periods.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
