    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Casale Sinibalda
    The Casale Sinibalda is located on the western side of the Fosso Saina. Located to the north of the casale are the remains of a basis villae of the so-called fourth style, meaning it verges on opus quadratum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Casale Sinibalda (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Casal Rotondo
    A Roman tomb that supports a Medieval farmhouse (casale) at the sixth mile of the Via Appia. The tomb originally dates ca. 30 BC; it was a large, circular tomb with a diameter of approximately 35 m.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Casal Rotondo (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)

    Modifications: update reference; modified name "Casa Rimoniana" (update reference)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Cassio
    A villa in Tibur that has been incorrectly linked to Gaius Cassius Longinus. In the eighteenth century, the site produced a cache of Egyptianizing sculpture that likely dates to the reign of Hadrian and is now held in the Vatican Museums.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update deprecated Arachne reference --> IDAI gaz.; created OSM location of Ruderi della villa di Cassio
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Castalian spring
    A spring in the ravine between the Phaedriades cliffs (on the lower southern slope of Mt. Parnassos) at Delphi.

  • Castellum aquae

    Creators: E.W.B. Fentress

    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Castel Malnome (Ponte Galeria)
    An imperial necropolis with at least 326 tombs was identified at modern Castel Malnome (Ponte Galeria) in Italy. Archaeological evidence marks these as burials belonging to working-class people of the Roman imperial period, with most graves having either no grave goods or very few. The osteoarchaeological analysis led excavators to speculate that the individuals buried here many have worked in the salt flats.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: add vici.org 58288: Necropoli di Malnome
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Castelraimondo
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 19 E3 Castelraimondo
    Creators: H. Bender
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; G. Moosbauer; M. Puhane; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Castel Sant'Angelo
    The Mausoleum of Hadrian, also known as the Castel Sant'Angelo, is an Imperial tomb located on the right bank of the Tiber River.

    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; jfu
    Modifications: references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

  • Castulonensis Saltus
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 27 B3 Castulonensis Saltus
    Creators: P.O. Spann
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Ross Twele; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; R. Warner; Richard Talbert
    Modifications: created OSM location of Cerro de la Parrilla
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Catacomb of Ponziano
    A Paleochristian catacomb at the second mile of the via Portuensis. The catacomb is noted for containing the original tombs of Pope Anastasius I and his son Pope Innocent I.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Catacombe di Ponziano (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Catacombs of Generosa
    A Paleochristian catacomb located at the sixth mile of the via Portuense.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Catacomb of Generosa (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Catacombs of San Senatore
    A Christian catacomb located at the fifteenth mile of the Via Appia in use from the late third century A.D. until the Middle Ages.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Catacombe di S. Senatore (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Caunus
    An ancient city of Caria in southwest Asia Minor.
    Creators: C. Foss; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Rob Chavez; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created OSM location of Kaunos; created connection "Caria (region)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Cave of Eileithyia (Inatos)
    Sacred cave dedicated to the goddess of childbirth, Eileithyia, at Inatos, Crete. The site was in use from the Geometric period to the Roman period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: Hölbl et al. 2022
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Cayster (river)
    The Küçükmenderes River.

  • Celenderis
    An ancient city on the southern coast of Asia Minor at modern Aydıncık in Turkey's Mersin province. It was a major pottery producer and exporter during the Achaemenid period.
    Creators: S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Rob Chavez; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Central Baths
    A bath complex (IX, 4, 5-18) located at the intersection of the Via Stabiana and Via di Nola that was built following the earthquake of AD 62.
    Creators: Athanasia Varveri
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Valeria Vitale
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Terme centrali (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Centum Celas
    Centum Cellas, also referred to as Centum Cellæ, Centum Celli, or Centum Cœli refers to a Roman villa rustica of the first century A.D., located in the Castelo Branco district of Portugal.
    Creators: E.W. Haley
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created OSM location of Centum Cellas
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Centum Cellae
    Centum Cellae (modern Civitavecchia) was an ancient coastal settlement in Tyrrhenian Etruria. The emperor Trajan re-builds the harbor at the site in 106/7 and Pliny the Younger mentions its name, Centum Cellae. Saracens destroyed the city in A.D. 812.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

  • Cerro de las Cabezas
    The Cerro de las Cabezas is an archaeological site located approx. 8 km south of Valdepeñas, in the province of Ciudad Real, Spain.

    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner

  • Cetamura
    Cetamura is an ancient hilltop settlement with occupation phases stretching from the Etruscans to the Romans to the Medieval period. The site is located near Gaiole, Radda and Castellina in Chianti, Italy.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Elizabeth Robinson; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; modified OSM location of Cetamura del Chianti (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)

  • Chaon (mountain)
    Mentioned by Pausanias, this mountain is securely identified with the modern Megavouni (Greece).

  • Chapel of Hakor
    Chapel for the Sacred Barque of Amun-Ra in Karnak, established by the Egyptian pharaoh Hakor of the Twenty-ninth dynasty who reigned from 392/1 to 379/8 BCE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Barque Chapel of Hakoris (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Charcha/‘Arcaiapis’/Karcharoman

    Creators: M. Roaf; S.E. Kroll; St J. Simpson; T. Sinclair

  • Charra
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 91 unlocated Charra
    Creators: M. Roaf; St J. Simpson

    Modifications: update references; modified name "Charra" (add TP reference)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Chatal Höyük (Amuq)
    Mound site in the Amuq Plain inhabited from the late 4th millennium BCE-mid-1st millennium BCE. In the Late Bronze Age Chatal Höyük was the site of a sizeable town with connections to the Hittite Empire. In the Iron Age the town was within the sphere of the Syro-Hittite state of Unqi, based at Tell Tayinat/Kinaliya. The town gradually declined, but remained inhabited without interruption until at least the fifth century BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Çatal Höyük; created name "Çatal Höyük"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Chaussée Jules César
    A Roman road linking Lutetia and Rotomagus, the construction of which was begun by Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa. The modern French Route nationale 14 follows the course of the ancient road.
    Creators: C. Haselgrove; J. Kunow
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference; modified OSM location of Chaussée Jules César (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Cibyra
    An ancient Greek city, largely rebuilt in the early Roman empire after a major earthquake. Kibyra is located near the modern town of Göhlisar (formerly Horzum) in Turkey's Burdur province.
    Creators: C. Foss; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Rob Chavez; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Cilicia
    An ancient region, stretching along the southern coast of Asia Minor as far north as the Taurus mountains and westward from the Amanus mountains to the river Melas or, according to some ancient commentators, all the way to the coastal city of Korakesion (modern Alanya in Turkey)
    Creators: P.-L. Gatier; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Sarah Bond; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; M. Ballance; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: added MANTO reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott

  • Ciminius (mountain)

  • *Cincaris
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 32 E3 *Cincaris
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Circeii 1
    Circeii received a Latin colony ca. 390 B.C. The remains on the site include an enclosure wall built in polygonal masonry. "Circeii 1" refers to the earlier Roman colony founded at the eastern side of Monte Circeo. The settlement eventually moved to the western side of the peninsula.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Circus Maximus
    An ancient chariot-racing venue at Rome and a major location for public entertainments (ludi), the Circus Maximus is located between the Aventine and Palatine hills.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
    Modifications: created location "OSM location: Circus Maximus"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Cirta/Constantina
    The capital city of the ancient Berber Kingdom of Numidia.
    Creators: E.W.B. Fentress
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner

  • Cluacar(ia)?

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Cnidus
    Cnidus, a Greek city of ancient Caria that was part of the Dorian Hexapolis, was located at modern Burgaz in south-western Asia Minor on the modern Datça peninsula (Knidia) in Turkey. In the late fourth century, the political center of the peninsula moved from the site at Burgaz to the site at Tekir.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Noah Kaye; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; created connection "Caria (region)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Cnidus
    An ancient settlement located at Tekir on the western tip of the modern Datça peninsula in Turkey (ancient Knidia), which extends from the southwest corner of Asia Minor. In the later fourth century BCE, it grew markedly, succeeding the site at Burgaz as the political center of the peninsula.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Noah Kaye; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Coaña (El Castelón de)
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 24 E1 Coaña (El Castelón de)
    Creators: E.W. Haley
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created OSM location of El Castrillón (Castro de Cuaña/Coaña)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Cocosates (Sexsignani)
    A pre-Roman tribe that settled in what today is southwestern France, to the north of the river Adour. They were bounded by the Tarbelli to the south and the Boiates to the north.
    Creators: H.S. Sivan; R.W. Mathisen; S.J. Keay
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Michael Heubel; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; Richard Talbert
    Modifications: update references; modified name "Cocosates Sexsignani" (Latin name, Pliny reference); modified name "Cocosates" (Latin name, Caesar reference); created connection "Aquitani"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Col. Barcino
    Colonia Iulia Augusta Paterna Faventia Barcino (Barcelona) was a Roman settlement in Tarraconensis founded by Augustus.
    Creators: H.S. Sivan; R.W. Mathisen; S.J. Keay
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added Bianco 2023; modified name "Col. Barcino" (additional romanization form)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Colchis/Lazike
    Colchis/Lazike was an ancient region located to the east of the Black Sea.
    Creators: David Braund
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Diane Braund; R. Talbert; Richard Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference; removed Xenophon and Herodotus references as they seem to be erroneous; cleaned up references
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Col. Dea Vocontiorum
    An Augustan colony in Gallia Narbonensis located in the valley of the Drôme river; an important cultic center of the Vocontii.
    Creators: E. Bertrand
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: updated Zotero URI for Barruol 1969
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Collegium at Italica
    A building that has been identified as the seat of a Collegium because of its internal structure and size, was previously known as the"House of the Exedra".
    Creators: Lai Ching Tsui
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: added Brühlmann 2022; created name "Casa de la Exedra"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Colle Madore
    Colle Madore is an archaeological site connected with the Sicanians.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; update references; created OSM location of Area archeologica del Colle Madore
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Column of Trajan
    The Column of Trajan (or Trajan's Column) is a victory column that was erected in the Forum of Trajan at Rome ca. 113 in order to commemorate Trajan's victories in the Dacian Wars. The column is particularly noted for its helical historiated bas relief frieze decoration.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
    Modifications: update deprecated Arachne ref --> iDAI.gazetteer reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Comama/Col. Iulia Augusta Prima Fida
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 65 D3 Comama/Col. Iulia Augusta Prima Fida
    Creators: C. Foss; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: references; created connection "Untitled"

  • Complutum
    Complutum (modern Alcalá de Henares in Spain) was an ancient oppidum founded in the first century CE and largely re-fashioned in the third century.
    Creators: H.S. Sivan; R.W. Mathisen; S.J. Keay
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Javier Martínez Jiménez; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; summary; created OSM location of Complutum
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Compsa
    Compsa was a city of the Hirpini, located near the sources of the Aufidus river.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Condrusi

  • Contributa Iulia Ugultunia
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 26 D3 Contributa Iulia Ugultunia
    Creators: F.H. Stanley; Jr.; R.C. Knapp
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Coptos
    An ancient settlement on the Nile river (modern Quft/Qift in Egypt) that flourished from pre-dynastic times through late antiquity.
    Creators: J. Keenan; S.E. Sidebotham; T. Wilfong
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added Pantalacci 2023
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Corbio
    Corbio was an ancient city of Latium located on the northeastern flank of the Alban Hills, although its precise location is no longer secure. This Latin city is said to have fallen to the Aequi and then been the subject of contention between the Aequi and the Romans, ultimately recaptured by the latter after Cincinnatus' victory at Mons Algidus in 458 B.C.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; modified name "Korbion" (update references)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Corcyra (island)
    An island located in the Ionian Sea. Modern-day Corfu, Greece.
    Creators: W.M. Murray
    Contributors: Ingrid Luo; Jeffrey Becker; Pierre Motylewicz; Perry Scalfano; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Corent
    Corent was the site of a Celtic and Gallo-Roman oppidum.
    Creators: H.S. Sivan; R.W. Mathisen
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created OSM location of Place centrale gallo-romaine
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Coriaria Septimiana
    A place included the Regionary Catalogues for Rome's Regio XIV, Coriaria Septimiana refers to tanneries in the Transtiberim. On the basis of epigraphic evidence, the place listed in the Notitia is associated with a small tanning facility on the site of the paleochristian church of Saint Cecilia in Trastevere.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Coriglia, Castel Viscardo
    An Etrusco-Roman settlement.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Coriglia, Castel Viscardo (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)

  • Corigliano
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 45 H4 Corigliano

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Corinth Canal
    The Corinth Canal cuts across the Isthmus of Corinth, connecting the Gulf of Corinth to the Saronic Gulf and the Aegean Sea. Several abortive attempts in antiquity were made at creating the canal, although its final (and functional) realization occurred in modernity.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Corinth Canal (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Corinthiacus Sinus
    The Gulf of Corinth.

    Modifications: created connection "Boeotia"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Corioli
    Corioli was an ancient city of Latium connected in the tradition with C. Marcius Coriolanus. The location of Corioli is no longer known.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references

  • Cornus

  • Cozzo Presepe
    Cozzo Presepe is an archaeological site located in the Basilicata region of Italy, specifically in the comune of Montescaglioso. A number of archaeological features have been identified at the site, including an unusual defensive wall dating ca. 300 BCE.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add arachne reference; add Wikidata Q97729244: Cozzo Presepe; add references x 2; modified OSM location of Cozzo Presepe (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); created name "Cozzo Presepe"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Crathis/Crater (river)

    Modifications: created OSM location of Crati (river course)

  • Cremna/Col. Iulia Augusta Felix
    A significant Hellenistic settlement of Pisidia that received an Augustan colony, taking the name Colonia Iulia Augusta Felix Cremnensium.
    Creators: C. Foss; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Crustumerium
    An ancient town of Latium located at the headwaters of the Allia river, very close to the territory of the Sabines, Crustumerium figures in Rome's early history. The Romans conquered the site in 500 B.C. and formed the tribus Crustumina or Clustumina in 471 B.C.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: edited; add TGN 7005788: Monterotondo (inhabited place); created name "Crustumini"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Cugno dei Vagni

  • Cuicul

  • Cutha
    Kutha or Cutha (modern Tell Ibrahim) is located on the Upper Euphrates, north of Nippur and northeast of Babylon. The archaeological site consists of two tells. Archaeological evidence of the Neo-Babylonian period has been revealed by excavation.
    Creators: M. Roaf; St J. Simpson
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; created CIGS location of Tall Ībrāhīm; modified name "Tell Ibrahim" (change type to assoc modern name); created name "Tall Ībrāhīm"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker

  • Cythera (island)
    An Aegean island located off the southeastern peninsula of the Peloponnese. It appears frequently in Greek and Roman literature beginning with Homer.

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Dea Dia (temple)
    The Arval Brethren cultivated the cult of the Dea Dia. Remains of this Augustan era temple, located at La Tavernaccia restaurant in the Magliana vecchia neighborhood of Rome, are subterranean and not open to the public.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Decimomannu Roman bridge
    The remains of a stone, arched Roman bridge at Decimomannu, to the west of Assemini, Sardinia. Three of the original six arches survive today. The bridge may originally have been as much as 160 meters in length. R.J. Rowland considered it to be of Iulio-Claudian date.
    Creators: S.L. Dyson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Ponte romano (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Deir Abou Menas
    An ancient Christian pilgrimage site that grew into an active town centered around the monastery complex devoted to Saint Menas who is said to have been buried there. The town reached its peak as the most visited pilgrimage site in Egypt during the sixth century AD.
    Creators: A. Bernand
    Contributors: Adam Prins; Iris Fernandez; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; Herbert Verreth; Jen Thum; Mark Depauw; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; created OSM location of Abu Mena
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Deir el-Medina
    The workers' village of the artisans who worked on the New Kingdom tombs in the Valley of the Kings.
    Creators: Roko Rumora
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: added Larcher 2023; modified name "Deir el-Medina" (additional romanization form)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Delphi
    The ancient pan-Hellenic sanctuary of Delphi in Greece, seat of the oracle of Apollo.
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin
    Contributors: Adam Rabinowitz; Brady Kiesling; Danielle Hoyer; Gabriel Bodard; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Patrick DeVarney; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale; DARMC; Danielle Hoyer; G. Reger; Kristin Wenske; R. Talbert; Yeonsoo Kang

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Demeter Sanctuary (Eleusis)
    The Sanctuary of Demeter at Eleusis in Attica was the site of the celebration of the Eleusinian mysteries, observed from the Archaic period to Late Antiquity.
    Creators: J.S. Traill
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created OSM location of Αρχαιολογικός χώρος Ελευσίνος; created connection "Eleusis"; created connection "Attica"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Demetrion
    An ancient settlement and port on the west coast of the Aegean island of Samothrace, now occupied by the modern port of Kamariotissa.
    Creators: E.N. Borza
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; G. Reger; R. Talbert

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Dez/Hithite/Hudhud/Koprates? (river)
    This river, known by various names in antiquity, was an upstream tributary (via the Karun river) of the final stage of ancient Tigris/Pastigiris, ultimately debouching into the Persian Gulf. Today its waters still join the Karun. The modern course of the Dez lies within the modern country of Iran.
    Creators: A. Hausleiter; M. Roaf; R. Wenke; St J. Simpson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; P. Flensted Jensen; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • ‘Diabas’/Turnat (river)
    The Diyala River is a major tributary of the Tigris.
    Creators: M. Roaf; St J. Simpson
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of modern Diyala-Tigris confluence (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); modified OSM location of modern course of Diyala River (Reimported full relation geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

  • Diktynnaion
    A sanctuary located at Menies bay in Chania, Crete, with remains ranging in date from Hellenistic period to Late Antiquity.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. Bennet
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Diluntum
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 20 E6 Diluntum
    Creators: M. Šašel Kos; P. Kos
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Dimini
    The modern Greek village of Dimini in Thessaly lends its name to important prehistoric and Bronze Age settlements whose remains lie in its vicinity. In the 20th century, some scholars attempted to assign the placename "Aison" (reported by Stephanus of Byzantium) here as well, but others now reject the name entirely as false. The vicinity was abandoned at the end of the thirteenth century BCE and not reoccupied until modern times.
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary; added Odysseus reference; corrected NP link; title; summary; modified OSM location of archaeological site of Dimini (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); modified name "Aison" (removed defective empty reference, Greek, attested, false, new pauly reference, uncertain)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Diomedeae (islands)

  • Dioscurias/Sebastopolis
    A Greek city established by Miletos ca. 540 B.C. on the site of an earlier second millennium B.C. settlement.
    Creators: David Braund; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; Diane Braund; R. Talbert

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Diospolis Magna/Thebai
    Diospolis Magna/Thebai was known in ancient Egypt as Waset, "City of the Sceptre". The site was designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979.
    Creators: J. Keenan; S.E. Sidebotham; T. Wilfong
    Contributors: Adam Prins; Brady Kiesling; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Jeffrey Becker; Roko Rumora; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; Herbert Verreth; Jen Thum; Mark Depauw; R. Talbert; W. Röllig

  • Dolicha (island)
    The ancient Ionian island of Dolicha is probably to be associated with the modern, now-landlocked peak known as Koutsilaris in the modern Greek municipality of Mesolongi.
    Creators: W.M. Murray
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: cleaned up references; added MANTO reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Dolmen of Guadalperal
    A megalithic stone circle dating to the third millennium BCE located in Peraleda de la Mata in eastern Extremadura, Spain. The monument is usually submerged beneath the waters of the Embalse de Valdecañas, a reservoir of the Tagus river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: created OSM location of Dolmen de Guadalperal
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Dolopia
    A region of Greece inhabited by the Dolopes.

  • Dragoncello
    Dragoncello is a modern district of Rome's metropolitan area where archaeological evidence for a series of late republican villas was uncovered. At least four in number, these villa rustica sites have evidence for domestic production.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Villa di Dragoncello (sito F) (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)

  • Dūru

    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Džanfida
    Džanfida is a village located in the Armavir province of southwestern Armenia, ca. 9 km south of Sardarabat. Here a stone block with an inscription of Sarduri II (8th century BCE) was found which curses anyone who dares to damage or destroy his fortress or inscription.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Janfida; created name "Janfida"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Early Mithraeum

    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: Initial revision
    Actors: Anne Chen
  • Eburones
    The Eburones were an ancient people of Gallia Belgica.

    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ecbatana/Hagmatana/Achmeta/Epiphaneia/Ahmadan
    The capital of Astyages (Istuvegü), captured by Cyrus the Great in 549 BC. The site served as a summer residence for both Persian and Parthian kings.
    Creators: A. Hausleiter; E.J. Keall; M. Roaf
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Carolin Johansson; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; R. Talbert; W. Röllig

    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott

  • Elst
    In the villae of Elst, located between Arnhem and Nijmegen, the remains of two quadrangular Romano-Celtic type temples were discovered beneath the parish church following World War II.

  • Ely Roman Villa
    An extensive villa site of Roman imperial date, excavated in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Located in the current "Trelai Park", Ely Village, Cardiff, Wales.

  • Enipeus (river)
    Located in ancient Elis, the Enipeus was a right tributary of the Alpheius, which it joined downstream (west) of ancient Olympia. It has been identified with the modern Lestenitsas.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added OSM Location; summary; added New Pauly reference; added associated modern name; cleaned up references; added Connection to Alpheios; added MANTO reference; created OSM Location of modern Lestenitsas Potamos; created name "Lestenitsas Potamos"; modified name "Enipeus" (greek, strabo, Baseline created); modified name "Barnichios" (new pauly reference, greek, Baseline created); created connection "Alphe(i)os (river)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Erannoboas/Sonus (river)

    Modifications: add wikipedia ref.; update references; created OSM location of Son River; modified name "Erannoboas" (Greek name, reference); modified name "Sonus" (Latin name, Pliny ref.); created connection "Ganges (river)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Erasinos (river)
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 59 C3 Erasinos fl.

  • Eretum
    Eretum was a settlement of the Sabines and is involved in legendary accounts of early Rome.
    Creators: W.V. Harris

  • Eryx

  • Euboea (island)
    Euboea is the second largest Greek island by area and is separated from the Greek mainland by the Euripus Strait.
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Pierre Motylewicz; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Euboicus Sinus
    The Gulf of Euboea is an arm of the Aegean Sea.

    Modifications: created connection "Boeotia"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Euenos (river)
    The Euenos (modern Evinos) is a river of western Greece that flows into the Gulf of Patras.
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin

    Modifications: added MANTO reference; cleaned up references

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Falerii
    A fortified town located some 6 km from Falerii Veteres and established by the ancient Romans ca. 241 B.C.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add TGN; modified OSM location of archaeological area (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); created location "OSM Location: Falerii Novi Archaeological Area"; created name "Falerii Novi"; created name "colonia Iunionia Faliscorum"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Falerii Veteres
    Falerii Veteres was the principal city of the Faliscans. It is located on a tuff outcropping at the point where several tributaries of the Treia join to flow into the Tiber. After rebelling against Rome in 241 B.C., Falerii suffered serious reversals of fortune.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created CIGS location of Falerii; modified name "Falerii Veteres" (reference); modified name "Civita Castellana" (reference, type); created connection "Falisci"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Falisci
    The name for a group of Italic people who occupied the Ager Faliscus within Etruria.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Michael Heubel; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; Richard Talbert
    Modifications: reference; modified name "Falisci" (add Latin name attested, Livy reference, Baseline created); created name "Faliscans"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Fanum Carisi
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 48 B2 Fanum Carisi
    Creators: S.L. Dyson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Fanum Fugitivi
    A road station on the Via Flaminia, located between Interamna and Spoletium.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: ItMiller; update references

  • Fanum Minervae
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 11 unlocated Fanum Minervae
    Creators: C. Haselgrove; J. Kunow
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Fanum Voltumnae
    A shrine of Voltumna that served as the chief religious center of Etruria. The Etruscan League (duodecim populi Etruriae) was said to meet annually at the shrine. Archaeological excavations of the site of Campo della Fiera have been posited as the definitive location of the Fanum Voltumnae.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added Laschi et al. 2023; edited; summary (from location by jbecker); modified OSM location of Campo della Fiera (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); modified name "Fanum Voltumnae" (update references)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Ficana
    An ancient city of Latium that was said to have been conquered by Ancus Marcius, Ficana was located near the eleventh mile of the Via Ostiensis. Excavation at the site has produced important evidence for the urban center beginning from the eighth century BC. Pliny the Elder mentions Ficana as one of the lost cities of Latium.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created OSM location of Ficana
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Fidenae
    Fidenae was an ancient city of Latium.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created name "Fidenates"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Figlinae
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 17 D3 Figlinae
    Creators: E. Bertrand
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Findspot of so-called Kabul Hoard

  • Flavian Amphitheater at Puteoli
    The Flavian Amphitheater at Puteoli is an amphitheater constructed in the port town of Puteoli under the Flavian dynasty around 80 CE.

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Florentia
    Florentia (modern Florence / Firenze) was founded as a colony for military veterans ca. 80 B.C. by Lucius Cornelius Sulla.

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Forte Michelangelo
    A fortress at modern Civitavecchia in Italy. It was begun in 1508 and completed 1537 during the reign of Pope Paul III. Antonio Sangallo the Younger designed the fortress.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Forte Michelangelo (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Fortis Fortuna, T.
    A sanctuary (fanum) of Fors Fortuna in Trastevere. Varro ascribes its foundation to Servius Tullius.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Forum Aurelii
    A settlement in Etruria situated on the Via Aurelia between Centumcellae and Cosa according to the Antonine Itinerary.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add Nenci reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Forum Boarium (at Rome)
    Rome's so-called "cattle market", the Forum Boarium is a key area of commercial and ritual activity on the east bank of the river Tiber. It is flanked by the Capitoline, Palatine, and Aventine hills.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Forum Boarium (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, edited)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Forum Clodii
    An ancient road station on the Via Clodia.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Forum Flaminii
    A town founded in 220 B.C. by Caius Flaminius during the construction of the Via Flaminia.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; update references; created OSM location of San Giovanni Profiamma
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

    The Roman Forum of Scylletium/Scolacium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Forum of Skilletion (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Fosso Saina
    A minor tributary of the Anio river in the vicinity of Guidonia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Fosso Saina (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Franchthi Cave
    The Franchthi Cave is located on the Argolic Gulf in southeastern Argolis. The cave was occupied from the Paleolithic (ca. 20,000 BC) through to the Mesolithic and Neolithic periods, ultimately being abandoned ca. 3000 BC. The cave shows continuous human occupation for more than 20,000 years.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
    Modifications: modified location of Franchthi Cave (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • François Tomb
    An important painted Etruscan tomb dating to the final quarter of the fourth century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: jfu
    Modifications: add Arachne Tomba François Vulci, Viterbo (Provinz); modified OSM location of François Tomb (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Fratte
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 G4 Fratte
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Area archeologica etrusco-sannitica di Fratte (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Fregellae
    Fregellae was a city of Latium Adjectum that became a Roman colony in 328 B.C., but was subsequently captured by the Samnites; a Roman presence was re-established in 313 B.C. Loyal to Rome during the Second Punic War, Fregellae revolted in 125 B.C. and the site was razed.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update arachne refs x 2
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Fregenae
    An ancient town of Etruria, Fregenae was located between Alsium and the mouth of the river Tiber.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified name "Fregenae" (update reference)

  • Freiria

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Fresilia
    Now unlocated, Fresilia was a fortified city of the Marsi that the Roman dictator M. Valerius Maximus captured in 302 B.C.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary; modified name "Fresilia" (add Latin name, add Livy reference,)

  • Gabii
    An ancient Latin city located on the line of the Republican Via Praenestina connecting Rome to Praeneste. Gabii is allied to Rome from an early date and flourished during the archaic period, declining by the time of Augustus.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added Glisoni 2023
    Actors: Tom Elliott

    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Galava
    A Roman fort located along the Roman road from Brougham to Ravenglass. The previous association with Ambleside is now in doubt since the discovery of a diploma at Ravenglass in 1995, which plausibly links Itunocelum with Ravenglass, and consequently making Ambleside more likely to be identified with *Glannoventa.
    Creators: A.S. Esmonde Cleary
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Scott Vanderbilt; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: update references; modified OSM location of Galava Roman fort (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Galin(...)
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 35 unlocated Galin(...)
    Creators: D.J. Mattingly
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Gallo-Roman Theater of Lillebonne
    The Gallo-Roman Theater of Lillebonne was in use from the first to the third century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Gabriel Moss
    Modifications: add tag; modified OSM location of Théâtre gallo-romain (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ganges (river)
    The Ganges flows some 2,525 km (1,569 mi) from its sources in the western Himalayas to the Bay of Bengal.
    Creators: M.U. Erdosy
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: Renou 1925; modified location of course of Ganges fl. (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ganges (river in Sri Lanka)
    This ancient name is probably to be associated with the modern Mahaweli, which is the longest river of Sri Lanka.
    Creators: M.U. Erdosy
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title; update references, add summary; summary; created OSM location of Mahaweli River; created name "Mahaweli River"; created connection "Orientale Mare/Gangeticus Sinus/Eous Oceanus"

    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Garden and Pool Complex at Petra
    Garden terrace and monumental pool with island pavilion dates to the Nabataean/Early Roman periods, 9 BCE-c. 200 CE. Formerly called the "Lower Market."
    Creators: Jane Ellen Millar
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
    Modifications: modified OSM Location of the Garden and Pool Complex (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Garni temple
    The Garni Temple dates to the first century A.D. and was sacred to the Armenian sun god Mihr.
    Creators: Perry Scalfano
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Garni; created name "Garni"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Garšana
    A Babylonian town mentioned in a collection of 1500 unprovenienced tablets. It is possibly to be identified with the archaeological site of Tall Baridiyah.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: -unlocated; summary; created CIGS location of Tall Baridiyah; created name "Tall Baridiyah"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Garumna (river)
    The Garonne is a river of southwestern Gaul and northern Iberia.

  • Gasr Banat

  • Gasr Doga
    The mausoleum of Gasr Doga is a monumental, elite Libico-Punic tomb built in the Tarhuna area.

    Modifications: update references

  • Gavar
    Refounded by Armenian refugees in the 19th century and renamed first Nor Bayаzet and then Kamo (1959-1995), the modern Armenian city of Gavar can trace occupation back to the Bronze Age.
    Creators: David Braund
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; Diane Braund; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; added Wikipedia reference; title; summary; added Wikidata; created OSM Location of modern Gavar; created CIGS location of Gavaṛ; created name "Gavaṛ"; created name "Kamo"; created name "Nor Bayаzet"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Gazandži (Kazana)
    Gazandži is a village at the Turkish-Armenian border location south of Armavir, on the right bank of the river Arasse, approximately 9 km northeast of Iğdir. Here a cylindrical stone with a building inscription of the Urartian king Argišti I., son of Minua (8th century BCE) was found.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Kazancı
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker
  • Gazara
    Gazara is a fortified ancient city dating to the early second millennium BCE.
    Creators: B. Isaac
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Gelati Monastery
    The Monastery of Gelati was founded in 1106 in western Georgia. It was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1984.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker

  • Germania Inferior
    Germania Inferior was a province of the Roman empire located on the west bank of the Rhine river. It was established as a province ca. AD 80.
    Creators: A.S. Esmonde-Cleary; C.M. Wells; J.F. Drinkwater; J.J. Wilkes; R.C. Knapp; R.S. Bagnall; S. Mitchell; S.T. Parker; W.V. Harris

  • Gherla
    Gherla is a Roman fort or castrum located in Dacia. Epigraphic evidence suggests a foundation date ca. 143 CE. The site came to be abandoned in the third century.
    Creators: J.J. Wilkes
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Ghuzza
    A multi-period complex in Egypt's eastern desert comprising a fort, settlement(s?), and production areas for gold-washing of quartz collected from the wadi alluvium. Most visible structures date to the Ptolemaic and Roman periods, but there is evidence for earlier activity during the New Kingdom period.
    Creators: S.E. Sidebotham
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added Crépy 2023; cleaned up references
    Actors: Tom Elliott

  • Giricano
    Modern Giricano, site of the ancient Dunnu-ša-Uzībiis, is located in the Upper Tigris region of south-eastern Turkey, in the province of Diyarbakir, about 11 km southeast of modern Bismil, ca. 5 km northwest of Ziyaret Tepe, on the north bank of the Tigris River.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg

  • Glaukos/Telmessicus Sinus

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Gleieh
    Gleieh (also Gleiʾeh, Glaiʿā) is small site in the middle Euphrates region and was part of the kingdom of Suhu. The city, which is probably to be identified with ancient Kār-Apladad, was situated on the south bank of the Euphrates, opposite Sur Jureh (which lies on the northern bank). Like many towns and cities of the ancient kingdom of Suhu, Gleieh/Kār-Apladad is now underwater; the area was flooded after the construction of the Haditha dam.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Glay‘a; created name "Glay‘a"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Gleyzia d'Augreilh

  • Gonur Tepe
    A city in the Murghab River delta inhabited in the third-second millennia BCE. Gonur Tepe is located ca. 60 km north of Mary, Turkmenistan.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg

  • Gorditanum Pr.
    A cape located at the northwest corner of the island of Sardinia. Modern Capo Falcone
    Creators: S.L. Dyson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update; modified OSM location of Capo Falcone (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Gövelek
    Gövelek is a village situated 27 km to the east of Van in the southeast of Turkey. Here the upper part of a stela with an inscription of Rusa, son of Erimena (presumably last quarter of 8th century BCE) was found. It reports his military success and describes deportations from the city Ṭušpa, the building of the city Rusaḫinili, and the creation of an artificial lake called "Lake of Rusa". The lake was supposed to ensure the water supply for the capital Ṭušpa (modern Van Kalesi), a function it still performs today. The lower part of the stela has been found at the shore of the lake.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: cleaned up references; added Grekyan 2004; created GICS location of Gövelek; modified OSM Location of modern Gövelek (representative)
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Graeco-Roman theater at Oinoanda
    The theater at Oinoanda is believed to date from the second century B.C. It sits on the northern fringe of the city.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Graeco-Roman theater (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

  • Greppe S. Angelo necropolis
    A rock-cut necropolis of Caere that is noted as the findspot of the Sarpedon krater of the artist Euphronios.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker

  • Grottacce
    At Grottacce are the remains of a Roman seaside villa or villa maritima.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Villa romana alle Grottacce (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Grotta Oscura
    The quarries at Grotta Oscura were an important source of high-quality tuff located in the territory of Veii. This was the "tuffo giallo della via Tiberina" that was used at Rome from the Archaic period onward.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Grottarossa
    Grottarossa is located at the intersection of key roadways in northern suburbium of Rome, lying along the Via Flaminia as well as at the point where the Via Veientana separated from the Via Cassia and thereby connected Rome with Veii. There is archaeological evidence for tombs, both built tombs and rock-cut tombs in the exposed tuff escarpments, as well as villas.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Area archeologica di Grottarossa (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Grotta Scaloria
    A cavern discovered in 1931 near Manfredonia with evidence for ritual activity dating to the Neolithic period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Grotta Scaloria (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Grylios (river)
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 D3 Grylios fl.

  • Gryneion
    An ancient coastal city of Aeolis where an oracle of Apollo was located. It was located near the modern Turkish village of Yenişakran (İzmir Province) and the small cape known as Termaşalık Burnu.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • *Gunela?

    Creators: R.B. Hitchner

  • Gurza
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 33 G1 Gurza
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: ItMiller; update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Guzana Archive 1
    Approximately 85 clay tablets were discovered in the eastern room of a house adjoining the tarrace of the northeastern palace of Guzana. The texts were found in a secondary context, probably as fill, and belonged to Mannu-ki-Aššur, Assyrian governor in Guzana during the first quarter of the 8th century BC. The archive consists of letters to and from the governor, as well as administrative lists concerning persons, animals, and objects.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
    Modifications: added ORACC reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • Guzana Archive 2
    Inside a clay pot, found in a private house east of the citadel gate of Guzana, excavators discovered the private archive of a man with an Aramaic name, Il-manani, dating to the last years of the Assyrian Empire. The archive consists of five Aramaic dockets concerning loans of barley, previously attached to perishable material, and five clay tablets written in Assyrian cuneiform, specifically three loan documents, one purchase document concerning a slave, and one legal settlement.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
    Modifications: added ORACC reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • Guzana (Tell Halaf)
    An Aramaean principality founded on the site of an extinct Neolithic settlement. Settled through Hellenistic times, it was abandoned at the end of the first century BCE.
    Creators: M. Roaf; S.E. Kroll; St J. Simpson; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; R. Talbert; W. Röllig

    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Gyth(e)ion
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 58 D4 Gyth(e)ion
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; Eliza Gettel; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Habıbuşağı (İzoli)
    Habıbuşağı (İzoli) was an Urartian fortress situated near Kömürhan, at the left shore of the river Euphrates in the Elazığ Province of eastern Turkey. Today it is covered by the reservoir behind the Karakaya dam. Habıbuşağı is best known on account of a rock inscription of the Urartian king Sarduri II, son of Argišti (eighth century BCE) which reports the expedition of Sarduri to this region. Habıbuşağı is, in fact, the westernmost known fortress of the Urartian kingdom.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Habıbuşağı; created name "Habıbuşağı"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Hadrianopolis
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 54 B2 Hadrianopolis

    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Hadrianou Hormos
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 45 H4 Hadrianou Hormos

    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Hadrianoutherai
    Located in Mysia, Hadrianoutherai was established by the Roman emperor Hadrian.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Jeffrey Becker; Jordy Didier Orellana Figueroa; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; R. Talbert; W. Röllig
    Modifications: edited; references, summary; update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Hadrumetum/Iustinianopolis
    Hadrumetum/Iustinianopolis was an important ancient port in North Africa. Founded by Phoenicians, the site pre-dated Carthage. Under Roman administration the site prospered and Trajan assigned it colonial status as Colonia Concordia Ulpia Trajana Augusta Frugifera Hadrumetina.
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Javier Martínez Jiménez; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Hagno (spring)
    A spring on Mount Lykaion, mentioned by Pausanias and associated in his narrative with the sanctuary of Zeus Lykaios. The exact location of the spring is uncertain today.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Dan Diffendale; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add manto 10214854: Spring Hagno (Arcadia); update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Hagnous
    Hagnous was a deme of Attica adjacent to the demoi Pallene and Gargettus.
    Creators: J.S. Traill
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add Plutarch; add manto 10764695: Hagnous (Attica)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Halaesa
    Halaesa is located on the north coast of Sicily between between Kalakta and Kephaloidion. The city was founded in 403 B.C. by Archonides of Herbita. The city sided with Rome during the First Punic War and was made "libera et immunis". By the Augustan period it had become a municipium.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Jonathan Prag; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created location "OSM Location: Halaesa archaeological site"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Hala Sultan Tekke
    A major Late Bronze Age settlement occupied the site of Hala Sultan Tekke, which later became an important Sufi Islamic shrine associated with Umm Haram.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Noah Kaye; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott

    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Halicarnassus/Halikarnassos
    An ancient city in Caria, now known as Bodrum in Turkey.

  • Halys (river)
    The Kızılırmak river, the ancient Halys River, is a major river of Asia Minor that flows into the Black Sea.
    Creators: David Braund; T. Sinclair

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Hamam (Hamamköy)
    Hamam is a modern Turkish village near Erzurum in the Northeast of Turkey. Here an inscription of the Urartian king Argišti I, son of Minua (eighth century BCE), was found which reports the filling of a grain silo.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Hamamköy; created name "Hamamköy"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Hammam Beni Guecha
    The so-called Hammam Beni Guecha is a ruined Roman spa located just north and east of the modern Algerian village of Chouara Torche (Beni Guecha municipality). The site may be associated with a road station recorded on the Peutinger Map: Fons Carmerata.
    Creators: E.W.B. Fentress
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: provided precise AAA link; place type; summary; added PPCA reference; added imagery location after PPCA; title; add TP reference; created Imagery Location of Hammam Beni Guecha; modified name "Fons Camerata" (name)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Haradu

  • Harmedon (island)
    An ancient island or island group, attested by literary or documentary sources, whose precise location cannot be determined today
    Creators: G. Reger; J. Bennet
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Harran/Carrhae
    A major settlement of Upper Mesopotamia from the Bronze Age onward. The earliest mentions of the site are found in the Ebla tablets (ca. 2300 B.C.). Notably the location of the Battle of Carrhae between the Roman Republic and Parthian Empire in 53 B.C., which proved to be a devastating defeat for the Romans. Modern-day Ḥarrān, Turkey.
    Creators: P.-L. Gatier; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Carolin Johansson; Ingrid Luo; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; M. Ballance; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: title; summary; create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created CIGS location of Harran
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Hattusa
    The Late Bronze Age capital of the Hittite empire (near modern Boğazkale in Turkey). The site was enrolled as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1986.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Max Gander; Néhémie Strupler; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: created OSM location of Hattuşaş; created CIGS location of Boğazkale
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Hebron
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 70 G2 Hebron

    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Helicon (mountain)
    In Greek mythology, Helicon was the site of two springs sacred to the Muses, the Aganippe and the Hippocrene. The mountain is located near the Gulf of Corinth and rises to an elevation of 1,749 meters (5,738 ft).
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created connection "Boeotia"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Heliopolis/Col. Iulia Augusta Felix
    An ancient settlement in Lebanon's Beqaa Valley, named as a UNESCO World Heritage Site because "with its colossal structures, [it] is one of the finest examples of Imperial Roman architecture at its apogee."
    Creators: E.M. Meyers; J.P. Brown
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Gabriel Mckee; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; R. Talbert; W. Röllig

  • Hellespontos (province)
    A Roman province of the 5th-6th century in the diocese of Asiane.
    Creators: J.J. Wilkes; R.S. Bagnall; S. Mitchell; S.T. Parker
    Contributors: Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Brian Z. Lund; M. Joann McDaniel; Mary E. Downs; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title; place type; summary
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Hellespont (strait)
    The Hellespont is a narrow strait of northwestern Turkey that connects the Aegean Sea to Propontis (Sea of Marmara). It is known today as the Dardanelles. Pseudo-Apollodorus records a myth that seems to have been widespread in antiquity: the Hellespont got its name by being the place where Helle, sister of Phrixus, fell off the flying golden ram.
    Creators: E.N. Borza
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Gabriel Bodard; Ingrid Luo; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title; created OSM location of Dardanelles; created connection "Mysia (region)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Hellespontus (province)
    A Roman imperial province.
    Creators: A.S. Esmonde-Cleary; C.M. Wells; J.F. Drinkwater; J.J. Wilkes; R.C. Knapp; R.S. Bagnall; S. Mitchell; S.T. Parker; W.V. Harris

    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Heraclea ad Latmum/Pleistarcheia
    A town of Caria located 25 km west of Miletos on the Ionian coast, Heraclea was located on the lower slopes of Mt. Latmos. Once a part of the Delian League, the city fell to Mausolos in the fourth century B.C. and his philhellene policy accounts for its change of name.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created connection "Caria (region)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Heraclea Minoa
    An ancient Greek city of the south coast of Sicily located at the mouth of the Halykos river. Founded by Selinus in the sixth century BC, the site was abandoned in the first century AD.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Elizabeth Robinson; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; modified OSM location of Heraclea Minoa (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott

  • Heraion (Teichos)
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 52 B2 Heraion (Teichos)
    Creators: C. Foss
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Rob Chavez; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created OSM location of Heraeum
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Herakleion
    An ancient sanctuary of Hercules (Melqart) that Strabo places at one end of the long island (Cotinussa) that extended south from ancient Gades. Significant landscape and coastal change have occurred since antiquity, disrupting the integrity of these islands. Nonetheless, modern scholars have consistently identified the location of the sanctuary as at or near the 17th-18th century Castillio de Sancti Petri, which today occupies a separate homonymous islet. Archaeological finds possibly associated with the sanctuary have been made in the vicinity (both terrestrial and underwater) over the years, but precise location of foundations or other identifiable architecture have remained elusive.
    Creators: F.H. Stanley; Jr.; R.C. Knapp
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Islote de Sancti Petri (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Herakles, T.
    A sanctuary of Herakles located on the island of Lemnos, active from the Archaic period through to the time of the Roman empire.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; edited; edit summary, update references; created ToposText location of Herakles sanct. (Lemnos); modified name "Herakles" (ctype, reference, edited)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Heratemis?/Phratemis?/Phrystimus?

  • Hera temple
    The so-called 'Tavole Palatine' is the site of the ruins of a sixth century B.C. Doric temple sacred to Hera and associated with the city of Metapontum.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Herculis (islands)

    Modifications: add TP reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Herdoniae/Ardaneae/Civitas Serdonis
    Herdonia was an ancient city of Apulia located along the via Minucia. The city was the site of two major engagements of the Second Punic War (212 and 210 B.C., respectively), both of which were Carthaginian victories. The city's extensive remains have been investigated by the Belgian Institute since the Second World War.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Herdonia (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott

  • Hermonthis
    Modern Armant, an important town of the Egyptian Middle Kingdom that was enlarged during the Eighteenth Dynasty and continued to thrive through the Ptolemaic, Roman, and Coptic periods.
    Creators: J. Keenan; S.E. Sidebotham; T. Wilfong
    Contributors: Adam Prins; Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; Herbert Verreth; Jen Thum; Mark Depauw; R. Talbert; jfu

  • Heroonpolis

    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Hierapolis/Pamukkale
    Hierapolis (modern Pamukkale in Turkey's Denizli province) was a major ancient city in Phrygia located at the site of hot springs in southwestern Anatolia. The site was designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1988.
    Creators: C. Foss; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Rob Chavez; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • House M8-A
    Private house preceding the Christian church.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: additional chronological details
    Actors: Anne Chen
  • House of Amor and Psyche
    A domus in Ostia Antica on the Via del Tempio d’Ercole, between the Via della Foce to the south and the Tiber to the north. Installed in late antiquity, and incorporating large parts of a preexisting tenement, this house had a wide central corridor, which opened through an arcade onto a small garden (viridarium) backed by a nymphaeum.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified OSM location of House of Amor and Psyche (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of Augustus
    An elite domus located at the southwest corner of the Palatine Hill that is identified as the house lived in by the Roman emperor Augustus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Casa di Augusto (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of Iphigeneia
    The House of Pinarius Cerialis and Cassia or Casa dell’orefice or Casa di Ifigenia (III, 4, b).
    Creators: Athanasia Varveri
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified OSM location of so-called "Casa di Ifigenia" (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of Julius Polybius
    The House of Julius Polybius (IX 13,1.3) sits on the north side of the Via dell'Abbondanza and dates from the second century BC.
    Creators: Athanasia Varveri
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Casa di Giulio Polibio (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of Marcus Lucretius
    The House of Marcus Lucretius was excavated in 1846 and 1851.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Domus Lucreti (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of the Tragic Poet
    The so-called "House of the Tragic Poet" (VI, 8, 3, 5) was built in the first century BC and has the plan of a classic "Samnite" house. The house was excavated in 1824. It lies at the corner of the Via delle Terme and the Via della Fullonica, across from the Forum Baths.
    Creators: Valeria Vitale
    Contributors: Athanasia Varveri; Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: update deprecated Arachne link; modified OSM location of so-called "Casa del Poeta Tragico" (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of Trebius Valens
    The House of Aulus Trebius Valens (III,2,1) is an atrium-style house in Pompeii that lies on the north side of Via dell'Abbondanza. It was first excavated in 1913.
    Creators: Athanasia Varveri
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified OSM location of so-called "Casa di Trebius Valens" (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Hrazany

  • Hurmizd Ardashir/[Suq al-Ahwaz]

  • Huzirina
    The ancient Huzirina, modern Sultantepe, is a Late Neo-Assyrian archeological site, now in Şanlıurfa Province, Turkey.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Sultantepe Höyüğü (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); created CIGS location of Sultantepe
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker
  • Huzirina Archive 1
    In Huzirina, about 400 clay tablets were discovered in a secondary position outside a private house with a central courtyard in area F. Likely, this library was previously located in the private house since a similar type of clay tablet was also found in the central courtyard. The library dates from 718 BC to the end of the Assyrian Empire and belonged to a family of šangû-priests: Qurdi-Nergal, his son Mušallim-Baba and others. The library consists of incantations, incantation rituals, medical texts, prayers, hymns and lexical lists, including god-lists.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
    Modifications: added ORACC reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • Hybla Heraia
    Hybla Heraia (modern Ragusa) was an indigenous center of ancient Sicily that came into contact with Greek and, later, Roman and Byzantine cultures.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Jonathan Prag; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of the Archaeological Area of Ibla (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)

  • Ikarion Mare
    The Ikarian Sea is the southeastern part of the Aegean Sea, extending from Samos to Mykonos.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger

    Modifications: created connection "Caria (region)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Ikaros (island)
    An island in the Aegean Sea (modern Ikaria), now part of the modern country of Greece. According to Ovid, the island took its name from the burial place of Ikaros, son of Daidalos, whose fantastic flight on wings made by his father ended tragically in the sea nearby.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary; added MANTO reference; removed smith (outdated); cleaned up references; modified OSM location of Ikaria (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Ikos
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 55 F2 Ikos
