  • Mincius (river)
    The Mincio river is a tributary of the Po river.
    Creators: M. Pearce; P. Tozzi
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; created OSM location of Mincio (river course)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Mines at Serabit el-Khadim
    Multi-period mining, principally for turquoise, but also for other minerals, was carried out on the Serabit el-Kahdim plateau in the Sinai (modern Egypt).
    Creators: D.F. Graf
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added Tallet 2023; cleaned up references; created name "Serabit el-Khadim"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Minio (river)
    A river that flows some 62 km from the Monti Sabatini to the Tyrrhenian Sea. The modern Mignone.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add TP ref.
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Minor Acropolis, Norba
    The so-called Minor Acropolis is located on the hill to the south of the Porta Maggiore. This area is surrounded by the urban enclosure wall and is terraced in polygonal masonry. Two platform temples of unknown assignation are to be found here.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Minor Acropolis (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Mirobriga
    A celtiberian and subsequent Roman settlement at modern Ciudad Rodrigo in Salamanca, Spain.
    Creators: E.W. Haley
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Mirobriga
    Miróbriga (also known as Mirobriga Celticorum) is an ancient Roman town located near the village Santiago do Cacém, Portugal. The site shows evidence of Iron Age occupation beginning in the ninth century B.C. and continuing through to the time of the Roman colonization of Lusitania.
    Creators: F.H. Stanley; Jr.; R.C. Knapp
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: created OSM location of Ruinas Romanas de Miróbriga
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Missua
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 32 G3 Missua
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: edited
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 62 unlocated Misylon
    Creators: T. Drew Bear
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Mithraeum at Fertőrákos
    A well-preserved Mithraeum with modern stone vault above ground and site below in Fertőrákos, Hungary, at the site of ancient Scarbantia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Perry Scalfano
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: created OSM location of Mithrász-szentély
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Mithraeum at Vulci
    A mithraeum was discovered at Vulci in 1975 during excavations of a Roman aristocratic house. The shrine was well preserved with two tauroctony scenes dating to the third century. The site was destroyed in the fourth century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
    Modifications: add Arachne Gruppe des stiertötenden Mithras, Vulci
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Mithraeum of Lucretius Menander
    The Mithraeum of Lucretius Menander located in ancient Ostia dates to the third century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: add Melega 2022
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

  • Molì de l’Espigol
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 25 G4 Molì de l’Espigol
    Creators: H.S. Sivan; R.W. Mathisen; S.J. Keay
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Poblado íbero del Molino de Espigol (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Molino San Vincenzo
    Field survey, geophysical prospection, as well as targeted research and training excavations, have revealed the remains of a mid- to late imperial rural settlement with evidence for agricultural activity. However, the earliest finds (e.g. bucchero) date to the sixth/fifth century B.C., indicating the likelihood of Etruscan settlement activities at this site. The entire site seems to have undergone severe recycling and reuse processes in late antiquity and the remaining structures have broken down systematically in modern times. Ongoing intensive agricultural activities affect the few archaeological structures that remain, resulting in a poor state of preservation.
    Creators: Dominik Hagmann
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Günther Schörner
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Molino San Vincenzo (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Molpa
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 46 B1 Molpa
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Archaeological site of Molpa (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Moltone, S. Pietro
    San Pietro di Tolve Roman villa.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Piana San Pietro, Tolve (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Monte Adranone (Adranon?)
    An indigenous center of the eighth to fourth centuries B.C. that became Hellenized, Monte Adranone in Sicily is probably to be identified with the ancient name Adranon.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Jonathan Prag; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; title; summary; modified OSM location of Area archeologica di Monte Adranone (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Monte Annamunna
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 E2 Monte Annamunna
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Monte Bernorio
    Monte Bernorio is the site of a fortified Cantabrian settlement covering more than 120 hectares.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: added Torres-Martínez 2012; settlement (fortified); cleaned up references
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Monte Chibbò
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 47 D3 Monte Chibbò
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Monte del Grano
    Monte del Grano is a popular name that was assigned to a mausoleum once thought to belong to Alexander Severus, although that assignation is no longer supported. The archaeological remains are now part of the Parco XVII Aprile 1944.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created OSM location of Mausoleo del Monte del Grano
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Monte Gibel Gabel
    An archaeological site located ca. 5 km south of Caltanissetta, Sicily, situated on a 615-meter high mountain plateau. Excavations during the twentieth century under Dinu Adameșteanu revealed evidence for the Bronze Age Castelluccio culture, with indigenous occupation continuing until at least the sixth century B.C.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location Gibil Gabib (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Monte Mozinho
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 24 C3 Monte Mozinho
    Creators: E.W. Haley
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created name "Castro of Monte Mozinho"; created connection "Conventus Bracaraugustanus"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Monte Pruno
    A settlement of the Oenotrians and the Lucani dating to the seventh through third centuries B.C. Its ancient name is unknown.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary; cleaned up Greco 1996 reference; added Ferrara 2015, Greco 2019, and Greco 2020; created location "OSM Location: Parco archeologico Monte Pruno"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Monte Sannace
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 45 E3 Monte Sannace
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Parco archeologico Monte Sannace (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Monte Saraceno di Ravanusa (Kakyron?)
    The ancient city of Kakyron, said to have been founded by the Sicani in the eighth century B.C., is probably to be identified with the remains of a fortified city, north of Licata, located on the western side of Sicily.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Jonathan Prag; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title; summary; modified OSM location of Monte Saraceno di Ravanusa, archaeological area (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Montesei di Serso
    A hilltop settlement with a long-term habitation, stretching from ca. 2000 BC to the first century BC. The archaeological site preserves the remains of 4+ mid-first millennium BC dwellings.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Francesca Cotugno
    Modifications: edited; modified location "Area archeologica Montesei di Serso" (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance); created OSM location of Montesei di Serso
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Monteverde
    The eleventh century monastery of Santa Maria di Monteverde sits atop and reuses elements of Roman and pre-Roman settlements on the hilltop.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; modified OSM location of Santa Maria di Monteverde (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, 11C, church)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Monumental Mid-Republican Building Complex
    This monumental complex of buildings at the city of Gabii was likely constructed in the mid-third century BCE as a public area for feasts, bathing, and ritual activities.
    Creators: AJ Adler; Shannon Well-Moran
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott; Thomas Landvatter; Shannon Wells-Moran
    Modifications: added Optiz 2016
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Monumentum Regiae Gentis
    Monumentum Regiae Gentis (the Mausoleum of Juba and Cleopatra Selene) was built ca. 3 BC by Juba II, the last king of Numidia.
    Creators: T.W. Potter
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: edited; created location "OSM location: Royal Mausoleum of Mauretania"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Mopsou(h)estia/Seleukeia pros to Pyramo
    Mopsou(h)estia/Seleukeia pros to Pyramo was an ancient settlement in Cilicia Pedias (now modern Yakapınar, Turkey).
    Creators: P.-L. Gatier; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Gabriel Bodard; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Phoebe Acheson; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale; DARMC; M. Ballance; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: modified OSM Location of archaeological site of Misis (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Moregine
    Moregine, immediately to the south of the archaeological site of Pompeii, is the findspot of an important archaeological assemblage buried by seismic activity that preceded that final eruption of Vesuvius in A.D. 79.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of modern hamlet of Moregine (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Morgantina, House of Ganymede
    The House of Ganymede at Morgantina is a peristyle house with mosaic floor pavements. The earliest phase of the house belongs to the third century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of House of Ganymede (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Moridunum
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 8 unlocated Moridunum
    Creators: A.S. Esmonde Cleary
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: created connection "Untitled"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Morsott
    The modern Algerian settlement of Morsott is possibly to be identified with ancient Vasampus, attested in the Peutinger map.
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: title; summary; create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; update reference; created OSM location of Morsott; created name "Morsott"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Moscha Limen
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 4 unlocated Moscha Limen
    Creators: D.T. Potts
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: edited; modified name "Moscha Limen" (Initial revision)
    Actors: Gabriel McKee
  • Motya
    A small island in the Stagnone Lagoon of western Sicily, Motya has evidence for quite ancient settlement, including a significant Punic phase. The settlement on the island was destroyed by Syracuse in 379 BC. At one point the island was connected to the mainland via a causeway.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Jonathan Prag; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added Peripoli 2023
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Mouchthousioi/Muctuniana Manus
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 35 unlocated Mouchthousioi/Muctuniana Manus
    Creators: D.J. Mattingly
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: Février 1996; update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Mount Judi
    Mount Judi (also al-Ǧūdiyy, Cûdî‎, Cudi), also spelled Guti and Kutu, is a mountain where Sennacherib had several monuments carved. The Neo-Assyrian name is Mount Nipur.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Cudi Dağı
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Mousti Kome
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 35 unlocated Mousti Kome
    Creators: D.J. Mattingly
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Mugilla
    Mugilla was an ancient oppidum of Latium, located at Corioli. The gens Papiria is associated with the site. Its precise location is now unknown.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add wikidata reference; update references; created name "Mogillanous"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Mura dell Arce
    The so-called "Mura dell Arce" of Vetulonia served as the sixth- and fifth-century B.C. fortifications of Etruscan Vetulonia. These are massive walls built in megalithic technique using limestone.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: references; modified OSM location of Mura dell Arce (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Mura di S. Stefano
    A second century A.D. Roman villa built atop an earlier villa rustica.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Villa romana delle Mura di Santo Stefano (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Mura Greche
    The so-called "Mura Greche" are remains of the later third century B.C. fortifications of Neapolis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of mura Greche (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Muro Maurizio
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 45 G3 Muro Maurizio
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Muro Tenente (Scamnum?)
    Scamnum is a road station located in Messapia that is mentioned on the Tabula Peutingeriana. It is perhaps to be identified with excavations at the site of Muro Tenente that have revealed long term occupation levels, beginning from the Neolithic period.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title; summary; modified OSM location of archaeological area of Muro Tenente (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Mursia
    A modern village on the northwest coast of the Mediterranean island of Pantelleria. Mursia lies atop a settlement of late Bronze Age date that is associated with the cemetery (Sesi) that lies immediately to its south.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
    Modifications: added Peinetti 2023
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Muslubium
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 31 C3 Muslubium

  • Mysia II (province)
    According to Hierokles, a province of the later Roman empire administratively included in the diocese of Thrakike.
    Creators: J.J. Wilkes; R.S. Bagnall; S. Mitchell; S.T. Parker
    Contributors: Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Brian Z. Lund; M. Joann McDaniel; Mary E. Downs; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Mysia I (province)
    According to Hierokles, a province of the later Roman empire administratively included in the diocese of Illyrikon.
    Creators: J.J. Wilkes; R.S. Bagnall; S. Mitchell; S.T. Parker
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Brian Z. Lund; M. Joann McDaniel; Mary E. Downs; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Mysia (region)
    A region of northwestern Asia Minor that ancient sources associate with the Mysi, a people who had migrated there from Thrace, probably late in the second millennium BCE. Sources vary on the extent and subdivisions of the region, but in general it seems to have been at least roughly bounded on the north by the Hellespont and Propontis, on the east by the Rhyndacus river (modern Mustafakemalpaşa) and mount Olympus (Ulu Dağ), and on the west either by the Aisepos river (Gönen Çayı) or (if the Troad is taken to be part of Mysia) the Aegean Sea.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; Richard Talbert
    Modifications: summary; cleaned up references
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Mysia (region in Bythinia)
    According to some ancient authors, the Mysi (a Thracian people who migrated into Asia Minor) originally inhabited Bithynia before moving further south and west, whence this regional name that the Barrington Atlas places between the Askania Limne (modern Lake Iznik in Turkey) and the Propontis.
    Creators: C. Foss
    Contributors: Edward Keogh; Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; Richard Talbert
    Modifications: added Connection; title; summary; added New Pauly reference; created BAtlas Map Label Location; created connection "Mysia (region)"
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Mysia (settlement)
    An ancient settlement in the Argolid, mentioned by Pausanias, who highlights there a sanctuary of Demeter. This settlement is probably to be identified with the modern Phyktia.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Mzetamze
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 88 B3 Mzetamze

    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Nabulu
    A town mentioned in Neo-Assyrian sources that is now identified as modern Girnavaz Höyük. Nabulu was a Late Bronze Age and an Iron Age settlement located north of Nusaybin.
    Creators: Claudia Horst
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Girnavaz
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Nages Roman Bridge
    An unnamed Roman bridge over the modern river Rhôny. It is located in the modern Nages-et-Solorgues commune in France's Gard department.
    Creators: S. Loseby

  • Nahr al-Kalb monuments
    Over twenty rock reliefs (with accompanying inscriptions) are carved into the limestone cliffs around the estuary of the Nahr al-Kalb river.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny

    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Najafabad
    Najafabad (Persian: نجف‌آباد‎) is a city in Iran and the capital of Najafabad, Isfahan Province. The discovery of a stele of the Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721-705 BC) indicates that the settlement’s ancient name, at least in the eighth century BC, might have been Kišesim.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Najafābād; created OSM location of نجف‌آباد

  • Nasium

  • Neaethus (river)
    A river of Bruttium (modern Neto in Italy) mentioned in various sources. It is identified in the epitome of Apollodorus as the location where the Trojan women burned the Trojan ships after arriving in Italy.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert

  • Neapolis

  • Neapolis
    After the sacking of Jerusalem, Vespasian settled Roman veterans on a new town site located between Mt. Gerizim and Mt. Ebal. The new Roman colony was built on the site of Mabartha.
    Creators: E.M. Meyers; J.P. Brown
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

    Actors: Noah Kaye; Tom Elliott
  • Neapolis (Kavalla)
    An ancient port city on the coast of Thrace, Neapolis (modern Kavalla in the Decentralized Administration of Macedonia and Thrace in Greece) was probably founded from Thasos in the seventh century CE. It served as the port for Philippi in Hellenistic and Roman times, and was refortified by Justinian in the sixth century CE.
    Creators: E.N. Borza
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title; added Malamidou 2023; summary
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Necropoli di San Placido

  • Necropolis of Campovalano
    A Picene necropolis located near Campovalano (Campli) in the province of Teramo. While more than 600 tombs were identified, there may have been as many as 20,000 originally.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
    Modifications: modified OSM location of La necropoli di Campovalano (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)

  • Negrenenses Maiores/Ad Maiores

  • Nennig
    The site of a Roman villa some 40 km upstream on the Moselle from Trier. The site was discovered in 1852 and was excavated between 1866 and 1876.

  • Nicomedia
    Nicomedia was founded in 712/11 BC as a Megarian colony named Astacus and was rebuilt by Nicomedes I of Bithynia in 264 BC. The city was an important administrative center of the Roman Empire.
    Creators: C. Foss
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; R. Talbert; W. Röllig

  • Nilus (river)
    The Nile is a major river of northeastern Africa and is generally acknowledged as the longest river in the world, measuring some 6,650 km (4,130 miles) from source to mouth.
    Creators: A. Bernand
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; H. Kopp; R. Talbert; W. Röllig
    Modifications: added MANTO reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Nimrud
    In the ninth century BC, Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883-859 BC) built himself a new administrative center. Kalhu (biblical Calah) — modern Nimrud, a site identified as Larissa, a city mentioned in Xenophon’s Anabasis — became the capital of the Assyrian Empire, replacing Ashur, which had served as Assyria’s capital since the third millennium BC. The city — which is located twenty miles south of the modern Mosul and which occupied a strategic position six miles north of the point where the Tigris River meets the Greater/Upper Zab — served as Assyria’s capital until the reign of Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC). Although Kalhu never again became the primary residence of Assyria’s kings, that city remained a vital administrative, military, and religious center until the fall of the Assyrian Empire.
    Creators: M. Roaf; St J. Simpson
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; R. Talbert; W. Röllig
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Nimrūd; created name "Nimrūd"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker
  • Nina
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 93 C2 Nina
    Creators: A. Hausleiter; M. Roaf; R. Wenke; St J. Simpson
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; P. Flensted Jensen; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; add references x 2; update references; created CIGS location of Ishān Zurghul; created OSM location of Tell Zurghul; created name "Ishān Zurghul"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Nineveh Archive 1
    The Palace of Sennacherib (South-Palace Palace) at Nineveh remained in use until the Assyrian capital was captured, looted, and destroyed in 612 BC. Numerous tablets discovered in Rooms XL and XLI, as well as in some of the adjoining rooms, nineteenth-century British excavators unearthed the remains of a library, including many clay tablets inscribed with literary texts. During the reign of Ashurbanipal (r. 668–ca. 631 BC), the last great king of Assyria, the tablets found in this archive repository were probably part of his tablet collection.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: added ORACC reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • Nineveh Archive 2
    In the Palace of Sennacherib (South-West Palace) at Nineveh, in Room LXI, nineteenth-century British excavators discovered about 450 clay bullae. Most of these had seal impressions on one side and indications on their backsides that they were fastened with rope to perishable materials (for example, papyrus and leather). These bullae are probably the remains of an archive of Aramaic documents.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny
    Modifications: added ORACC reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • Nineveh Archive 3
    In the Palace of Sennacherib (South-West Palace) at Nineveh, in Room LIV, nineteenth-century British excavators found the remains of an archive consisting of cuneiform tablets, some of which also included summary notes in Aramaic.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jamie Novotny
    Modifications: added ORACC reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • Nineveh Archive 4
    In the Palace of Ashurbanipal (North Palace), in Room C, nineteenth-century British excavators unearthed the remains of an archive of clay tablets. This find yielded records for military officers and possibly literary texts (although this has yet to be conclusively proven).
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny
    Modifications: added ORACC reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • Nineveh Archive 5
    In the Palace of Ashurbanipal (North Palace), in the southwest corner nineteenth-century British excavators unearthed the remains of a library, including many clay tablets inscribed with literary texts. During the reign of Ashurbanipal (r. 668–ca. 631 BC), the last great king of Assyria, the tablets found in this archive repository were probably part of his tablet collection. Because these tablets were excavated very close to the Nabû temple (Ezida), which also had its own archival repository, some of the tablets thought to have come from the so-called “Library of Ashurbanipal” might have actually belonged to the neighboring Nabû temple. Today, the North Palace library material is not clearly differentiated from that of Ezida, due to the fact that the excavators did not provide detailed information about the exact findspots of the tablets.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
    Modifications: added ORACC reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • Nineveh Archive 6
    A clay pot with about thirty clay tablets was found to the north of the Šamaš Gate at Nineveh, in a secondary context. The archive, whose texts are dated between 669 BC and the fall of Nineveh (612 BC), belonged to Ninurta-šarru-uṣur (“the son of the palace”), as well as to several other people, including some Egyptians. This small archive consists of loan and purchase documents, legal texts, as well as a piece of correspondence.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jamie Novotny; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: added ORACC reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • Nineveh/Ninos
    This important Mesopotamian city flanks the eastern edge of the Tigris flood plain, opposite modern Mosul, of which it is now a suburb. From the third millennium B.C. onwards, Nineveh was the most important religious center of the goddess Ištar in the area that would become the Assyrian heartland. Starting in the Middle Assyrian period, the city came under the authority of the kings of Assyria, who often sponsored large-scale building activities there. However, it was not until 704 B.C. that Nineveh became the administrative capital of Assyria, when the Neo-Assyrian king Sennacherib moved the royal family and court there and transformed the city into a thriving imperial metropolis. Nineveh remained Assyria’s capital until 612 B.C., when it was captured and destroyed by a Babylonian-Median collation led by Nabopolassar and Cyaxares. The visible remains of the (7th-century) Assyrian city include the citadel mound Kuyunjik, the smaller mound of Nebi Yunus, and the twelve-kilometer-long city wall.
    Creators: M. Roaf; S.E. Kroll; St J. Simpson; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Carolin Johansson; Francis Deblauwe; Gabriel Bodard; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add TGN 7017998: Nineveh (deserted settlement); created CIGS location of Nīnūa
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker
  • Nippur/Nufar/‘Hippareni’
    An ancient Sumerian settlement whose ruins lie at Nuffar in modern Iraq. Under various names it persisted as a settlement throughout the periods of Greek and Roman engagement in Babylonia.
    Creators: A. Hausleiter; M. Roaf; R. Wenke; St J. Simpson
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg; Sebastian Heath; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; P. Flensted Jensen; R. Talbert; W. Röllig
    Modifications: update references; created OSM location of Nippur; modified CIGS location of Nufar (update references); created CIGS location of Nufar; created name "Nufar"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Nirabu
    A town mentioned in Neo-Assyrian sources. Nīrabu is equated with Aramaic nrb, classical Nērabos, and modern Nayrab.
    Creators: Claudia Horst
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: update references; created CIGS location of Naiyrab; modified name "Nayrab" (change name type -> associated modern name); created name "Naiyrab"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Nitriai
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 74 C3 Nitriai
    Creators: A. Bernand
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference

  • Nitriai
    An ancient people, tribe, or cultural group. Located: Wadi Natrun.

  • Nitriansky Hrádok
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 13 D4 Nitriansky Hrádok
    Creators: A. Bursche; L.F. Pitts
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; E. Krekovič; P. Kaczanowski; R. Madyda‑Legutko; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Nomentum
    The Latin town of Nomentum and Rome were linked by means of the Via Nomentana. In Livy's history the town, a member of the Latin League, is captured by Lucius Tarquinius Priscus. Nomentum was one of a number of towns captured by Tarquinius. The Romans granted the town civitas sine suffragio after 338 B.C.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: edited; add TGN 7006979: Mentana (inhabited place); created name "Nomentani"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Nopigeia
    Remnants of an ancient settlement have been identified south and east of the modern beach village of Nopigeia on Crete that date to at least the 5th century BCE. The church of Agios Georgios Nopigion, which is located between Nopigia and Drapania, was built on the remains of a Roman-era bath complex. A single, late source (Aelian) provides the name Mithymna, which may have belonged to this settlement. Bronze Age remains have also been identified in the vicinity.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. Bennet
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary; edited; modern Names; place += bath; title; cleaned up references; added Chronique toponym reference; create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created OSM location of Mithimna; created name "Nopigia"; created name "Nopigeia"; created name "Drapanias"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Nora
    A pre-Roman and Roman site in southern Sardinia.
    Creators: S.L. Dyson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Elizabeth Robinson; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; modified OSM location of Nora archaeological area (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Norba
    Norba, located in the Monti Lepini, was a member of the Latin League (ca. 499 B.C.) and became a Latin colony ca. 492 B.C. The city was destroyed in the early first century B.C.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Adam Rabinowitz; Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update arachne references; modified OSM location of Norba latina (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Normandykes Roman Camp (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • North Leigh
    North Leigh Roman villa is a large villa complex located near the River Evenlode. This was a luxurious villa with four bathing suites.
    Creators: A.S. Esmonde Cleary
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner

  • Oenoanda bridge
    An Ottoman bridge at Oinoanda on the Xanthos river. A Latin inscription found nearby suggests an earlier Roman bridge existed at the site.

  • Oescus

  • Oeta M.
    A mountain range of southern Phthiotis and northern Phocis in Greece, Oeta is celebrated in mythology as the site of Herakles' death.

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Okehampton Roman fort and fortlet
    A Roman fort and a series of five associated enclosures situated on a hilltop overlooking the valley of the River Okement to the northwest and Okehampton town to the southwest. Excavations suggest that the site was occupied ca. A.D. 50-80.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: update references; modified OSM location of modern Okehampton (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Old Kandahar citadel
    Tradition holds that the Iron Age and Achaemenid citadel of Old Kandahar was re-established during the time of Alexander the Great. It functioned as a local seat of power for at least two millennia.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified CIGS location of Old Kandahar citadel (Standardized title, Baseline created); created OSM location of Old Kandahar
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker

  • Olenia Petra
    An ancient mountain or outcrop in Elis mentioned by Homer, Pausanias, and others. Strabo tentatively identifies it with mount Skollis (modern Santomeri).
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II

  • Olympos (mountain in Greece)
    Olympus is the highest mountain in Greece, located in the Olympus Range. In Greek mythology, it is the home of the Olympian gods.

  • Opitergium

  • Oplontis
    An ancient place (modern Torre Annunziata in Italy), lying between Pompeii and Herculaneum and buried by the eruption of Vesuvius in 79 CE. Its ancient name is known only from Peutinger's Roman Map.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Orchomenos/Orchomenus
    The so-called "Boeotian Orchomenos", located in the vicinity of the Byzantine church of Panaghia Skripou. The longer, modern title is used to distinguish this settlement from another Greek site with the same ancient name located in Arcadia in the Peloponnese.
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Joshua Sosin; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified connection "Boeotia" (New Pauly reference, located in)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Oreine (island)

    Creators: D.T. Potts

    Modifications: update references; modified OSM location of modern Dessie (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Orraon/Horreum
    Orraon was a city of the Molossians, founded probably in the early fourth century BCE and planned on a grid system. It may have been destroyed by the Romans after Pydna in 168 BCE, and its inhabitants were removed to Nikopolis in 31 BCE. The site is remarkable for the preservation of its stone-built domestic architecture.
    Creators: W.M. Murray
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Dan Diffendale; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; update references; created OSM location of Όρραον; modified name "Orraon" (add SEG reference, Baseline created); modified name "Horreum" (Baseline created, Latin name, Livy ref. added)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Ossaia

  • Ouiriballon Akron
    A promontory of northwest Corsica that extends westward and is capped by the Île de Gargalo. It is bounded on the south by the Golfe de Girolata and on the north by the Golfe d'Elbo. Today, the entire promontory is set aside as the Réserve Naturelle de Scandola (a UNESCO Natural World Heritage Site).
    Creators: S.L. Dyson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: Jehasse 1976; updated Connections, Locations; edited; Initial revision; created OSM location
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Paktyes (mountain)
    A a spur of the Messogis mountain range lying to the east of Ephesos, elevation 305–1,524 m.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Michael Heubel; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; Richard Talbert
    Modifications: update references; created connection "Mes(s)ogis M."
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Palace of Tupkish
    Palace at the Hurrian city Urkesh, constructed by Tupkish in the late third millennium BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of the Palace of Tupkish (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Palaiokhori
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 58 H4 Palaiokhori
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: Renfrew 1982
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Palaio Pretorio
    The ruins of a colonnaded structure in marble, perhaps a temple; a well / cistern is also observed by Sealy.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add topostext
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Palatinus Mons
    The central hill of Rome, Italy. Legend held that Romulus founded the city of Rome on the Palatine.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: edited; add Panella et al. 2021; modified OSM location of Palatine Hill (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • *Pallanum
    An ancient settlement of the Frentani located on Monte Pallano.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Palmyra
    An ancient oasis and trading city with monumental remains, located in modern Syria. Under Zenobia, Palmyra was the capital of the breakaway Palmyrene Empire, leading to Aurelian's razing of the city. Inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1980.
    Creators: J.P. Brown; P.-L. Gatier
    Contributors: Adam Prins; Brady Kiesling; Carolin Johansson; David Michelson; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Gabriel Bodard; Ingrid Luo; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Thomas Carlson; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; R. Talbert; R. Warner; W. Röllig
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Tadmur
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Palmyrene Gate
    Main entrance gate in the western city walls of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified Plan location of Palmyrene Gate (updated precision of tower corners according to georeferenced plan from James 2019 fig. 8.22)
    Actors: Anne Chen
  • Paludes Minturnenses
    The Marshes of Mintumae were located near the mouth of the river Liris.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: Musacchio 2022; created connection "Liris/Clanis (river)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • [Pambotis L.]
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 54 C2 [Pambotis L.]
    Creators: W.M. Murray
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; created OSM location of Pamvotida Lake
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Panagia Angeloktistos
    The church of Panagia tis Angeloktistis or Panagia Angeloktisti is a Byzantine church located in the village of Kiti, Cyprus. Its origins lies in the fifth and sixth centuries. It was listed as a tentative UNESCO World Heritage site in 2015.
    Creators: D. Rupp
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; summary, references; created OSM location of Panagia tis Angeloktistis; created connection "Cyprus (island)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Panaztepe
    A mound site located approximately 35 km northwest of modern Izmir, Turkey, with signs of habitation from the 3rd millennium BCE through the early Iron Age.
    Creators: Clifflena Tiah
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Panaztepe (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pandion

  • Panionion
    Located near Mt. Mycale, the Panionion was an Ionian sanctuary dedicated to Poseidon Helikonios that served as the meeting place of the Ionian League.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; update references; modified name "Panionion" (Baseline created, added Greek name, Paus. reference)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Panormos (settlement, port)
    An ancient settlement presumed to have been co-located with a harbor (limen) mentioned by Pausanias as lying 15 stadia east of the Rhion Pr. (modern Rio in Greece), on the north coast of the Peloponnese.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; modified name "Panormos" (Greek name, reference, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Parco delle Tombe di via Latina
    A cluster of Roman Imperial tombs along the Via Latina excavated in the nineteenth century.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Parco delle Tombe di via Latina (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)

  • Parthenion (mountain)
    A mountain of the Peloponnese that lies to the northwest of ancient Tegea and between the modern villages of Partheni and Elaiochori.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference; cleaned up references
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Parthenope/Neapolis
    Founded as Parthenope by Greeks in the eighth century B.C., the site eventually gave rise to Neapolis in the sixth century B.C. and was one of the most prominent cities of Magna Graecia. Modern-day Naples, Italy.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Ingrid Luo; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; David Mimno; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: MANTO 9721323: Naples (Italy)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pasargadae/Batrakatash
    Pasargadae/Batrakatash was an ancient Persian city and the capital of Cyrus the Great (559–530 BC). It remained the capital until Cambyses II moved it to Susa. The site is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
    Creators: A. Hausleiter; M. Roaf; R. Wenke
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Carolin Johansson; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; P. Flensted Jensen; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of archaeological site of Pasargadae/Batrakatash (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); created CIGS location of Pasargad; created name "Pasargad"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker
  • Passalae/Passadai/Passyadrae/Pazalai
    An ancient people whose territory is unlocated
    Creators: M.U. Erdosy
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: edited; update references; modified name "Passalae" (update reference)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Patibīri
    A town mentioned in Neo-Assyrian sources; an alternate name is Bad-tibira; the modern site is Tel Madain.
    Creators: Claudia Horst
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Bad-Tibira (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Patra(e)
    Patra(e) (modern Patras) is an important ancient center with settlement beginning in the Late Helladic period. Patras played a leading role in the foundation of the second "Achaean League" and was the site of a Roman colony after 146 BC.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add manto reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pausilipum
    Pausilipum was an ancient Graeco-Roman settlement on the Bay of Naples.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: added Busen 2023
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Pedonianis
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 22 B5 Pedonianis
    Creators: A.G. Poulter
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add TP reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pedum
    Pedum was an ancient city of Latium that was part of the Latin League. Located between Tibur and Praeneste, its precise location is now unknown. Some suggest that modern Gallicano is the site of the ancient city.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created name "Pedani"; created connection "Latin League"; created connection "via Pedana"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Pegai/Antipatris/Arethousa?
    Pegai/Antipatris/Arethousa? was a city built by Herod the Great and named for his father-in-law, Antipater.
    Creators: B. Isaac
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Carolin Johansson; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Pella/Apamea
    Pella/Apamea in Syria was an ancient city established by the Seleucids ca. 300 B.C.
    Creators: J.P. Brown; P.-L. Gatier

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Pella/Berenice/Philippeia
    Pella/Berenice/Philippeia (Tabaqat Fahl (طبقة فحل)) is a ruined ancient city located in northwestern Jordan. Pella was continuously occupied from the Neolithic period until its destruction by means of an earthquake in AD 749.
    Creators: E.M. Meyers; J.P. Brown
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Carolin Johansson; Gabriel Mckee; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; update references; modified OSM location of Pella (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); created CIGS location of Ṭabaqat Faḥl; modified name "Pella" (Baseline created, references); created name "Ṭabaqat Faḥl"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Peloponnesus/Peloponnesos/Peloponnese
    The large peninsula protuding into the Mediterranean Sea that constitutes the southern part of Greece. It is largely separated from mainland Greece on the north by the Corinthian Gulf, joining it only in the northeast via the narrow Isthmus of Corinth.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Gabriel Moss; Jeffrey Becker; Pierre Motylewicz; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott

  • Penius
    An ancient settlement, located somewhere north of the Phasis river (modern Rioni in Georgia). Its precise location has not been determined.

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Persepolis/Parsa/Persai/Sat Setun
    Persepolis/Parsa/Persai/Sat Setun was the ceremonial capital of the Achaemenid Empire. The origins of the settlement belong to the sixth century BC (ca. 515). The archaeological site was named as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979.
    Creators: A. Hausleiter; M. Roaf; R. Wenke
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Carolin Johansson; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; P. Flensted Jensen; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; add TGN 7002205: Persepolis (deserted settlement); created CIGS location of Takht-i Jamshīd; created OSM location of Persepolis; modified name "Takht-i Jamshīd" (name type -> associated modern name); created name "Takht-i Jamshīd"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Persou (Bir Umm Fawakhir)
    A cluster of mines and associated late-antique settlement at Bir Umm Fawakhir in Egypt's Eastern Desert.
    Creators: J. Keenan; S.E. Sidebotham; T. Wilfong
    Contributors: Adam Prins; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; Herbert Verreth; Jen Thum; Mark Depauw; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title; summary
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Persou (Wadi Hammamat)
    Wadi Hammamat was the site of major mining and quarrying operations in the ancient world. The site is mentioned in the Turin Papyrus Map, in connection with a quarrying expedition under Ramesses IV.
    Creators: J. Keenan; S.E. Sidebotham; T. Wilfong
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; title; summary; created OSM location of Persou II
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Petavonium
    A Roman legionary encampment (castrum) associated with the Legio X Gemina that later developed into a Roman town. The site is located in the Vidriales valley in the province of Zamora (Castilla y Leon).
    Creators: E.W. Haley
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Petavonium (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)

  • Peukelaotis/Kaspatyros?

  • Phakoussa
    The modern city of Faqous in the southeastern portion of the Nile delta is thought to have been built atop an ancient city known to the Greeks as Phakoussa. Strabo identifies it as the terminus of an ancient canal connecting to the Red Sea.
    Creators: A. Bernand
    Contributors: Adam Prins; Brady Kiesling; Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; Herbert Verreth; Jen Thum; Mark Depauw; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary; added Wikidata; create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; cleaned up references; created OSM location of فاقوس; created CIGS location of Fāqūs; created name "Fāqūs"; created name "Phakousa"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Phanagor(e)ia
    A colony founded by Teos on the Gulf of Taman ca. 540 BC.
    Creators: David Braund
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Carolin Johansson; Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; Diane Braund; R. Talbert

  • Pheradi Maius
    Pheradi Maius was a civitas of Africa Proconsularis. The archaeological site is today located near the village of Sidi Khelifa, Tunisia.

  • Philitzi
    An ancient settlement, likely dating from Geometric to Classical times, has been identified on the modern islet of Filitzi, which was attached to Paros in antiquity.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Phocis
    A region of central ancient Greece. In ~ 356 BCE, Phocian generals seized Delphi, starting the Third Sacred War.
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Phoinike
    Phoinike was an ancient Greek city of Epirus and the location of the Treaty of Phoenice which ended the First Macedonian War.

  • Phoinikous
    An ancient settlement, attested by literary or documentary sources, whose precise location cannot be determined today
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: Initial revision; created connection "Cythera (island)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Phoinikous Limen
    An anchorage, harbor, and/or coastal station on the east-southeast coast of Sicily that is mentioned in ancient sources. It may have been located in the area where the ruins of the 18th century Tonnara di Vendicari now stand or somewhere else in the bay behind and south of it to the island of Vendicari.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: place type; summary; created OSM location of Isola di Vendicari; created OSM location of Tonnara di Vendicari; modified name "Phoinikous Limen" (greek, certain)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

    Creators: M. Roaf
    Contributors: Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; Brian Z. Lund; DARMC; H. Kopp; M. Joann McDaniel; Mary E. Downs; R. Talbert; W. Röllig
    Modifications: delete blank ref.; modified OSM location of Farah Bala Hisar (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Phrygia
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 91 unlocated Phrygia
    Creators: M. Roaf; St J. Simpson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created connection "Radani (river)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Phrygia
    Phrygia was a region of west-central Anatolia.
    Creators: T. Drew Bear
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; Richard Talbert

  • *Phua

  • Piano di Cammarata
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 46 D2 Piano di Cammarata
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created OSM location of Celimarro, Castrovillari
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Piazza d'Armi
    The site of the arx of ancient Veii located on the southern spur of the volcanic plateau on which the city is located. There is archaeological evidence for an initial occupation phase of the ninth century B.C. By the seventh century B.C., the area shows evidence for adoption of rectilinear huts and assumes an orthogonal street grid.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
    Modifications: created OSM location of Area Archeologica di Piazza d'Armi
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Picus
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 32 D3 Picus
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: update reference; modified name "Picus" (add TP reference and name)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Pieria
    Originally the territory of the Pieres, later incoporated into Macedonia
    Creators: E.N. Borza
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Michael Heubel; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; Richard Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference; cleaned up references
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Pieve di San Giovanni Battista a Sillano
    A ruined church that was once part of the diocese of Volterra, San Giovanni Battista a Sillano is unique in Tuscany for having a Romanesque-Norman façade. The ruined edifice likely dates to the twelfth and thirteenth centuries although the parish exists as early as the mid-tenth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Pieve di San Giovanni Battista a Sillano (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pinaros? (river)
    An ancient river located in what is now the country of Turkey. It is probably to be identified with either Deli Çay or Payas Çayı.
    Creators: P.-L. Gatier; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; M. Ballance; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: created OSM location of Payas çayı
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Pirae
    Now unlocated, the "oppidum Pirae" is mentioned by Pliny the Elder and was located between Formiae and Minturnae. Local toponym suggests, according to A. Marzano, that this same place was later incorporated into a villa owned by Marcus Aemilius Scaurus. Marzano suggests that Pirae is in the vicinity of Torre Gianola.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: updated Connections; add pliny; summary, references; modified name "oppidum Pirae" (add Latin name, Pliny reference); created connection "Formiae"; created connection "Minturnae"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Pi-Ramesses
    Capital city built by New Kingdom pharaoh Ramesses II at the modern Egyptian village of Qantir. The site is near the old capital, Avaris.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Pi-Ramesses (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance); created CIGS location of Qantīr; created name "Qantīr"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Pistoriae
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 41 D2 Pistoriae
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pizzo S. Angelo
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 47 E3 Pizzo S. Angelo
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Planasia/Lerina (island)
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 16 D2 Planasia/Lerina Ins.
    Creators: R. Häussler; S. Loseby
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Plataea
    Plataea is an ancient city of Boeotia, located south of Thebes. In 479 BC Plataea was the site of the Battle of Plataea, in which an allied Greek army defeated the Persians. Plataea was destroyed in the Peloponnesian War by Thebes and Sparta in 427 BC and rebuilt in 386 BC.
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; add TP ref.; created OSM location of Plataea; created connection "Boeotia"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Plestia
    Plestia was a municipium of the tribus Ufentina.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; modified OSM location of archaeological area (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Plestina
    Now unlocated, Livy reports that Plestina was conquered by the Roman dictator M. Valerius Maximus in 302 B.C.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary; update references; modified name "Plestina" (add Latin name, add Livy reference,)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Plinthine
    An ancient settlement at modern Kom el-Nagous in Egypt. Archaeological evidence shows habitation on the site stretches back to at least the Ramesside period. A large Ptolemaic temple seems to have been dismantled and built over during the Roman period.
    Creators: A. Bernand
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: DARMC 4824 = related; added Redon 2023; summary; cleaned up references; added Names; added OSM location which supersedes the DARMC location currently published (it should be withdrawn).; created OSM Location of Kom el-Nagous; created name "Plinthine"; created name "Kom el-Nagous"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Poeninus (mountain)
    Great St. Bernard.
    Creators: E. Bertrand
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Michael Heubel; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; Richard Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Poggio Pellicia
    An isolated tumulus with grave goods ranging in date from the seventh to the fourth centuries B.C.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of tumulus (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Poliochne
    A Bronze Age settlement on the island of Lemnos, Poliochne pre-dates Troy I and shows influence from the Greek mainland during Early Helladic II (ca. 2500 BC). Mycenaean horizons have also been identified.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Poliochne (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pollenzo Roman amphitheater
    The Roman amphitheater at ancient Pollentia (modenr Pollenzo).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of borgo Colosseo (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pollusca
    Pollusca was an early city of Latium Vetus connected with Longula and Corioli. Coriolanus captured these three cities in 488 BC. The location of Pollusca is no longer known.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; modified name "Polouska" (update reference)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pomodiana/Cumodina
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 21 F6 Pomodiana/Cumodina
    Creators: J.J. Wilkes
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add TP reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pompeiopolis/Sebaste
    Pompeiopolis/Sebaste, in Paphlagonia, was founded under Pompeius in 64 B.C. in the valley of the Amnias river.
    Creators: C. Foss
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pondel
    A Roman aqueduct dating to 3 B.C.
    Creators: E. Bertrand
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Pont D'Aël (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Pons Aelius
    The Pons Aelius or Aelian Bridge (now Ponte Sant'Angelo) was completed by Hadrian in AD 134 to span the Tiber opposite the new mausoleum of the emperor.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Ponte Sant'Angelo (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pons Aluti
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 22 B4 Pons Aluti

    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pons Chabinae
    A Roman bridge across the Cendere Çayı that lies west of Arsameia pros Nymphaio (modern Eskikale in Turkey's Adıyaman Province).
    Creators: P.-L. Gatier; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; M. Ballance; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: modified OSM Location of Severan Bridge (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pons Mulvius
    Pons Mulvius (the Milvian Bridge) is a Roman bridge over the Tiber river. The original phase of the bridge dates to the consulship of Gaius Claudius Nero in 206 B.C. The bridge is most famous as the site of a decisive battle between Maxentius and Constantine I fought in A.D. 312.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add ItMiller
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pont du Roi
    A Roman bridge in the modern French commune of Boucieu-le-Roi (Ardèche department).
    Creators: E. Bertrand
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Pont du Roi (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Pontecagnano
    The ancient settlement of Pontecagnano is located on the plain of the Sele river, about 4 km from the sea. Settlement begins in the Chalcolithic period. The Early Iron Age sees the arrival of people identified as Villanovans who originated in South Etruria, initiating a proto-urban phase of the settlement covering some 80 ha.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add Nizzo 2023
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ponte da Ladeira dos Envendos
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 26 C2 Ponte da Ladeira dos Envendos
    Creators: F.H. Stanley; Jr.; R.C. Knapp
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: update references; modified OSM location of Ponte de Pracana (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Ponte dell'Abbadia
    An ancient bridge over the Fiora river (the ancient Armenta) near Vulci. Ancient name unknown.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add Arachne Brücke bei Vulci, sog. Ponte dell' Abbadia Vulci, Viterbo (Provinz)

  • Ponte San Cono, Buccino

    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pozzo Pantaleo
    The 'Pozzo Pantaleo' is a Roman mausoleum that made use of a cistern of the early Imperial period. In a third phase the site was repurposed as a shrine dedicated to the Christian Saint Pantaleon.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Pozzo Pantaleo (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Praeneste
    An ancient city of central Italy, the eighth and seventh century B.C. origins of which demonstrate high-level trade contact with the Eastern Mediterranean world. The city withdrew from the Latin League (499 B.C.) and opposed Rome in the Latin war; Cincinnatus eventually subdued Praeneste. Sulla founded a new colony there in the first century B.C.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created name "Praenestini"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Praetorium Publilianum
    Praetorium Publilianum was the center of an imperial latifundium in the territory of Teanum Apulum.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add Bruun 1999; update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Prata Mucia
    The so-called Prata Mucia was a meadow granted to the Roman Republican hero Mucius Scaevola in recognition of his heroism in the face of the invasion of Lars Porsena of Clusium. While it was located on the right bank of the River Tiber, a precise location cannot be ascertained.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: edit summary
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Prepsidai
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 60 unlocated Prepsidai

    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Priene/‘Lince’?
    Priene/‘Lince’? was an ancient Greek city of Ionia on an escarpment of Mycale Mons.

  • Propontis

    Modifications: created connection "Mysia (region)"
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Prusias ad Mare/Kios
    Prusias ad Mare/Kios was an ancient Greek city on the Propontis. The city joined the Aetolian League and was destroyed by Philip V of Macedon. Prusias I of Bithynia rebuilt the site, naming it for himself.
    Creators: C. Foss
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pseudopenias Pr.

  • Pteleon

  • Puente de la Perdiz
    A Roman bridge located near the hamelt of Nestar, over the Rio Rubagón.
    Creators: E.W. Haley
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Puente de la Perdiz (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, Baseline created)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Punta della Vipera Etruscan temple
    A coastal Etruscan sanctuary that dates ca. 540-530 B.C. with additional architectural phases dating to the fourth through second centuries B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Tempio Etrusco Punta della Vipera (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Punta de Muros
    A coastal fortified settlement dating to the late Bronze and early Iron Ages, known in modern times as Castro de Cociñadoiro and A Punta de Muros. The site was excavated ahead of its complete destruction in the first decade of the 21st century as part of the development of the Porto Exterior da Coruña at Punta Langosteira.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
    Modifications: updated reference: Cano Pan 2010
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Pupput
    Pupput was an ancient city of Africa proconsularis.
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: update references; update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

  • Pylos
    An archaic through Roman settlement located at the Armatova hill, west of Agrapidochori in Ileia in the Peloponnese.

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Pylos
    A classical city in Triphylia not far from the coast and somewhere north of Lepreon, later annexed to the latter, unlocated.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created connection "Boinoa/Oinoe"

  • Pylos/Koryphasion
    A Classical settlement, probably the Pylos of Thucydides, on the Koryphasion promontory, (modern Akr. Koryphasiou in Messenia) in the Peloponnese.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Pyramid of Khendjer

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pyramos (river)
    The modern Ceyhan river in southern Turkey. Its modern mouth is well to the east of its ancient location, which was to the west of Magarsa and much inland from the modern coast.
    Creators: P.-L. Gatier; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; M. Ballance; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: added MANTO reference; added RE and New Pauly links; created OSM Location of modern Ceyhan

  • Qalaat al-Madiq
    A town and medieval fortress in northwestern Syria adjacent to the site of ancient Apamea.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Qalaat al-Madiq (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); modified connection "Pella/Apamea" (change type to succeeds)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Qa`la Bost
    Qa`la Bost is an ancient fortress within the ancient city of Bust, located on the Helmand River in southern Afghanistan and overseeing a major crossroads linking Kandahar and India to eastern Iran. Standing remains at the site predominantly date to the Islamic Middle Ages, but archaeological finds suggest an occupational history dating back to at least the first millennium BCE.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified CIGS location of Qa`la Bust (Standardized title, Baseline created); modified name "Qa`la Bust" (time period, assoc modern); modified name "Qa`la Bust" (time period, assoc modern)
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker
  • Qalatgah
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 89 H3 Qalatgah
    Creators: M. Roaf; S.E. Kroll; St J. Simpson; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; created CIGS location of Qalatgah
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker
  • Qalat-i Dinka
    Archaeological site in the Peshdar Plain with remains dated to the Neo-Assyrian period. The mound is part of a larger frontier settlement known as the Dinka Settlement Complex.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Qalat-i Dinka
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Qaleh Dukhtar
    The so-called "Maiden Castle" is a large fortification built by Ardashir I in the early third century A.D. It is located about 8 kilometers to the north of Firuzabad in modern Iran. Despite the distance involved, it is listed as part of the "cultural landscape of Bam" in the 2004 UNESCO World Heritage List.
    Creators: A. Hausleiter; M. Roaf; R. Wenke
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; P. Flensted Jensen; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM Location of Qaleh Dukhtar (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
