    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Qasr el-Banat
    Qasr el-Banat is a fortified site in Egypt's Eastern Desert, some 15 km from Wadi Hammamat.
    Creators: J. Keenan; S.E. Sidebotham; T. Wilfong

  • Qattara?/Karana?
    Tell al-Rimah, is the site of a settlement inhabited from the third to first millennium BCE that has been identified as the site of either Qattara or Karana.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg

  • Ras Ibn Hani
    Archaeological evidence on this cape on the northwest coast of the modern country of Syria demonstrates continuous human occupation from the Bronze Age through Byzantine times, down to the modern day.
    Creators: J.P. Brown; P.-L. Gatier
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; R. Talbert; R. Warner; W. Röllig

  • Ratiaria
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 21 E6 Ratiaria
    Creators: J.J. Wilkes

    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Războieni-Cetate Roman castrum
    Base of the Roman ala I Batavorum milliaria from the time of Hadrian to Rome's withdrawal from Dacia in the third century, this site at the modern village of Războieni-Cetate in Romania has been the subject of intensive geomagnetic survey and verification excavations between 2016 and 2018.
    Creators: J.J. Wilkes
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: DARMC 24420; summary; added Rubel 2023; title; cleaned up references; place type -> fort; updated Names; created Approximate Imagery Location of Unexcavated castrum; created name "Războieni-Cetate"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Reccopolis
    Reccopolis is an urban, Visigothic, ex-novo foundation made under king Liuvigild in A.D. 578. The archaeological remains at the site include a palace complex, public area, basilica, walls, and aqueduct. The site is known today by the Spanish version of its Latin name (Recópolis); it is located near the modern village of Zorita de los Canes in the Spanish province of Guadelajara.
    Creators: Javier Martínez Jiménez
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: add Jiménez 2023; modified OSM location of Reccopolis (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Regio IX, Pompeii
    The so-called Regio IX, an archaeological subdivision located in the central section of Pompeii, contains a mix of residential and commercial structures.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: add Ynnilä 2012
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

  • Rhodos (island)
    The island of Rhodes has an area of some 1,400 square km and sits 18 km from the coast of Asia Minor. The island has been inhabited by humans since the Neolithic period.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. Bennet
    Contributors: Benjamin M Crowther; Jeffrey Becker; Kali Kocian; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Faith Lubeck; Jeff Mayfield; R. Talbert; Rajas Pradhan

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Rhyndakos (river)
    The ancient Rhyndakos river has been identified with the modern Mustafakemalpaşa Çayı, which flows through the modern Uluabat Gölü (ancient Miletopolitis/Apolloniatis) and then into a lower course of what is now known as the Simav Çayı, ultimately emptying into the Propontis (modern Sea of Marmara).
    Creators: C. Foss
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: cleaned up references; summary; created location "OSM Location: Mustafakemalpaşa Çayı (1)"; created location "OSM Location: Mustafakemalpaşa Çayı (2)"; created location "OSM Location: Mustafakemalpaşa Çayı (3)"; created location "OSM Location: Mustafakemalpaşa Çayı (4)"; created location "OSM Location: Simav Çayı (1)"; created location "OSM Location: Simav Çayı (2)"; created location "OSM Location: Simav Çayı (3)"; created connection "Propontis"; created connection "Miletopolitis/Apolloniatis/Artynia L."; created connection "Mysia (region)"
    Actors: Tom Elliott

  • Rogous
    A fortified acropolis known as Kastro Rogon and located near modern Nea Karasounta in Epirus, Greece has been identified as the likely site of ancient Bouchetion, a colony of Elis.
    Creators: W.M. Murray
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: DARMC 11807 = related; added OSM location that supersedes currently published DARMC location; added modern names; title; summary; update reference; created OSM Location of Κάστρο Ρωγών; created name "Kastro de Rogous"; created name "Kastro Rogon"; created name "Nea Kerasounta"; created name "Nea Kerasous"; modified name "Bouchetion" (Greek name, Strabo reference); modified name "Bouchaition" (greek, less certain); modified name "Boucheta" (greek, less certain); modified name "Boucheton" (greek, less certain)

  • Roman amphitheater at Aosta

  • Roman amphitheater at Deva
    The second-century A.D. Roman amphitheater at Deva Victrix (modern Chester, England) was the largest military amphitheater in Britain.

  • Roman amphitheater at Volsinii

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Roman amphitheater of Milan
    The Roman amphitheater of Milan was built near the Porta Ticinese during the second and third centuries. It was destroyed by the time of the Gothic Wars, most likely during the fifth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
    Modifications: created OSM location of Anfiteatro Romano
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Roman Theatre at Caere
    The Roman theater at Caere (modern Cerveteri, Italy) is known especially for the sculptural program honoring Julio-Claudian emperors, including Tiberius and Claudius.

  • Sacred Area of S. Omobono
    An archaeological area in the Forum Boarium comprising an ancient ritual precinct with twin temples ranging in date from the Archaic period through the time of the Roman Empire. The Medieval church dedicated to S. Omobono stands atop the remains of one of the two ancient temples.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM Location of Sacred Area of S. Omobono (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Saepinum

    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference

  • Saltus Philomusianus
    Saltus Philomusianus was a sizable imperial estate located between Bulla Regia and Chimtou. Roman soldiers of legio III Augusta seem to have garrisoned a praesidium in the estate ca. 52-57 CE.
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: summary, references; Fenwick 2022; add TM GEO ID 43501: Saltus Philomusianus; modified name "Saltus Philomusianus" (Initial revision)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Samothrace

  • Sanctuary at Agios Konstantinos (Methana)
    A Late Helladic sanctuary was excavated by Helene Konstolakis-Jiannopoulou in 1990 near the chapel of Agios Konstantinos and Elenis. Activity at this site dates between 1500 and 1300 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
    Modifications: update references; modified OSM location of Mykenische Siedlung OINOH? (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sanctuary of Apollo on Delos
    The famous sanctuary of Apollo on the Cycladic island of Delos.
    Creators: C. Foss; G. Reger
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: cleaned up references; added MANTO reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Sanctuary of Artemis Limnatis at Messene
    A sanctuary on the slopes of Mount Ithome and within the city walls of ancient Messene in the Peloponnese. It was developed beginning in the 4th-3rd centuries BCE.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Sanctuary of Artemis Limnatis (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sanctuary of Artemis Limnatis in the Taygetos
    A sanctuary in the Taygetos mountains, attested in both literary and epigraphic texts, its precise location cannot yet be determined; however scattered and reused architectural components and inscriptions have been found in the area of the Chapel of Panagia Kapsocherovolousa, Volimos, northwest of modern Alagonia in the Peloponnese. Of uncertain foundation date, but confirmed by the Roman Senate under Tiberius as belonging to the Messenians (as part of the Ager Denthaliatis), rather than the Spartans.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary; edited; cleaned up BAtlas reference; title, summary; reference: topostext; reference: iDAI; updated Names; created name "Limnatis Artemis"; created name "Tempel der Artemis Limnatis"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Sanctuary of Asklepios at Athens
    A major sanctuary complex located west of the Theatre of Dionysus Eleuthereus on the south slope of the Athenian Acropolis.
    Creators: Denitsa Dzhigova
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Gabriel Moss; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: update; modified OSM location of the Sanctuary of Asklepios at Athens (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sanctuary of Fortuna Primigenia
    The Sanctuary of Fortuna Primigenia at Praeneste is a terraced sanctuary of monumental proportions. The phase visible today dates to the late second century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Temple of Fortuna Primigenia (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

  • Sandalium? (island)

  • Sangarius (river)
    The Sangarius river (modern Sakarya) is the third longest river in Asia Minor and flows through ancient Phrygia.
    Creators: C. Foss

  • Sanitium
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 16 B2 Sanitium
    Creators: R. Häussler; S. Loseby
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: updated Zotero URI for Barruol 1969
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • San Menna
    The church of San Menna in Rome was recorded by the anonymous pilgrim author of the Einsiedeln in the eighth century CE. It was located along the Via Ostiensis, most likely between the Porta San Paolo and the Basilica of Saint Paul. Likely founded in 589, the church is not attested after the tenth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: LTUR ref.
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • San Nicola in Carcere
    San Nicola in Carcere is a titular church in Rome's historical district (rione) Sant'Angelo, close to the Forum Boarium. The twelfth century church is built atop the remains of Roman temples of the Forum Holitorium and incorporates their remains into its structure.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: update deprecated Arachne references; modified OSM location of San Nicola in Carcere (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • San Pietro a Badia Pozzeveri
    An abbey with tenth century origins connected to the pilgrimage route known as the Via Francigena.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified location of San Pietro a Badia Pozzeveri (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • San Roque Theatre - Carteia
    The Roman theater of Carteia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of San Roque Theatre - Carteia (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Santa Cristina
    A nuragic sanctuary centered on a sacred well that was in use from ca. 1200 to 700 BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Parco Archeologico Santa Cristina (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); modified OSM location of sacred well (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); modified OSM location of nuraghe Santa Cristina (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Santa Filitica
    A Roman villa and subsequent Vandal-era and, following a period of abandonment, Byzantine-era village, located on the northwest Sardinian coast in the northern part of the modern municipal territory of Sorso. Pre-modern names for the site are unknown.
    Creators: S.L. Dyson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add wikimedia, wikidata references; add TGN 7669150: Santa Filitica (deserted settlement); summary; place type += settlement; added references (CBI, Sardegna Cultura, Testone 2012); associated modern name "Sorso"; title; add vici.org; update references; created OSM location of Santa Filitica; created name "Sorso"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Santa Maria della Libera
    An eleventh century church near Aquinum built largely from spolia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Madonna della Libera (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Santa María do Castro
    The castro of Santa María de Cervantes is located on the banks of the Ancares river the municipality of Cervantes, in the province of Lugo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Castro de Santa María (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Santi Giovanni e Paolo
    An ancient Christian basilica on the Caelian Hill in Rome that was built in AD 398 by will of a senator known as Pammachius. The basilica was located over the home of two Roman soldiers, John and Paul, who had been martyred under Julian in AD 362. The church was thus called the Titulus Pammachii.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Gabriel Moss; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: Astolfi 2017; modified OSM Location of Basilica dei Santi Giovanni e Paolo (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • S. Antonio
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 43 D2 S. Antonio
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • San Vitale
    The basilica of Saints Vitalis, Valeris, Gervase and Protase, commonly known as the Basilica di San Vitale, is a titular minor basilica church in Rome. The church was built ca. AD 400 by Pope Innocent I.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: add wikipedia (it); modified OSM location of Santi Vitale e Compagni Martiri in Fovea (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, refresh OSM data, update title, summary, place type); created name "Titulus Vestinae"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Sapinuwa
    Bronze Age Hittite city at the location of modern Ortaköy, Turkey
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: references; created OSM location of Şapinuva; created CIGS location of Ortaköy
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker
  • Saqqarah
    A pharaonic necropolis serving the ancient Egyptian city of Memphis. It was most active during Early Dynastic and Old Kingdom Egypt. The step pyramid complex of the Third Dynasty Pharaoh Djoser is the best preserved and most well known structure of the site.
    Creators: Iris Fernandez
    Contributors: Gabriel Bodard; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale
    Modifications: added TGN 1100514: Ṣaqqâra (ancient site)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sarapi(a)s (island)
    Masirah (or Mazeira) is an Island off the east coast of Oman.
    Creators: M. Roaf
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Brian Z. Lund; M. Joann McDaniel; Mary E. Downs; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; created OSM Location of modern Al Masira
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

    The second largest island in the Mediterranean Sea
    Creators: S.L. Dyson

    Modifications: added MANTO reference; add MANTO 8254032: Sardinia (island)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Sarissa
    Sarissa was a Hittite site of the second millennium BC. Its remains are located at Kuşaklı, Turkey. Excavations have recovered a substantial archive of Hittite texts.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: corrected typo in summary; modified OSM location of Sarissa - Kuşaklı Örenyeri (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); created CIGS location of Kuşaklı; created name "Kuşaklı"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Sarkine
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 88 C3 Sarkine
    Creators: David Braund
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; Diane Braund; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sarsina
    Sarsina was a town of the Umbri that was captured by Cornelius Scipio in 271 B.C. and was the birthplace of the Latin author Plautus. The necropolis at Sarsina has been extensively studied.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Jonathan Weiland; Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sarsura?

  • Sason (island)
    Pliny notes that this island was notorious as a pirate refuge.
    Creators: J.J. Wilkes
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add TP reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Saticula
    Saticula was a Samnite site in Campania that received a Latin colony in 313 B.C.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add TGN 6005276: Saticula (deserted settlement); update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Saviniago
    The Gallo-Roman villa of Séviac was designed around a central peristyle courtyard and its fourth-century A.D. phase covered up to one hectare.
    Creators: H.S. Sivan; R.W. Mathisen; S.J. Keay
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created OSM location of Villa gallo-romaine de Séviac
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Saww
    A port on the Red Sea, located at a small dhow harbor now called Mersa Gawasis. The port was used during the 12th Dynasty for expeditions to Punt and Sinai.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: added Bard 2022
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Saxa Rubra
    Saxa Rubra (modern Grottarossa) is the name of a road station on the Via Flaminia nine Roman miles from the center of ancient Rome. It was at Saxa Rubra that Constantine I defeated Maxentius in A.D. 312.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: reference; add It Miller
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Scaldis (river)
    The Scaldis was a river of Gallia Belgica. It separated the territory of the civitates of the Atrebates and the Menapii from that of the Nervii.
    Creators: C. Haselgrove; J. Kunow
    Contributors: Francis Deblauwe; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added Bongers 2020
    Actors: Tom Elliott

  • S. Callisto
    A large catacomb on the Via Appia south of Rome notable especially for its so-called 'Crypt of the Popes'. The catacomb covers approximately 15 hectares.

  • Scythia
    An ancient region, located roughly north of the modern Danube river and west of the Don.

    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Sebasteion
    The Sebasteion at Aphrodisias was a temple complex dedicated to Aphrodite and the Iulio-Claudian emperors that was financed by local patrons. It was built between ca. AD 20 and 60. The complex was excavated in 1979-81.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Ann Morgan; Jeffrey Becker; Katelin McCullough; Sean Gillies
    Modifications: cleaned up bad zotero URI
    Actors: Tom Elliott

  • Sepia (mountain)
    An unlocated mountain peak in Arcadia, probably part of mount Kyllene to the east of Pheneos
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II

  • Sep. Plautii
    The Mausoleum of the Plautii dates to the first century B.C. It is located near Ponte Lucano at Tibur.

  • Sep. Scipionum
    A family tomb of the Cornelii Scipiones near the Porta San Sebastiano in use from the third century B.C. to the first century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
    Modifications: Coarelli 1996; LTUR; update arachne references x 2; add references x 2
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Septem Pagi
    Septem Pagi refers to a community of South Etruria located on the Tiber's right bank that was absorbed by Rome at an early date.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Seriphos (island)
    Seriphos is an island of the western Cyclades. The island was settled by the third millennium B.C. The island was a member of the Delian League.

  • Sette Bassi
    A large, suburban villa complex on the Via Tuscolana. The villa was in use from the reign of Antoninus Pius until the fourth century A.D.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert

  • Shadikanni/Ar(a)ban/(H)Oraba?/*Castellum Arabum

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Siagu
    An ancient settlement in the Roman province of Africa Proconsularis. It was located at a site known today as Ksar el-Zit, which is in the vicinity of Bir Bou Rekba to the northwest of Hammamet, Tunisia.
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sibrium
    The Roman fort of Sibrium, known today as Castelseprio or Castel Seprio, became a significant Lombard town of the early Middle Ages. It was destroyed and abandoned in 1287. In 2011, the site, including the church of Santa Maria 'foris portas', the castrum and its Torba Tower, was enrolled as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
    Creators: M. Pearce; P. Tozzi
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; created OSM location of Parco archeologico di Castel Seprio
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Sicilia (island)
    Sicily is the largest island in the Mediterranean Sea and has been the site of human habitation since ca. 8,000 BC. In historical terms Sicily has seen important settlement activity connected to numerous culture groups - Punic, Carthaginian, Greek, Roman, Vandalic, Ostrogothic, Byzantine, Arabic, and Norman.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Pierre Motylewicz; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference; cleaned up references; update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • *Sidamaria
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 66 D2 *Sidamaria
    Creators: S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Ambar Höyük (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Tom Elliott

  • Sikani
    A town mentioned in Neo-Assyrian sources that is generally identified with Tell Fekheriye (Tell Faḫārīya).

    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Silsilah
    An ancient settlement east of the Nile, just south of and associated with the ancient quarries on Gebel el-Silsila.
    Creators: J. Keenan; S.E. Sidebotham; T. Wilfong
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; summary
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Silva Arsia
    A forest located near the boundary between the archaic territory of Rome and that of Veii. Lucius Junius Brutus fell there in battle in 509 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Silvium
    Silvium (modern Gravina in Puglia) was founded as a Greek colony. It was a town on the frontier of the Peucetii.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created OSM location of Scavi archeologici di Botromagno
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Simiou?
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 80 D1 Simiou?
    Creators: J. Keenan; S.E. Sidebotham; T. Wilfong
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: Initial revision; created OSM location
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Simitthu
    A city of Africa Proconsularis, Simitthu is especially noted for its marble quarries.
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: update
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

  • Sinai
    The Sinai Peninsula is bounded by the Mediterranean Sea to the north and the Red Sea to the south.
    Creators: D.F. Graf
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert

  • Siniyah Island Monastery
    A church and possible monastic complex identified in 2021/2022 on modern Siniyah Island in the emirate of Umm al-Quwain, UAE.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Yonatan Miller
    Modifications: added Power 2022 and Power 2022 (BIASA); created connection "Sīnīya Island"

  • Siphai/Tipha
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 55 E4 Siphai/Tipha
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Sisi, Kephali tou Agiou Antoniou
    Kephali tou Agiou Antoniou is an archaeological site in Agios Nikolaos, located near Sisi on the north coast of Crete. Remains of monumental Minoan architecture have been documented there.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: added references; added modern Names; added Roumpou 2023; created name "Sissi"; created name "Sisi"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Skandeia
    Pausanias locates Skandeia on the coast of the island of Cythera, some 10 stades from the inland settlement of Cythera.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; modified connection "Cythera (island)" (ctype)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Skollion
    A physical feature mentioned by Strabo as near Pylos in Elis. It may be identical with the mountain named "Skollis" mentioned later in Strabo.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title; summary; added additional BAtlDir references; evidence; summary; replaced BAtlas unlocated reference with BAtlDir reference; added RE reference; title; added modern Location and Names; retract current BAtlas location once the new location is published.; created connection "Skollis (mountain)"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Skollis (mountain)
    A mountain that Strabo reports as lying on the border of Elis and Achaea in the Peloponnese, identified with the modern Santameri/Santomeri/Santameriotiko (also now often called by its ancient name).
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added RE reference; title; summary; cleaned up references; modified Imagery location of Skollis M. (associated modern); modified Geonames location of Santomeri (certain); created Geonames location of Santomeri; modified name "Skollis" (evidence, greek, Baseline created); modified name "Santomeri" (certain); created name "Santomeri"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Skouriotissa

  • Skylax (river)
    Skylax fl. (modern Çekerek river) is a tributary of the Iris river in Asia Minor.
    Creators: T.B. Mitford

  • Slack Roman Fort (Camulodonum?)
    The remains of a first-century A.D. earthwork and the buried remains of a Roman fort at Slack. These remains might be associated with the Roman toponym Camulodonum.
    Creators: A.S. Esmonde Cleary
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Scott Vanderbilt; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner

  • Sobanos (river)
    An ancient river mentioned by Ptolemy. It may be identifiable with the modern Salween.
    Creators: M.U. Erdosy

  • So-called House of the Doric Peristyle
    A large private house in Cyrene.
    Creators: Valeria Vitale
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified OSM location of the House of the Doric Peristyle in Cyrene (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • So-called Oratory of Phalaris
    A small, rectangular Greek temple-type building dated to the first century B.C. and located in the upper agora of Agrigento, on the Poggetto di San Nicola. The name "Oratory" comes from its later use as a Christian chapel.
    Creators: Valeria Vitale
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Jonathan Prag
    Modifications: modified OSM location of so-called "Oratorio di Falaride" (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • So-called Tempio di Venere e Cupido
    The so-called Temple of Venus and Cupid at Rome is part of the complex of buildings associated with the Sessorian palace. The structure's modern assignation is owed to the discovery of a fragmentary statue of Sallustia Orbiana in the guise of Venus Felix. Sallustia Orbiana was the wife of Alexander Severus. The statue is now held in the Museo Pio Clementino in the Vatican Museums.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Tempio di Venere e Cupido (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • So-called Temple 1 at Hattusa
    Temple 1, also referred to as the "Great Temple", is located in the lower city of Hattusa. It dates to the thirteenth century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of so-called Temple 1 (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • So-called Temple of Cybele
    Recently discovered temple in the acropolis of Cyrene
    Creators: Valeria Vitale
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of the so-called Temple of Cybele in Cyrene (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sogdiana
    Sogdiana was a wide region of the Achaemenid Empire lying between the Oxus (Araxes) and Iaxartes rivers.
    Creators: M.U. Erdosy
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Michael Heubel; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; Richard Talbert

  • Soluntum
    An ancient settlement on the north-west coast of Sicily, some 16 km east of modern Palermo.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson

  • Sousikana
    An ancient settlement, attested by literary or documentary sources, whose precise location cannot be determined today
    Creators: M.U. Erdosy
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • S. Paulus
    One of Rome's four major papal basilicae, S. Paulus was founded by Constantine I in the early fourth century A.D. and expanded by Valentinian I in the 370s. The basilica, with many renovations, repairs, and improvements, stood until the 19th century, when it was destroyed in a fire. The reconstructed basilica only generally resembles the original structure.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: place type; summary; created OSM location of Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Spercheios
    A river of central Greece that rises in the Tymfristos mountains. Today it empties into the Malian Gulf some 14km east of its ancient mouth (BAtlas 55 C3 Spercheios fl.).
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Robin Iversen Rönnlund; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: cleaned up references; added MANTO reference; created location "OSM Location: Σπερχειός"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Spina
    An Etruscan port city at the mouth of the Po river on the Adriatic Sea, most likely founded at the end of the sixth century B.C.
    Creators: M. Pearce; P. Tozzi; R. Peretto
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Spina (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Spoletium
    An ancient city along the route of the Via Flaminia; an initial colony was established there in 241 BC.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • SS. Marcellino e Pietro
    The church of Saints Marcellinus and Peter is a Roman Catholic church located on the Via Merulana in Rome. Pope Siricius built the original church in the fourth century A.D., close to the catacombs of Marcellinus and Peter. The relics of the saints were deposited in the church in 1256.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created OSM location of Chiesa dei Santi Marcellino e Pietro ad Duas Lauros
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Stabiae
    An Oscan and Roman settlement located on the bay of Naples.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; add TGN 7015639: Castellammare di Stabia (inhabited place); update references; created OSM location of Scavi archeologici di Stabia; modified name "Stabiae" (Baseline created, Latin name, reference)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Stadium-garden at Hadrian's Villa
    A garden at the Villa Hadriani imitating the shape of a stadium, situated between the Three Exedras' Hall (to the west) and the Winter Palace (to the east), with a semi-circular nymphaeum at its southern end.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Stadium-garden at Hadrian's Villa (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Stageira
    An ancient city on the east coast of the Chalcidian peninsula. Birthplace of Aristotle.
    Creators: E.N. Borza
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; G. Reger; R. Talbert

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ste-Cécile Paleochristian Church
    Remains of this paleochristian church, located at modern Loupian in Hérault, France, were discovered and excavated in the 1980s. The structure lies immediately north of the current church of Ste-Cécile, which dates to the 14th century.
    Creators: S. Loseby
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: place type; summary; cleaned up references; removed unrelated PECS reference; create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created DARE Location
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • St-Estève-de-Ménerbes
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 15 E2 St-Estève-de-Ménerbes
    Creators: S. Loseby
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Stifone
    Evidence of a Roman shipyard has been discovered at the locality of Stifone within the comune of Le Mole of the town of Narni. This shpiyard was connected to an artificial canal dug adjacent to the river Nera.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Stifone (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

    Contributors:

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Stratoni (Stratonikeia/Stratonike?)
    Recent archaeological survey and excavation have identified structures, artifacts, and Hellenistic pottery just west of the modern Greek village of Stratoni, on the north-eastern coast of the Chalkidiki peninsula. Excavators argue that these should be taken as reinforcing an association between the modern name Stratoni and the ancient Macedonian polis of Stratonike, which is attested in ancient sources.
    Creators: E.N. Borza
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: replaced BAtlas reference with BAtlDir reference (unlocated); summary; added RE reference; updated Locations, Names; added Papastathis 2023; retract BAtlas location once these changes are checked in: title; place type -> settlement; created location "OSM Location: Modern Stratoni"; created name "Stratoni"; modified name "Stratonikeia" (greek, less certain); modified name "Stratonike" (greek, less certain)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Strymon (river)
    The modern Sturma river originates in what is now Bulgaria, flows through the ancient region of Thrace, and empties into the Aegean Sea.
    Creators: E.N. Borza
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference; cleaned up references; summary; added Malama 2023
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • St-Sylvestre

  • Sufetula

  • Sultan Kala
    A fortified area at Merv covering some 400 hectares.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Sultan Kala (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sumhuram
    A small, fortified town that served as an outpost for the Ḥaḑramawt kingdom from the first to seventh centuries. The archaeological site and its surrounding landscape are known by the modern name Khor Rori, and the town is tentatively identified as Ptolemy's Abyssapolis, and the port of Moscha Limen of the Periplus Maris Erythraei.
    Creators: D.T. Potts
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: edited; edited; edited; edited; modified OSM location of Khor Rori (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance, Baseline created, less certain (per BAtlDir)); created name "Sumhuram"; created name "Khor Rori"; created connection "Moscha Limen"
    Actors: Gabriel McKee; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott

  • Tall el Hammam (Jordan)
    Tell el-Hammam or Tall al-Hammam is an archaeological site located in Jordan near the mouth of the Jordan River. The site has substantial occupational remains from the Chalcolithic, Early, Intermediate, and Middle Bronze Age, and from Iron Age II.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:

  • Tall Mūzān
    Urkesh or Urkish (the modern Tell Mozan) is a tell located in the foothills of the Taurus Mountains of northeastern Syria. Hurrians founded the site during the fourth millennium B.C.

  • Tanarus (river)

  • Tarchna/Tarquinii
    An ancient city of Etruria and the leading city of the doudecim populi Etruriae, Tarquinia (called Tarch(u)na or Tarchna in Etruscan) was a major urban center of ancient Italy.
    Creators: W.V. Harris

  • Taşköprü

  • Tatta L.
    Tatta L. (Lake Tuz or Tuz Gölü) is one of the largest of the world's hypersaline lakes and the second largest lake in Turkey.
    Creators: S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created name "Tatta"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Taurianos Skopelos
    Now unlocated, Taurianos Skopelos seems to be a rock formation in the Vibonensis Sinus, known in modern times as Golfo di Sant’Eufemia. As described by Ptolemy, this place is probably near Temesa on the Tyrrhenian Sea coast. The compilers of the Barrington Atlas note that the ancient place may be the same as the modern "Scogli Isca", which is now incorporated in a protected marine habitat area administered by the Republic of Italy.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add summary
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Taurike Chersonesos

    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Diane Braund; R. Talbert

  • Tegulata/Teglata

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Tel Hazor
    Tel Hazor (Hebrew: תל חצור‎‎) is an archaeological site located in the southern Hula Valley overlooking Lake Merom. From the Middle Bronze Age to the Israelite period in the ninth century B.C., Hazor was the largest fortified city in the region. It served as a commercial center with links to Babylon and Syria. In the Book of Joshua, Hazor is described as “the head of all those kingdoms” (Josh. 11:10).
    Creators: Clifflena Tiah
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Noah Kaye; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: add TGN 7023951: Tel H̲aẕor (deserted settlement); edited; added Runjajić 2023; modified OSM location of Tel Hazor (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); created CIGS location of Tel Hazor
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Tel Kisson
    Tel Kisson, also known as Tell Keisan, is an archaeological site located 8 km from the Mediterranean shoreline in Israel's Galilee region. Human occupation at the site of the tel begins in the Chalcolithic period. By the middle Bronze Age, the site was prosperous and fortified. It experiences possible destruction in the twelfth century BCE and recovers, though at a reduced scale. From the later eleventh century BCE, the site is occupied as perhaps an economic enclave of Phoenician Tyre.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Tel Keisan
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell Abraq
    Tell Abraq was an ancient Near Eastern city.
    Creators: D.T. Potts
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: cleaned up references; created OSM location of Tell Abraq
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Tell Abu Qubur
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 91 F4 Tell Abu Qubur
    Creators: M. Roaf; St J. Simpson
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; update references; created CIGS location of Tall Abū Qubur; created name "Tall Abū Qubur"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Tell Afis
    Iron Age settlement in Syria. The site has been tentatively identified as Hadarikka/Hazrek, the capital of the region of Luhuti/Luash, which became part of the kingdom of Hamath around 796 BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Tall Āfis; created name "Tall Āfis"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Tell al-Fakhar
    Tell al-Fakhar is located in northeastern Iraq. Excavations between 1967 and 1969 two occupation phases dating to the Mitanni/Kassite and Neo-Assyrian periods.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Tall al-Fakhār; created name "Tall al-Fakhār"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Tell al-Lahm
    Tell al-Lahm is probably to be identified with Dur-Yakin, Duru(m), and/or Kissik, which are mentioned in Assyrian and Neo-Babylonian sources, and also in some first-millenium BCE texts together with Ur, Uruk, Larsa, Eridu, and Kullab (Uruk sanctuary).
    Creators: A. Hausleiter; M. Roaf; R. Wenke; St J. Simpson
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; P. Flensted Jensen; R. Talbert
    Modifications: title; summary; created CIGS location of Tall al-Laḥam; created name "Tall al-Laḥam"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Tell Arbid
    Tell Arbid is an archaeological site located in Syria's Al-Hasakah Governorate in the basin of the Khabur River. The site is active from the third millennium BCE onward.
    Creators: M. Roaf; S.E. Kroll; St J. Simpson; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: edit summary; modified OSM location of `Arbid Tahtani (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); modified name "Tell ‘Arbīd" (ctype)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell Barri/[Kahat]
    Tell Barri/[Kahat] is an archaeological site located along the Wadi Jaghjagh, a tributary of the Khabur River, in north-eastern Syria's Al-Hasakah Governorate. The ancient name of the site was Kahat. The site is occupied from the later Halaf period (late seventh to early sixth millennium BCE) to the Iron Age (first millennium BCE). The tell is substantial - at least 32 meters in height, covering an area of 37 hectares - and was accompanied by a lower town of some 7 hectares.
    Creators: M. Roaf; S.E. Kroll; St J. Simpson; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary, references; created CIGS location of Tall Barri; created name "Tall Barri"; created connection "Hirmas/Mygdon(ios) (river)"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Tell Beydar
    Tell Beydar (ancient Nabada) is an archaeological site in NE Syria that was first settled ca. 2600 BC.
    Creators: Francis Deblauwe
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Gabriel Bodard; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott; Valeria Vitale
    Modifications: modified Imagery location of Tell Beydar (update); created OSM location of تل بيدر; created CIGS location of Tall Baiydar
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Tell Brak
    Tell Brak, located in the Upper Khabur of northeastern Syria, was occupied between the sixth and second millennia BCE. The tell stands ca. 40 m tall and covers ca. 130 hectares.
    Creators: M. Roaf; S.E. Kroll; St J. Simpson; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Eric Kansa; Francis Deblauwe; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; B. Siewert-Mayer; DARMC; H. Kopp; R. Talbert; W. Röllig
    Modifications: edit summary; update references; modified name "Tall Birāk" (change type, update dates); modified name "Tall Brāk" (change type, change language to Arabic)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell el-Borg
    Fortified site dated to the New Kingdom located on the eastern frontier of Egypt, just into the Sinai Peninsula.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Tell el-Borg (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell el-Heir
    An ancient site in the Sinai that was the location of a series of successive fortresses from the Persian through the Roman periods. It may be identifiable with the Greek name Magdolos and/or the Hebrew name Migdol. There is also some speculation that much earlier textual evidence for a fortification of Ramses III should be tied to this site as well.
    Creators: A. Bernand
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added HANE-EC reference; summary; added Defernez 2023; modified OSM location of Grenzfestung des Ramses III (fort); modified name "Magdolos" (BAtldir uses question mark)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Tell el-Hesi
    Archaeological site located in southern Palestine with signs of habitation (with gaps) from the late Neolithic through the Hellenistic period, as well as burials from Late Antiquity.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: modified OSM location of תל חסי (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance); modified CIGS location of Tel Hesi (update references, edited); created CIGS location of Tel Hesi; modified name "Tel Hesi" (update references)
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Tell en-Nasbeh
    Tell en-Naṣbeh is an archaeological site ca. 12 km north of the Old City of Jerusalem. The site is often identified with the biblical Mizpah in Benjamin.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Noah Kaye; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Tall al-Naṣbah; created name "Tall al-Naṣbah"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Tell es-Sweyhat
    Tell es-Sweyhat or Sweyhat refers to an ancient settlement mound or tell located along the Euphrates river in what is now the Raqqa Governorate of northern Syria. This human settlement was occupied from the beginning of the third millennium BCE until its collapse in the early second millennium BCE. The site remained occupied during the Early Bronze-Middle Bronze age transition. There is later reoccupation of the site during the Hellenistic and late Roman periods.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Tell es-Sweyhat (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell Habuba Kabira
    The northernmost of two associated settlements located on the western bank of the Euphrates, showing signs of habitation from the Late Uruk period through the Middle Bronze Age. Rescue excavations were conducted at the site before it was inundated by the Tabqa Dam Reservoir in the early 1970s.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Ḥabūbah; created name "Ḥabūbah"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Tell Hammam al-Turkmen
    Tell Hammam al-Turkmen is an ancient settlement mound or tell located on the left bank of the Balikh river, approximately 80 km north of Raqqa, Syria. The tell has a diameter of 500 meters and stands 45 meters tall.
    Creators: M. Roaf; S.E. Kroll; St J. Simpson; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; update summary, references; created OSM location of تل حمام; created CIGS location of Tall Ḥammām al-Turkmān; created name "Tall Ḥammām al-Turkmān"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Tell Ischali
    Tell Ishchali is an archaeological site in Iraq's Diyala province. Its main floruit in antiquity was from ca. 2700–1800 BC, primarily Dynastic through the Isin–Larsa period. The site was part of the city-state of Eshnunna.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell Jidr/[Dabrum]?/Karkar?
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 93 B2 Tell Jidr/[Dabrum]?/Karkar?
    Creators: A. Hausleiter; M. Roaf; R. Wenke; St J. Simpson
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; P. Flensted Jensen; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created CIGS location of Tall Jidar; created name "Tall Jidar"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Tell Khaiber
    A tell in southern Mesopotamia (modern-day Iraq located 13 km kilometers west of Nasiriyah and 25 km south of the ancient city of Larsa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Tall Khaibar; created name "Tall Khaibar"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Tell Mohammad Diyab
    An archaeological site in northeastern Syria inhabited in the Early Dynastic through post-Akkadian period (ca. 2750-1800 BCE).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: created CIGS location of Tall Muḥamad Diyāb
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell Mohammed Arab
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 89 E4 Tell Mohammed Arab
    Creators: M. Roaf; S.E. Kroll; St J. Simpson; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: create DARMC citation to preserve cross-project linkage after retracting DARMC location; created CIGS location of Tall Muḥamad ‘Arab; created name "Tall Muḥamad ‘Arab"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Tom Elliott
  • Tell Qasile
    Archaeological site on the Yarkon River in modern Tel Aviv, identified as a Philistine city inhabited during the 12th and 11th centuries BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of תל קסילה (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell Wilaya
    Tell Wilaya is a small site that was occupied from the Jemdet Nasr Period to the Old Babylonian Period. Its ancient name is not known, but it may have been Keš.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
    Modifications: modified OSM Location of Tell Wilaya (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance); created CIGS location of Tall Wilāiyah; created name "Tall Wilāiyah"
    Actors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Telmessos
    Telmessos (modern Fethiye) was an ancient city of Lycia.
    Creators: C. Foss; S. Mitchell
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references; created connection "Lycia"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Temenos of Athena
    Area on the north-east side of the Piana di Himera, delimited by walls and containing four religious buildings (temples A, B, C and D), probably dedicated to Athena. The foundations are still visible in the archaeological site of Himera.
    Creators: Valeria Vitale
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Jonathan Prag
    Modifications: modified connection "Himera" (Initial revision)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Temesa/Tempsa
    An ancient city located on the west coast of Bruttium, just north of the Gulf of Hipponium.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add MANTO 10217837: Temesa (Italy); add TGN 6005874: Tempsa (deserted settlement); add Ptol. reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tempio della Tosse
    The so-called "Tempio della Tosse" is an ancient Roman building along the river Anio. Its dating is problematic, but it is likely a building of late antiquity that is built on the site of an earlier villa. It has been interpreted as a nymphaeum, a temple, and also as a tomb.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: update references; modified OSM location of Tempio della Tossa (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple district at Hattusa
    An area of the upper city of Hattusha with the remains of up to 30 temples.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM Location of temple district (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple East of Lavinium
    From the 5th century BC.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: reference; iDAI.gazetteer
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Amenhotep, son of Hapu
    A mortuary temple located in the Theban Necropolis that was dedicated to one Amenhotep, son of Hapu, an official in the court of the 18th Dynasty pharaoh Amenhotep III. Numerous roles are attributed to Amenhotep, son of Hapu, including those of priest, scribe, and architect. Likely he received special dispensation for the construction of the mortuary temple.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Temple of Amenhotep, son of Hapu (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Apollo
    The Temple of Apollo (VII,7,32) in Pompeii is one of the city's oldest cults, dating to the sixth century BC. The sanctuary assumed its present appearance in the second century BC.
    Creators: Valeria Vitale
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: added De Caro 1986; update reference; modified OSM location of so-called "Tempio di Apollo" (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Apollo at Delphi
    The Temple of Apollo situated in the center of the oracular sanctuary of that god at Delphi. Visible remains today are a 20th century reconstruction of the temple rebuilt in the fourth century BCE following a destructive landslide (repaired and altered multiple times thereafter). The date and cause of the temple's eventual destruction sometime not earlier than late antiquity remain undetermined.
    Creators: Jonathan Mak
    Contributors: Adam Rabinowitz; Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Jake Lipscomb; Tom Elliott; Adria Hardy; Jake Lipscomb; Jennifer Garza
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Ναός Απόλλωνος (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Ares
    The sanctuary with a temple dedicated to Ares is located south of the Altar of the Twelve Gods in the Athenian Agora. The temple was originally erected at Pallene ca. 430 BC and sacred to Athena Pallenis at Pallene. The structure was moved to the Agora in the early first century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Temple of Mars (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Artemis Orthia
    An Archaic temple dedicated to Artemis Orthia within the sanctuary of this goddess at Sparta. The site contained rich deposits of votives and masks.
    Creators: Danielle Hoyer; Paul Cochran
    Contributors: Adam Rabinowitz; Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Temple of Artemis Orthia (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Athena Alea at Tegea
    An ancient sanctuary at Tegea dedicated to Athena Alea. The extant phase of the temple is attributed to Skopas who was responsible for rebuilding following a fire in 394 B.C.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Temple of Athena Alea (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Athena at Paestum
    A Late Archaic Doric Temple of Athena (ca. 500 B.C.) at Paestum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Robert B Camp; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Adam Rabinowitz
    Modifications: Ammerman 2021; modified OSM location of Temple of Athena at Paestum (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Athena (Ilium)
    The Temple of Athena at Ilion was a peripteral temple executed in the Doric order with a 12 x 6 columnar arrangement. Its creation is traditionally ascribed to Lysimachus (ca. 301-281 BCE), though it was later restored under Roman influence, likely during the principate of Augustus. Little of the temple, save its forecourt, remains in situ. It is mostly known from membra disiecta, including metopes uncovered during Schliemann's excavations.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: added Denker 2023; modified OSM location of Temple of Athena (Ilium) (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Athena Pronaia
    The Temple of Athena Pronaia, located at Delphi, is a peripteral Doric building (6 x 12 columns). It was built ca. 500 BC and is the largest building in the sanctuary of Athena Pronaia.
    Creators: Janna Newman; Monica Beltran
    Contributors: Adam Rabinowitz; Christian Dukes; Jeffrey Becker; Shanell Smith; Justina Gil
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Archaic temple of Athena (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Baalshamin
    Temple in Palmyra dedicated to the Canaanite god Baalshamin.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Modifications: update deprecated Arachne reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Bacchus
    Part of the complex of Roman temples at Baalbek, the Temple of Bacchus is one of the best-preserved temples of the Roman world. It is conventionally dated to the second century CE.
    Creators: jfu
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Temple of Bacchus (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Hera at Foce del Sele
    A sanctuary at the mouth of the Sele river in Italy with an octastyle temple dedicated to the Argive Hera.
    Creators: A.M. Small; I.E.M. Edlund Berry
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: add arachne, tgn references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Hercules, Lanuvium
    The Temple of Hercules at Lanuvium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Temple of Hercules at Lanuvium (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Hibis
    A large temple located in the Kharga Oasis that is dated to the Saite-Persian period.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Temple of Hibis (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Jupiter Heliopolitanus
    The Temple of Jupiter Heliopolitanus at Baalbek is considered the largest temple of the Roman world. It served as an oracular shrine.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; jfu
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Temple of Jupiter (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Minerva at Theveste
    The Temple of Minerva at Theveste dates to the third century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: added Arachne reference; modified OSM location of Temple de Minerve (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Roma and Augustus, Leptis Magna
    The Temple of Roma and Augustus at Leptis Magna is a large temple (ca. 46 x 20 meters) situated on the so-called "Old Forum". It was initially erected between 8 BCE and 19 CE using limestone from Ras el-Hammam. The temple has a pseudo-peripteral temple and is oriented to the southeast. Reconstruction and restoration in the second century CE used marble instead of the original limestone.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: created connection "Old Forum at Lepcis Magna"
    Actors: Gabriel McKee; Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Vesta at Rome
    The Temple of Vesta, located at the east end of the Forum Romanum.
    Creators: Sebastian Heath; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • *Templum Augusti

  • Tenedos (island)
    An island located in the Aegean Sea 5 km off the coast of Troas. Modern Bozcaada.

  • Thamusida
    A Roman city located in the province of Mauretania Tingitana, along the road from Tingi to Sala. The city is mentioned by Ptolemy, the Antonine Itinerary, and the Geographer of Ravenna.
    Creators: M. Euzennat
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: added De Grossi Mazzorin 2023
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Thanaramusa Castra
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 30 E4 Thanaramusa Castra
    Creators: T.W. Potter
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Thapsus
    An ancient settlement and port, located at modern Ras Dimass in the Tunisian municipality of Bekalta (Monastir). Habitation at the site dates to at least the 6th century BCE and continued through the Byzantine and into the Islamic period, but it appears that the main settlement itself relocated to Bekalta in medieval times.
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: summary; port; added locations after Tranoy; added Tranoy 2023; cleaned up references; created location "OSM Location: Monumental complex and baths"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Tharros
    An ancient Phoenician settlement located in western Sardinia on a promontory in the Gulf of Oristano, just south of modern San Giovanni di Sinis. While it originates as a Punic or Carthaginian settlement ca. 700 BCE, it continued as a major town in Roman times.
    Creators: S.L. Dyson
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added Floris 2023
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Thasos (island)
    The Aegean island of Thasos.
    Creators: E.N. Borza
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Perry Scalfano; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; G. Reger; R. Talbert
    Modifications: added MANTO reference; cleaned up references
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Thasos (settlement)
    Greeks from Paros founded a colony on Thasos in the middle of the seventh century B.C.
    Creators: E.N. Borza
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; G. Reger; R. Talbert

  • Theatrum Pompei
    Rome's first permanent theater, located in the Campus Martius. The complex was completed under the second consulship of Pompeius Magnus in 55 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Via di Grotta Pinta (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Thebai/Thebae
    The ancient city of Thebes in Boeotia (modern Greece).
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Maija Gierhart; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; G. Reger; R. Talbert; jfu
    Modifications: modified connection "Boeotia" (Initial revision)
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Theban necropolis
    Collective name for the complex of tombs and temples on the western bank of the Nile, opposite the city of Thebes/Luxor. The necropolis was used for royal and elite burials throughout the Pharaonic period.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Theban Necropolis (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Theches (mountain)
    A mountain and pass in the Pontic range near Trabazon where Xenophon says the 10,000 first sighted the sea. Its precise location cannot be determined today.
    Creators: David Braund; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; Diane Braund; R. Talbert
    Modifications: summary; added Mitford 2000; added Brennan 2023; cleaned up references; added Rood 2004; modified name "Theches" (Baseline created, added Greek name as attested, add Xenophon reference)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • The Deir
    Monumental religious building carved out of rock in Petra, Jordan which was used for a variety of complex religious ceremonies and customs after the time of its completion in the mid-first century CE.
    Creators: Amir Weksler; Louise de Picciotto
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
    Modifications: modified OSM Location of Monastery (Ad Deir) (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Thelepte
    Thelepte was a Roman city in Africa Byzacena. It achieved municipal status perhaps in the time of Vespasian and became a colonia under Trajan. The city played an important administrative role in fourth century AD north Africa.
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Thenebreste
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 34 unlocated Thenebreste

    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: update reference

    Modifications: update
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Theveste
    Theveste (modern Tébessa, Algeria) became a Roman center and, in the Imperial period, the Legio III Augusta was raised there. In later times Theveste is connected with the Donatists.
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: add TGN 7001307: Tbessa (inhabited place); update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • *Thiges/Castellum Thigensium
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 33 B4 *Thiges/Castellum Thigensium

    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • *Thisitana

  • Thoantion (promontory)
    An ancient promontory on the island of Rhodes, placed by Strabo opposite the island Chalke and the Sporades in general.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. Bennet
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert

  • T(h)onabaei
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 4 C2 T(h)onabaei
    Creators: D.T. Potts
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: von Wissmann 1976
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Thracia
    Thracia refers to a territory occupied by the Thraci (or Thracians), a human population of the northern Balkan Peninsula whose reach stretched from the north Aegean Sea to the Danube river. Parts of Thracia would eventually become incorporated into the Roman provinces of Moesia and Thracia.
    Creators: E.N. Borza
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; G. Reger; R. Talbert; Richard Talbert
    Modifications: added Sayar 2023
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Thracia (province)
    The Roman province as defined in the Barrington Atlas (BAtlas 100 L3 Thracia)
    Creators: A.S. Esmonde-Cleary; C.M. Wells; J.F. Drinkwater; J.J. Wilkes; R.C. Knapp; R.S. Bagnall; S. Mitchell; S.T. Parker; W.V. Harris

  • Thyrsos (river)
    The Tirso river, one of the most important rivers of Sardinia, flows from the Punta Pianedda to the Gulf of Oristano.
    Creators: S.L. Dyson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created OSM location of Tirso (river) mouth; created OSM location of Tirso
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Thysdrus
    Thysdrus (modern El Djem, Tunisia) was a Punic and Roman city of North Africa. It flourished in the second century A.D. and built its massive amphitheater in the third century. After an abortive revolt in A.D. 238, the city was destroyed by soldiers loyal to Maximinus Thrax.
    Creators: R.B. Hitchner
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: edited
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tiberis (river)
    The Tiber river is the third-longest river of the Italian peninsula, flowing 406 km (252 mi) from the Apennine Mountains to the Tyrrhenian Sea.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sarah Bond; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tibur
    A Sabine town, 30 km east-north-east of Rome, Tibur was the seat of the Tiburtine Sibyl.
    Creators: L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: created name "Tiburtes"
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • *Tiddis
    *Tiddis (or Castellum Tidditanorum) was a Roman city located in the Constantine Province in Algeria.

  • Tigranocerta/Cholimma/Chlomaron
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 89 D3 Tigranocerta/Cholimma/Chlomaron
    Creators: M. Roaf; S.E. Kroll; St J. Simpson; T. Sinclair
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Til-Barsip Archive 1
    In House C1 in the Lower City of Til-Barsip, 22 Assyrian clay tablets, as well as 2 Aramaic texts, were discovered in and around the doorway between Room XI and XII in a secondary position. The earliest text dates to 683 BC, during the reign of Sennacherib (704-681 BC), but most of the documents date later, to the reign of Ashurbanipal (668-ca. 631 BC). The archive belonged to a man called Hanni, with some of the texts also concerning a man named Ištar-duri, and consists of purchase and loan documents as well as some others, such as a juridicial agreement.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: added ORACC reference
    Actors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Seidler
  • Tillibari
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 35 C2 Tillibari
    Creators: D.J. Mattingly
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
    Modifications: update reference
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tilmen Höyük
    A bronze age settlement in the Islahiye valley of modern Turkey where habitation seems to have begun as early as the Late Chalcolithic.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: added Orsi 2022
    Actors: Tom Elliott
  • Tilurium
    Tilurium was the site of the fortress of Legio VII Claudia Pia Fidelis.

  • Timavus (river)

    Modifications: update references
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Timici
    A Roman settlement in Mauretania, mentioned in both Ptolemy and Pliny, has been associated with a site that was known as Sidi bou Chaïb in the mid-20th century. That site is now in the territory of the modern Algerian town of Taougrite (colonial Paul-Robert), Chlef province.
    Creators: T.W. Potter
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; R. Warner
    Modifications: add wikipedia
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Timpone della Motta
    The Timpone della Motta is an archaeological site located near Francavilla Marittima. The site was inhabited from the Middle Bronze Age onward. During the Iron Age, an Oenotrian settlement flourished here, one that developed into an important sanctuary. The site passed into Greek control in the later seventh century B.C. and was eventually abandoned following the Bruttian conquest of the region during the fourth century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: add Brocato 2022
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tincausari
    An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 37 E2 Tincausari

  • Tithorea/Neon
    An ancient city on the southern edge of the Kephissos plain. Known in modern times as Velitsa, the Greek village overlying the ancient site changed its name to Tithorea in the 1920s.
    Creators: J. Fossey; J. Morin
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; G. Reger; R. Talbert

  • Tomba degli Orazi e Curiazi

    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tomb of Cyrus the Great
    The Tomb of Cyrus the Great is located about 1 km southwest of the palaces at Pasargadae. It is typically dated to ca. to 559-529 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Tomb of Cyrus the Great (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tomb of Nebamun at Thebes
    Theban Tomb no. 65 (TT65), the tomb of Nebamun, dated to the reign of Hatshepsut. The tomb was reused in the Twentieth Dynasty for Imiseba, a member of the Theban Clergy. In late antiquity it (along with several of the surrounding tombs) was repurposed as an anchorite dwelling, called in modern times the "Monastery of Cyriacus."
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
    Modifications: modified OSM location of TT65 Nebamun/Imiseba/Monastery of Cyriacus (Reimported full node geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tonberon (river)
    The Hingol River flows some 350 miles (560 km) through Balochistan.
    Creators: M.U. Erdosy
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Hingol River course (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tongeren Gallo-Roman temple complex
    The Gallo-Roman temple complex of Tongeren is located in the northwestern part of the city of Tongeren. The site pre-dates the Roman city wall.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
    Modifications: modified OSM location of Tempelsite (Reimported full way geometry and updated provenance)
    Actors: Jeffrey Becker

  • Torre Astura
